description:
We were dying of thirst and ended up here. We wanted something refreshing so we went to with the sparkling matcha with cane sugar and yuzu. It was exactly what we wanted. I love matcha and have been to another similar place in SF but this place is way better. It seems very popular and they serve food. 

It seems like getting a seat may be difficult but I wouldn't mind coming back for a snack and trying out their other drinks.
author: Sarah C.

description:
Matcha EVERYTHING!

I love anything matcha flavored, so even though I was absolutely stuffed after dim sum and ice cream I still had to go.

When we arrived, the line was just at the door. There were about 10 customers ahead of us. There is a decent amount of seating at the restaurant, but most of it was full. We were lucky to be able to snag a table for 5 right after we ordered. Next time, I would probably get my drink to go.

Though not all the food items have matcha added to them the drinks definitely do. It was hard choosing a drink, but I defaulted to my usual latte (iced). I also ended up getting a matcha croissant to share with friends.

The matcha latte had a nice rich matcha flavor. I could have one of these everyday of the year. The croissant looked beautifully made but was quite disappointing. All my friends agreed that we couldn't really taste the matcha flavor. It just tasted like a regular croissant.

This is a must go for any matcha lover. I'll definitely be back if I'm in the area to check out more drinks!
author: Kevin W.

description:
Atmosphere: Everything is clean, minimal, and cute - from the plates to the tables and decor.

Foods / drinks:
- Sparkling Matcha + lime and mint: this was just okay because the lime was overpowering and made it taste like a mojito with a hint of matcha. The mint leaves were so fresh and the size was good.
- Matcha Latte: super tasty and just what you'd expect.
- Matcha Cream Puffs: Delicious.
author: Michelle B.

description:
Ah, Stonemill Matcha. This place is pure deliciousness. It has a café style, and has a chill/easy vibe to it. When I go, I get the Matchazuke, Katsu Sando, cheesecake, and matcha latte.

Matchazuke: I feel like I was transported back to when I first tried Dashi Chazuke in Tokyo. The Matchazuke consists of a decent sized filet of salmon on a bed of rice, with seaweed and scallions. Then, you pour the flavorful matcha broth in top. This meal is light, and will fulfill you.

Katsu Sando: I don't like sandwiches. But this is probably one of the only ones I'll eat. They have the perfect ratio of soft white bread to thick breaded meat, and small shreds of lettuce. When you eat it, it's very juicy and messy, but it's so good.

Cheesecake: This is a good cheesecake. I can't explain anymore.

Matcha Latte: Smooth, creamy, and hot. Filled with good flavor. Even though I am lactose intolerant, I still always find myself drinking this when I come here.
author: Jello O.

description:
The short: lovely spot for Japanese inspired food

Beautiful space, beautiful decor, beautiful layout, beautiful bathroom, beautiful food presentation, delicious food, beautiful server outfits, fast service

The downsides: the noise level is a little too loud to really enjoy the peacefulness of the matcha delights. 

I ordered the hojichata (a fun take on the horchata) and the korokke (potato croquette). Both were really delicious. I also sampled a friend's stonemill black sesame cake (too sweet for me but very delightfully flavorful for one bite)

The verdict: worth multiple visits
author: Catherine W.

description:
Hip matcha cafe tucked away on Valencia St. 

Came here with my sisters as we're matcha fiends and wanted to try drinks and their food. Overall we thought the drinks were really, really tasty and smooth, but food wasn't imperative to the visit. Prices are not outrageous, but again more than most people want to pay for a tea latte...

Hot hojicha latte ($4.50) 5/5
YUMMM this was our fave drink by far! The tea itself is a smoked green that tastes similar to genmaicha, but so so smooth and tasty when mixed with the milk. Must try! 

Iced matcha latte ($4.50) 5/5
Again, a delicious drink! They got the ratio of milk to matcha perfect! (Most places either too much or too little milk resulting in diluted tasteless mess).

Matcha pie ($5.50/slice) 3.5/5
This slice had 2 layers: the matcha layer at the bottom half and the whipped cream layer on top. Similar to a meringue pie or a light whipped pie in texture. Bottom layer was deliciously matcha flavored with good amount of sweetness. However, the top layer, which we thought had a hint of yuzu and some other fruit, was waaay too sweet and ruined the composition of the pie for us...

Katsu sando ($14) 2.5/5
To say the least-expensive for 3 small halves served in a cute basket. The tonkatsu was not as tender as we'd hoped, and the sauce a little overpowering. Not a bad sandwich, but your experience here would not be diminished without! 

Would probably come here to catch up with friends/hang out but too crowded and pricey to make it a daily routine.
author: Robin Y.

description:
Stonemill Matcha is a wonderful part of the San Francisco community! As a matcha lover, it's hard to say no to a cafe that has so many matcha options! From matcha lattes to fancy brewed matcha tea to matcha based pastries, you will find what you're looking for here. My favorites are the hot matcha lattes and the iced hojicha latte (which is seriously addicting). The mint matcha is also great, and the cheesecake is a great pairing!

There is often a wait, but the line goes by fast. The hard part is finding a table, especially on weekends, but if you're patient you'll be able to catch a table leaving as you finish your order. It's a little busy, so the place feels rushed, but that just speaks to how great everyone considers the place
author: Arya B.

description:
I wasn't too impressed the first time I came here but decided to give it a second try after seeing a few pictures from friends. 

I'm pleased to say I enjoyed it much more this time, so maybe I just didn't order the right thing for myself last time (some cake and cold brew tea). This time I ordered the matcha with yuzu while my boyfriend ordered the hand whisked matcha. The yuzu matcha was so refreshing and citrusy but still had a great matcha flavor. The hand whisked matcha was a great experience as well and also came with a small date that added a nice pop of sweetness. 

We both really liked our drinks and are looking forward to trying some of the food on our next visit!
author: Janice L.

description:
There is no place better than Stonemill Matcha for your lunchtime cravings or even for dinner. I tried nearly half of the menu, I have been to this place 4 to 5 times within last two months.  Matcha Latte and the cream puffs are the besttt!!
I can't get enough of them, the sandwich are the best too. I come here quite often, quite pricey then other places but the paying is worth the food.
author: Caroline B.

description:
Came here on a Saturday an hour before they closed. Parking was fairly easy although you have to pay for street parking. Line was a bit long and no tables were available. Pretty disappointed  that most of the items were sold out already. 

We ordered the matcha chocolate Mochi, matcha creme puff and a matcha latte. My favorite was the Mochi!! It was so chewy and sweetness was just perfect - not too sweet. The creme in the creme puff was super smooth which I though was better than beard papa's! Matcha latte wasn't anything special though. We ended up eating while standing because there weren't enough tables and some groups were just sitting and chilling after they were finished so we didn't stay long.
author: Denise J.

description:
I don't get to the Mission enough so when my friend suggested we come here for lunch I was a little more than excited to try this place. 

We got there exactly at noon and as expected from the yelp reviews, there was a queue to go into the cafe. When you get inside you have to queue again and (there's a sign that says this) you order, find a seat and put your number on the table. No savesies for tables before ordering. Thank goodness a lot of people were doing takeout so after we ordered we were able to get a table right away.

We ordered so much that it was almost comical to see two girls with ALL these dishes but what can I say? We were hungry and wanted to try everything! We had:

Hojicha Latte (hojita, milk and cane sugar): I tried this and this was refreshing (she ordered it cold).

Ginger Matcha Latte (matcha, fresh ginger, fresh milk and cane sugar): I like matcha lattes but I think the ginger was slightly overpowering and could hardly taste the matcha. 

Sesame Sponge Cake: I'd heard good things about the sponge cake and it did not disappoint. I'm not a fan of desserts or pastries but when I do eat them I like the Asian version, ie not so sweet. I could taste the slight sweetness and black sesame.

Matcha Cream Pie: The pie was really good! The cream on top was amazing and the matcha underneath was slightly sweet which made everything perfect with the flaky crust.

Matcha Croissant: Huge, flaky and buttery croissant with matcha flavor. This didn't quite work for me but I was glad I tried it.

Cheesecake: I am not a fan of cheesecake but tried this, to me this was just cheesecake but not as sweet as other cheesecakes.

Goat cheese pizza: I guess in our excitement we wanted to try the pizza but it was just meh for us. It was heated up but it still lacked flavor and crunchiness that a pizza should have in the crust.

Katsu Sando (pork cutlet, tonkatsu sauce and cabbage): This was my favorite thing on the menu. Crunchy pork cutlet and  cabbage in between two pieces of soft white bread with crusts cut off.....WOW.

Matchazuke (rice, salmon, nori, green onion, chicken dashi and matcha):  When they bring this out they pour the matcha and chicken dashi over the rice and what happens is a bowl of comfort food. Salmon is perfectly cooked and goes really well with the rice and soup/matcha. I could taste the matcha and it went well with the whole dish.

Everything was IG worthy so of course we had to take tons of pictures. That's what I love about Japanese food - sometimes it's so pretty I can't  bear to eat it.

Service was quick and efficient, they were hustling to get us our dishes as fast as possible so we could leave in a timely manner. They didn't rush us out of the cafe but we appreciated their attention to us whenever we needed anything and didn't have to wait around.

I was definitely impressed at the quality of all the items we ordered. Everything was fresh and beautifully presented. I am going back sooner rather than later to get the Furikake Croissant, Yuzu Meringue Tart, Chicken Okayu and Korokke.
author: Nette T.

description:
Long line moves fast.

Interior - Simplistic, open space, relaxing, and modern.

Service - Good. Order at the counter, get a number, and find a seat. Employees do a reasonable job in patrolling the restaurant to ensure customers aren't saving seats without food in hand.

Pastries - Overall, a few dollars more expensive than other Asian bakery chain counterparts. Hit or miss.

Black sesame cream puff - Tasteless. Beard Papa has the best cream puffs.

Matchazuke - Bland but warm and comforting. Medium rare, decently sized cube of salmon fillet sitting pretty on a bed of warm, gooey rice soaking up matcha soupy flavors. 

Black sesame cake - Homerun, must get item! If you love black sesame and angel cake, this was the perfect combination of black sesame frosting and fluffy texture.

Genmatcha cold brew - Refreshing, brown rice tea.

Katsu sando - Served in a very cute picnic basket. Three cuts of thick katsu in a sandwich. Delicious, savory, and filling.

Note to self - Must come back again because I skipped out on the many signature items like matcha items (duh), lattes (duh again), yuzu meringe tart, and hoji-cha. Everyone else ordered these items and seemed to really enjoy them. Dairy-free alternatives available.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
Modern, minimalistically decorated matcha cafe in the Mission. Busy on a weekday, around 2pm; laptop campers took up the bulk of their seating. Peaceful vibe, chill staff members. 

Hojicha Latte is creamy, earthy, & sweeter than I expected; a contrast from my Shokupan Toast (Japanese milk bread with matcha butter & anko jam) which tasted savory but looked like dessert. The matcha isn't overpowering & the muted purple & green are visually intriguing when spread. 

Matcha fans are sure to adore Stonemill Matcha. Unlikely to convert coffee addicts used to typical American cafes, but an interesting change for one afternoon.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
Around 4:00 pm on a Saturday, the line was out the door at Stonemill and the limited seating was completely full. Undeterred, I waited in the line (which the cashiers did a great job at working through very quickly) and ordered my food to eat-in, in the hopes that a table would open up.

I went with the iced hojicha latte ($4.50), katsu sando ($14.00!), kinako butter chocolate chip cookie ($3.00), and hot matcha latte ($5.00). In an effort to combat people saving tables, Stonemill asks that guests dining in order first, receive a number, and then take the number to an open table. I got my number but had to wait at one of the standing counters until a table opened up and I swooped on it. Be prepared for this to be your reality, as well (unless you're lucky enough to drop by when it's not so busy), which I really don't care for. Seating anxiety isn't something I look forward to when I'm just trying to enjoy an afternoon snack. I will give Stonemill credit, though, for asking that guests not use laptops at tables from 10:00 am - 4:00 pm.

My order came out shortly after I landed a table. The hojicha latte was really good and not at all too sweet, which I was worried about. I appreciate that they offer an iced version. The cookie was TINY for $3.00, and while it was quite good it really didn't taste any different than any other salted chocolate chip cookie I've had, so I feel like the price wasn't justified here. And speaking of ridiculous prices, that katsu sandwich (because God, do I hate the word "sando") is NOT worth $14.00. The katsu is cooked well and coated in a delicious katsu sauce, but the ingredients consisted of simply white sandwich bread, katsu, and lettuce. For one person it would be just satisfying enough, but sharing between two people just kept our stomachs from rumbling as opposed to feeling full. I had no complaints about the sandwich itself, I'm just failing to see the reason for its price.

I'm not a matcha fiend and don't totally get the hype around it (it's good but it feels like the hype is due to it being yet another food fad), but the latte was tasty and had a delicate flavor. But as my boyfriend got to the end he said the flavor became bitter, which he suspects may have been due to sediment settling at the bottom of the cup.

Overall, everything about Stonemill, from their decor aesthetic to their food, is lovely, and it's clear that quality ingredients are being used, but this is a pricey place with a somewhat stressful seating situation that takes from the enjoyment of going to a cafe to get an afternoon latte and a snack. Everything was delicious and I'd order it all again, not to mention that there are a number of desserts and pastries I still want to try. Just be aware that if you're coming at a peak time you may be standing around waiting for a table to open up before you can sit down and enjoy your food and drink.
author: Angela M.

description:
Finallly visited Stonemill Matcha for lunch and it's such a cute cafe! Love the choices of matcha that they have as well as their snacks.

I ordered the katsu sando and my friend ordered the matchazuke! The katsu sando was simple but I liked it! It was a deep fried pork cutlet sandwiched between two pillowy soft slices of white bread with tonkatsu sauce. It came in 3 pieces and I actually only finished 2 because I was full. I got to try a little of the matchazuke and that was surprisingly good.  I've never had anything like it! It was rice with salmon on top, and the broth was savory with a matcha kick. Definitely worth a try!

We both got iced matcha lattes and those were yummy as well. Super authentic and a good size. Employees are friendly and space is pretty big, but seating is limited around lunch time. Come early if you want to get a good seat!
author: Tara A.

description:
My favorite cafe. Foods and macha latte here is must try. I heard it's pretty busy in weekends so I visited 8 am ish Saturday and there was only a few customers. I liked visiting cafe in the morning to enjoy the quiet and calm atmosphere.
I ordered Macha latte, ochazuke and chashu denish. Everything was great. Macha smelled fantastic. Ocyazuke was new. I am Japanese and have ate hundreds of chazuke but never had chazuke with macha. Usually we eat w green tea. It was surprisingly good. Chashu denish was good too. I was really hungry but I barely finished them. Its a little pricy but it's in SF
author: Nazuki Y.

description:
Hmmmm, I'm not sold quite yet. I got a green tea matcha croissant ($5) and the stonemill cake. The matcha croissant honestly didn't have matcha flavor at all, and I was even more let down by the textures. It wasn't flaky at all like a croissant should be and was actually really hard to rip apart. Maybe it was old? 

The stonemill cake on the other hand was delicious and definitely made up for the croissant, enough to get my back in the door to try the other desserts. It's alive with that sesame flavor and hits you with every bite. It's so spongey and moist! I love the outer coating and how it adds sweetness to the cake. 

Interior is cute and laid back, fun place to hang out.
author: Lexi R.

description:
The first time I came here it was a week after their grand opening. No surprise it was insanely packed. Coming here on a Saturday afternoon only added to the frenzy of the crowd. I get it this place is the "hot and new" matcha place in SF. Firstly cause its new and secondly cause we don't really have any pure Matcha purpose shop in SF until this and Cafe Maiko opened. While our sister LA has been spoiled with such great Matcha stores for a while. 

Anyway back on target. The 1st time I came here we got Matcha and Hojicha Lattes and a matcha pastry and the item with rice drizzled in matcha sauce with salmon on top (sorry forgot the name). Both the matcha and hojicha lattes were terribly underwhelming. You couldn't taste any distinct taste from them. If you handed me either drink without telling me what it was, I wouldn't be able to guess Matcha or Hojicha. The rice bowl with salmon that was pretty good. I remember the salmon being nice and tender. The rice and matcha sauce didn't really have strong flavors but that salmon was gooood. 

So recently I came back here on a Friday afternoon after doing light hiking at Corona Heights. I was nearby and thought hey I'll give Stonemill another try. I struggled with parking so parked across the street in the no parking zone and ran inside to find....a line! At 3pm on a friday theres a line! Don't these people have to be somewhere?? (though I could as myself the same thing :/ ) So this time I got a Matcha cream pie and Hojicha Latte again on my second visit. I thought second times a charm I'm sure it might be different than the first. Nope. The Hojicha latte tasted just as bland as the last time. The matcha cream pie had a great crispy texture but the matcha flavoring was horribly bland. The cream even tasted slightly like lemon which is strange cause cream should have a fluffy empty taste to it to compliment the pie. 

Anyways I've only been here two times and I've haven't experienced the whole menu so maybe theres something that regulars are experiencing that I'm not. I'll likely come back a again to try some of their other pastries but I'll have my reservations to try their drinks.
author: Jude N.

description:
I'm a matcha fanatic and really really wanted to love this place. I tried the iced sparkling yuzu matcha tea, the yuzu tarte and the hojicha latte. I liked the hojicha's clean, round tea flavor and thought the yuzu tarte was a nice variation on key lime. However, the sparkling matcha tea was just ok- I thought it was too tarte and the use of sparkling water didn't add anything to the drink. My SO, who loves bubbly drinks, found it hard to finish. We ended up tossing half of it away- it was trying so hard to be so many things, and in the end just seemed like a chore to finish instead of a treat. 

I'll probably go back to try their hot matcha drinks and other treats...but only after the lines and hoopla die down.
author: Jean L.

description:
Just go here, seriously. 

If you like matcha or hojicha latte, you should go. I absolutely love their lattes, hot or cold. You can taste the authenticity, and it was well-mixed too.

If you like yuzu, their yuzu meringue pie is absolutely fabulous. It's sour and refreshing, perfect for an after-work bite on a hot sunny day. 

If you like matcha, either get the matcha cream puff or the matcha cream puff. The cream puff was really yummy, it's crispy but creamy and soft on the inside, but my absolute favorite dish here is the matcha cream pie. I don't usually like whipped cream, but here, the whipped cream tastes like it's yuzu infused. IT'S AMAZING. You should get this. It will not disappoint. I also tried the matcha croissant, which, in my opinion, didn't really leave an impression, so yea, get everything else.

If you're interested in something more filling, get the katsu sando or the matchazuke. Both are definitely really good. The bread from the sando is super soft, which balances the juicy yet crunchy katsu. The matchazuke is a unique take on the traditional ochazuke with poached salmon on rice, but it's definitely a winner.

In conclusion, just go. 
(Except if you're trying to do work, it's crowded and there are specific times when you're not allowed to use your computer, so maybe don't)
author: Shannen B.

description:
I'm very excited about this brand new addition to the Mission.  This cafe is very beautiful, stylish, and well designed.  It's all about Matcha: matcha lattes, ceremonial matcha, matcha desserts, etc.

I loved the sparkling matcha which is mixed with seltzer water.  I didn't even realize you could do this.  It's perfect if you like flavored club soda (they can also make it sweeter if you want) and great for to-go on a hot day.  

The food menu is limited so I usually just come here for drinks. This is the type of place you want to come back and try everything on the menu.
author: Joan W.

description:
I felt like Rihanna could sum up my feelings best about Stonemill Matcha...

"And I hate how much I love you, boy (yeah)
I can't stand how much I need you (I need you)
And I hate how much I love you, boy (ooh, whoa)
But I just can't let you go
And I hate that I love you so (ooh)"

I hate that I love the fancy posh decor, solid wood design, and deliciously exquisite drinks & desserts because the price tag makes me feel guilty. Like have I really become one of those people that indulges in a $5.50 slice of matcha cream pie? Yes, yes, apparently I have. Because that matcha cream pie is a slice of heaven...delicious full matcha flavor, balanced with a light whipped cream, and a flaky crisp pie crust. Yum.

The hojicha latte is also delicious. Just enough sweetness to not overpower it, a beautiful latte art design, and of course to top it all off, it's served in a handcrafted mug.

Lines can get rather long and sometimes it's difficult to find a seat. But, the desserts are really delicious. Not a fan of their croissant-like pastries, but the cream puffs and the matcha pie are amaze-balls.
author: Jess Y.

description:
On my way to check out Everlane, I decided to pop into Stonemill Matcha for a quick bite and Matcha latte. 

The space is large and simple. The tables are close together so I'm not sure this is the best place to set up shop and do some work on a laptop, but it's possible. 

I ordered the Matcha latte and the potato/beef fried balls (forgot the name) and everything came out very quickly. The Matcha latte was very Matcha-y and good and the potato/beef/carrot meatballs reminded me of Russian food- Russian food consists of 95% of dishes involving potatoes and beef (just kidding, but it really is a high number with those 2 ingredients). The fried balls were good, but the sauce they came with was better! 

This is a nice place to check out if you're a Matcha fan.
author: Irina R.

description:
I was in the neighborhood and wanted something a little different for lunch. I walked around a few blocks before I stumbled upon Stonemill Matcha. I wanted something healthy so I ordered the Matchazuke ($16). 

To be honest, I didn't expect much of anything when I got my order, but after I took the first bite of the rice and the macha soup I said to myself hmmm Oishii... The salmon was seasoned and cooked perfectly. I wish there was more of it (the bowl was small), but I was very satisfied by the time I finished (in literally less than 5 minutes). 

The restaurant was nice and clean. The staff were very friendly. I wouldn't mind stopping by here again when I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Tawan G.

description:
Stonemill Matcha rivals the matcha you will find in Japan! I know, that's a huge statement but it's the truth. BUT, there is a reason why I am giving them a 4-star rating and read on and you shall see why....

The GOOD:
- The Ginger Matcha Latte was a foreign pairing to me but when I tasted it, it just worked! The ginger doesn't overpower the matcha.
- The Matcha Pie is delicious! At first sight, it looks questionable because I wasn't sure if I would taste the quality of the matcha, but I did! The taste of the matcha is slight but still good. The pie crust pairs beautifully with the matcha.
- The Iced Matcha Latte has that premium matcha taste you will find in Japan!
- There's outdoor seating.
- It's pretty spacious inside.
- There's two bathrooms inside. Hey, this is a plus because some establishments don't have them for their customers.

What Could Be Better:
- The Matcha Cream Puff wasn't great for the price. It's probably more presentation if anything. It costs $4.5 and it tastes like the Matcha Cream Puff at Beard Papas. At the Newark, CA location, it cost $2.9 without any additional bells and whistles.
- The Matcha Pie runs out fast. It's like you have to be here no later than 1pm to get a slice. They close at 6pm so I think they should think about making more especially for their matcha fans; one being me that is coming from out of town :)

Overall, this place is good and I would definitely come back to show some love!
author: Loreto D.

description:
Tip: expect to wait 5-10mins for food and another 10 mins for an open table (be on a look out!)

What we ordered (ranked):

#5 Matcha croissant: bland, dry, lacked the rich buttery flavors and flakey texture. You know when you buy a bag of chips and it's really bad but you are already half-way committed so after you finish you kind of just hate yourself?...This was it. 

#4 Matcha Latte: it wasn't sweet or creamy and lacked matcha flavors. 

#3 Matchacano: turned out all of the matcha was in this cup! It was really rich in flavor and it was cool to watch them whisk the tea. 

#2 Katsu Sando: really tender fried katsu pork and love the tonkatsu sauce. 

#1 Hojicha Latte with Oat milk (not pictured): it had a well-balanced sweetness and hojicha tea flavors. 

Overall, would not be back for the pastries. However, I would return for the drinks and maybe the hot items.
author: Fei S.

description:
What's not to love about a matcha place? Stonemill matcha checks all the boxes for a matcha fanatic like me. They have the drinks and the pastries. They also have savory food, which I didn't get a chance to try, but would love to come back for - next time!!

Even for those who aren't as diehard into matcha as me, they have other Japanese flavors like black sesame and hojicha and fruit-mixed pastries, so there should be something for everyone! They have a very decent storefront on Valencia, with some seating outside as well. Good selection of pastries even when visiting later in the day. They have a version of the matcha latte with ginger, in case anyone enjoys ginger. They also have dairy-free alternatives for the milk, though they are additional cost. If you dine in, they give you a cute wood block with your number on it :)

The matcha cream puff was delicious! The cream puff had the harder crispier shell instead of the softer one that you get at like Beard Papa's, and the matcha cream comes allll the way out to give you extra matcha-lovin'! Very delicious and great for sharing as well. I definitely would recommend both the matcha latte and cream puff!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Come here if you love matcha! Amazing matcha latte with oat milk, yuzu and matcha desserts, as well as savory food infused with matcha. Try their hojicha (toasted tea) as well, amazing slight burn flavor and taste. The line can be long but moves relatively fast.

They use really strong matcha here. I couldn't fall asleep the night after but it was worth it.
author: Norases V.

description:
Just the matcha cream pie alone would lure me here anytime of the day! That is a definite must order if you're here. We got here on Saturday around 12pm, so pretty much the prime time for brunch. There aren't many tables and seating considering the amount of people who come here, but don't sit down until you have ordered your food for dine in. The servers will ask you for your number that you place on the table. 

I also ordered the matcha iced drink and a honey roll. You can ask for varying sugar sweetness which is always a plus. They handed us a table number and we waited for about 5 minutes before a table cleared up. We had to sort of hoover just in case someone else swooped in. We combined two tables eventually for our group. The pie like I said was amazing! It was the perfect proportion of matcha cream and regular cream. The crust was very flaky almost like a croissant. The honey bun was actually pretty hard but also pretty tasty as well! SF ordered their kotsu sandwich after we tried our baked goods since he was still a bit hungry. He regretted doing that because that sandwich was so deceivingly filling! I took a couple bites and that chicken was thick. All it needed was a bit of sauce and it would have been perfect. Can't wait to come back for that slice of matcha pie!
author: Ada C.

description:
Stonemill matcha DEFINITELY lives up to the hype. I was pleasantly surprised at not only the food, but the service and the space. As you enter into the restaurant, the intention is obvious. It's almost artistic how everything is set up. There is limited seating and sometimes it's difficult to find a spot, even during lunch when you wouldn't think it's as crowded!

Their items are a bit pricey but thankfully everything is a good portion size and tastes delightful. I highly recommend all of the items I bought which include: matcha cream puff, katsu sando, shopan toast, and matcha latte. I split everything with my friend and it was more than enough for the two of us.
author: Angelina H.

description:
Service: 5
Ambiance: 5
Food: 4.5
Price: 3

The line to order is intimidating, but moves fast. Once you order, the real challenge of finding a table starts. 

The service was excellent. From ordering at the counter, to the food/drinks served, all the way to clearing plates as we finished. The staff was super friendly, knowledgeable, and attentive. 

The aesthetic of this place is 110% on-point. Simplistic, open, and bright. 

The food was pretty good, too! I ordered an iced hojicha latte with 50% sweetness and almond milk (for an extra $1). It was refreshing and the tea was strong.

I also got the matchazuke, which I was apprehensive about. It came with an ok portion-sized grilled salmon topped with crispy salmon skin. It sat atop a scoop of rice, which the server will pour the savory matcha broth onto. The salmon was cooked perfectly - just slight under so it remained juicy and soft. The matcha broth was good, too. It was not very strongly matcha-flavored, though.

Overall, we got 3 lattes (each with almond/oat milk for +$1), 2 matchazuke, 1 katsu sando, and 1 yuzu tart. It came out to be $90 after tax and tip. This is quite pricey and overpriced for the amount/quality of food.
author: Jessica C.

description:
I love coming in here. When my friend first recommended this matcha specialty shop to me, I knew I just had to go, and when I went not 3 days after hearing about it, I was not disappointed!

First off, the drinks and food are all amazing (at least what I've tried so far). The Hojicha Latte is a bit on the thicker, heavier side, but is very aromatic and definitely made with freshly brewed tea. The Matcha Latte is great as either iced and hot and is naturally my go-to drink.

My friend and I had a brunch fest here some Sunday and ordered the Katsu Sando (Fried Pork Cutlet Sandwich), Matchatsuke, Matcha Cream Puff, as well as the Yuzu Matcha Meringue. Although all of them tasted great, I think the Katsu Sando was our favorite, as it just tasted very homemade, like something you would get for lunch as a child. The Matchatsuke was very unique and the flavor was very light. The salmon was cooked to perfection and peels right off with a light touch of the fork. The matcha broth was bitter but not overly so and complimented the salmon well. I have a terrible sweet tooth, so I loved the Yuzu Matcha for the tart flavor and the Matcha Cream Puff for the sweet matcha taste (beats Beard Papa's in my opinion)! I've also ordered their Matcha White Chocolate Cookie for the road and that cookie is very decadent and softly baked, just the way I like my cookies! They also top this cookie off with some dried crunchy rice grains, which surprisingly compliments the white chocolate and brings out the matcha flavor of the cookie as well.

The ambiance of this shop varies, depending on what day of the week or time you go-- It's very quiet and nice to work in during the wee morning hours, but the later in the day it gets, the more crowded and louder it usually becomes. The shop definitely tries to accommodate for this type of heavy customer traffic, but I think the seats could be spaced out a tiny bit more, especially at the bench table seats.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this place to try and if you can, to come and enjoy the early morning ambiance before the crowds come in.
author: Victoria W.

description:
Very nice place to go to if you are in the area. 
I went on a Sunday, and I expected a line. And surely at 11 am, there was already a small line forming in front of the door. While I was in line, I was worried we wouldn't get a table because there were a lot of people waiting for a seat. Luckily, my boyfriend found a seat outside.
Because this was our first time, we decided to order a little more than usual. My boyfriend wanted to try the katsu-sando (pork cutlet sandwich). He had some in Japan and wanted to compare. I wanted to know what the hype was for the matchazuke. For a side, I ordered a cream puff and we each ordered a drink: Hojicha latte and mizudashi (genmaicha). 

Katsu-sando: Sandwich was pretty good. There's three sandwich inside a basket. The ears on the bread are cut off and a pretty big katsu is used. The only thing I didn't like about it was that they used too much tonkatsu sauce. I don't really like the strong taste, but this is probably preference and I'm sure some people love it.

Matchazuke: Pretty expensive for what you get. My boyfriend thought it would be bigger. There's salmon on top with nori and green onion on top. The waiter poured the matcha dashi on top for us and left some wasabi. Very comforting flavor and light compared to the katsu-sando. Good for light eaters, but not for someone who eats a lot. You can not to-go this.

Hojicha latte: Solid latte. It had the distinct hojicha flavor and it wasn't overly milky. It came in a nice cup. Next time I do want to take it out to-go. 

Our bill ended up being over 50$. It's a pricey place so I don't see myself going here a lot to eat. More like every now and then or on a special occasion. However, if I am around, I would pick up a latte. The struggles to find the table on the weekend was pretty bad and if it means to eat at the park, I wouldn't mind.
author: Kiyomi K.

description:
I finally got a chance to stop by this place and boy the line was forming nonstop. But it was definitely worth the wait. 

The place is small but very clean. You have to order your food first before  able to grab to table and there are not that many tables. Therefore, they're not allowed laptops during certain hours ( I believe 10am-4pm). 

A few things I tried: 

Matcha latte: it's good but nothing special 

Sparkling matcha: This was good and uinique! Very refreshing. You can definitely taste the matcha. 

Japanese Souffle Cheesecake: THIS IS A MUST! I know it is nothing matcha related but It was perfection. Perfectly sweet, perfectly moist and just perfect texture. 

Matcha croissant: I had high hope for this but it was quite mediocre, especially if you have had a chance to tried Tartine croissant.... I couldnt taste the matcha. The croissant was just too soft, like not flaky enough.

Matchazuke: Salmon, rice and matcha broth. Yes this sounds very weird, I admit. I thought so too. But my friend swore to me that it was worth a try so I went for it and I'm glad I did. It's a savory dish. The matcha broth is an interesting twist, in a good way. It balances out the salmon flavor and the perfectly cooked piece of salmon skin that comes with it. 

I highly recommend this place. I will definitely come back here again many more times.
author: Veronica N.

description:
This place is amazing!  How so?  Here are a few reasons why....
1) Upon walking toward the café, a few girls had a photo shoot holding a cup of matcha latte and modeling their newest kicks in front of the business.  If the outside is good, inside must be better
2) The menu and pastries in the display are simple items inspired by Japanese ingredients.  To take a danish and top it with chasu and Asian sauce, genius!  The layers were nice and crispy which is an extra bonus.  And the katsu sando with the soft bread and crispy pork was delightful.  All the ingredients were light, healthy, and delicious all together
3) The staff were kind and friendly 
4) Although the place was packed, the environment was very peaceful 

If you're in the neighborhood, do stop by, grab a latte and a small bite and relax.
author: Linda N.

description:
My friend took me here for a matcha run. The interior is very cute! It def has a nice ambiance to enjoy a good cup of matcha with friends :) I got the sparkling matcha with yuzu.. was overall pretty good! My friend got the hojicha latte which I thought tasted delicious!

There are a number of baked goods. We split the black sesame cream puff and the matcha cake. The matcha cake was pretty good, but the black sesame cream puff was just okay. The cream puff tasted a few days old, so I wouldn't want to order it again.

Customer service is okay. Honestly, the casher and servers seemed to not really enjoy being there, so it didn't seem like the best service. Overall was a good one time experience and would want to check out other matcha places next time.
author: Jackie C.

description:
I'm pretty sure I ordered everything they had on the menu.

Honestly though, I spent like $70 here...on 12 things....for myself, because I couldn't decide and wanted to try ALL of it. They were probably judging me but I have no shame. When I'm on vacation, 90% of my budget is for food and this was 100% worth every penny. I regret nothing.

Actually, I regret not ordering whatever was left on the menu I didn't order. Next time I will bring a few friends and we'll split everything on the dang menu. It'll be worth it. They shall see. Heck, it'll even be on me if they're weary and then they'll thank me. Forever. Because it's that good. 

I'm not sure why people are mad about this place? Have they no taste? Or patience? My only qualm is that it's absurdly busy. But that's not a negative reflection on the business?? That means it's good and people want to be there. I certainly did. I wanted to wait for my appetite to replenish so I could order everything again. But, alas, I had places to be.

I'll eventually post pictures of everything I had but my favorite was the matcha cream puff. Can I swear on Yelp? I want to swear out of pure joy at how good this was. The cream? Sweet Jesus. I wish I had room for more. The was definitely something I'd have had seconds of. 

The salmon dish is also fantastic. I appreciated the server explaining how to eat it because I honestly had no idea. At first I was like "why is she explaining how to eat a salmon rice bowl" and after she poured the matcha goodness on it and explained to break everything up, it made sense AND made all the difference. This was also very good salmon. 

Please open Stonemill Matcha in LA. I need it. I need 100x more of it. Every day. Forever.
author: Nikki I.

description:
~Food~  
Matcha Croissant: It was light green on the inside but I couldn't really taste any matcha. It's a good croissant but should probably skip it if you want a "matcha" croissant.

Sparkling Matcha w/ Yuzu: A more refreshing alternative to just a Matcha Sencha/Tea mix. The bubbles blended well with the light fruit (from the Yuzu) and grass (matcha) taste. 

Katsu Sando: It was juicy, crunchy on the outside, soft on the inside, and just very delicious. The soft bread really soaks up the meat juice and overall it was a good ratio of bread to meat.

~Price/Quality/Quantity~  
With all that said in the food section^, I don't think the items were worth the price tags. The croissant tasted like a regular croissant but with a $4.50~5 slap to your face. The Matcha drink had quite a bit of ice in it for $4.50 and though the Sando was oh so delicious, it was $14. 

~Atmosphere/Service~
Came here on a Sat. around 1pm and there was a line to the door but I didn't have to wait long to get my food. Finding a seat can be a bit of a struggle but the majority of people eat and leave so just keep your eye out.

~Bottom Line~
There are better places for each item by itself. Will you find another place that has all of them under one roof? Probably not likely. That and the atmosphere is what the premium $$ is for.
author: Lily L.

description:
I've been recently craving for any matcha-flavored food so since I was in the area, I gave it a try. I ordered Hojichata and a slice of Stonemill Cake (which I unfortunately forgot to take a photo of because I was excited to try it out ).

The Hojichata is a little bit on the sweeter side but it's really good. It's like a creamy roasted rice green tea with lots of cinnamon in it. Its color makes it look like an herbal drink but it taste better than what it looks.

The Stonemill Cake is a good pair for the sweet Hojichata because it's not too sweet. It has a distinct taste/after taste to it, maybe because of the Black Sesame. Its texture is spongey but very moist.
author: Isabela N.

description:
Yum.

Their matcha desserts are so delicious. The matcha cream puff and pie were so good. 

I thought the latte was good but could have been stronger in matcha taste.
author: Samantha N.

description:
I have to admit I tittered at the line describing their cafe on their website..."a serene space to pause". Not guffawed, just tittered as I see the intention in the West Elm-meets-Scandinavian Designs decor, but in the middle of a Thursday afternoon, there was nothing library-like about this spot. It was a zoo, and people were gunning for open tables like they were in line for the rotisserie chickens at Costco. The light Asian-inspired menu is right up my current alley with dishes like Chicken Okayu and the Barley & Veggie Bowl, but there wasn't a chance in hell I could get a table without getting heavy dose of small-mouth for my supposedly selfish act.

Until the hype subsided, I made do with the $5.50 Ginger Matcha Latte which was a nice albeit overly sweetened elixir of creamy delight with just a hint of ginger amid the fragrance of the tea leaves (photo: http://bit.ly/2NNlr5G). I have to admit as I was waiting in line that I was mesmerized by the artistry of all the sweet-savory-sounding items like the Furikake Everything Croissant and Chashu Danish (photo: http://bit.ly/2KUjoi6), and the Peach & Blackberry Roll Cake reminded me of a high-end version of the delectable cake rolls at Yasukochi's Sweet Stop in the Super Mira Market in J-Town (photo: http://bit.ly/2zB2xf5). I'll come back some day to get that feeling of zen serenity they described euphemistically on their site.

LATTE - 3.5 stars...promising latte that would have been nice with a slice of that roll cake...oh well
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...looked like it has possibilities of serenity amid the crowd 
SERVICE - 4 stars...serene and courteous
TOTAL - 3 stars...jury's out for now but I'm willing to go zen some other time
author: Ed U.

description:
Verdict: not bad. Seems like a typical hipster place (probably why i went =P) but given the price I probably won't be coming very often, especially since the items served aren't worth that amount of money.

I got three items, a matcha latte, the matcha cream puff, and the toast with matcha butter and anko jam.

The matcha latte was quite nice. Not bad. If i was passing by and there was no line I'd grab one. Nice and soothing, with a pretty good amount of matcha taste.

The food was ok but not great. The cream puff had really good smooth cream but the pastry was a bit hard and not flaky at all.
The anko jam on the toast was nice. I would've liked to see more of it since i enjoyed its taste. I did not taste any matcha in the matcha butter. The toast essentially only had butter and anko jam. For $6, it rivals the famed avocado toast as worst bang for your buck.
author: Desmond C.

description:
This 3 star review is not because the drinks or food was bad, instead it's more like total value.  Stonemill matcha is one of those places where you have to think if it's worth the money. I decided to give it a try because I couldn't resist the lure of matcha everything. 

I tried their matcha latte and matcha cream puff. In all honesty, Starbucks matcha latte is MUCH better, just need to get them to double the matcha powder, and it's slightly cheaper. The cream puff was good, BUT it was not worth it for the $5. 

Go at your own risk!
author: Jie L.

description:
Heart is racing!

From the caffeine and from how good it was. We ordered the matcha shaved ice (only served on the weekdays) and it was divine. 

While a little steep in terms of price ($11 or $14 with a side of roasted strawberries), they don't skimp on the matcha at all. The matcha is infused into the shaved ice and the shaved ice is topped with a creamy matcha and condensed milk glaze. It also comes with two delicate slices of lime. You must experience it with the lime. First take a bite without and then squeeze some lime and be amazed by the difference. I prefer it with the lime and enjoyed every last spoonful. 

It's a trendy minimalist spot and would be a hip place to have a client meeting or catch up with a friend.
author: Lisa K.

description:
Solid place with tons of matcha options. Though I can't speak to all the options, I've had the matcha latte and matcha desserts here which I've enjoyed.

I do love their to-go cups which are blue/white ombre, v instagrammable.
author: Sophia L.

description:
Matcha heaven. A little slice of Japan tucked away in the heart of the Mission. My new weekday haven, where I can meditate and feel centered with some matcha before beginning the workday. Stonemill Matcha would appear designed to be a quiet intimate spot for reading, relaxing, or hanging out with a small number of people. But during peak hours, the cafe bustles with people squeezing to find standing room. It's a little jarring and definitely ruins the serenity one would typically associate with a delicate cup of matcha. 

The Experience: You walk inside to be first invited in by a display of handcrafted ceramics atop a long bar. Along this bar sit lines of Matcha pastries, amongst them matcha croissants, cream puffs, soft and buttery matcha white-chocolate chip cookies, and matcha creme pie. The warm matcha-color glows against the slate colored bar, where you place an order and find a seat. There are a few tables outside as well, framed by a few plants and succulents, where you can sip on your latte and watch the eclectic locals of the Mission hurry by.

The Magic: It all comes down to the details that quietly shine through at Stonemill. Each item is served in a ceramic vessel designed for that particular dish -- a pleasant pairing of color and feel which culminates in a perfect tasting experience. And what stands out the most is how honest the cafe feels. The Matcha is whipped in front of you, the local artists behind the ceramics are showcased, you can purchase the traditional whisks and even the imported Matcha. Every ingredient to the final experience of sipping on that Matcha Latte feels transparent, which lends itself to a sense of security. Stonemill achieves its namesake: making its patrons feel at ease, grounded.

The Tips:
-- Don't go during peak hours! I've heard weekends are a hot mess, though I've never dared venture here on the weekends. Many open tables on weekday mornings until 3pm.
-- Matcha Creme Pie may actually be sent from the heavens. Typically creme pies are rich and sit heavy due to low quality cream. This feels like gently whipped custard -- like a fluffy French-style mousse -- that balances well in texture with the Matcha creme beneath. The crust is also absurd.
-- Chicken oyaku is the perfect remedy for a cold (or hangover!) Order for take-out and ferry it to your lover for relationship bonus points ;P
author: Jessica M.

description:
I love me some matcha. Matcha anything and I'm in. 

I met my friend here on Sunday around 9:15am. The lines and crowds start coming around 10:15am, so come here early to avoid waiting.

We both ordered matcha lattes. Really enjoy it with the oat milk, as it adds a different cosistency. I would come back to try their other drinks and food. 

There's a decent amount of seating. The place has that minimalistic, wooden design. 

YAH for matcha in the Mission!
author: Joanna L.

description:
A great matcha cafe with fantastic Japanese food as well.  While the main focus here is matcha, many of their items are also great as well.  The cafe itself surprisingly isn't too noisy, despite how busy it gets.  Seating can be difficult on weekends though as this place gets quite busy.  The hours here are a bit limited as they currently close at 6pm each day.  

On a Friday around 5pm, the crowd wasn't too bad here, getting a seat was pretty stress-free.  However, on a Saturday afternoon, this place had a pretty big line and given that it's free seating here, you might find yourself having trouble getting a table, especially with many parties sitting here well after they've finished eating.  If you're coming here with a party bigger than 2, you may find it difficult to get a table. 

Overall, I really loved the food here, it had a very authentic Japanese flavor with some unique twists.  I'll definitely be back for more!

Katsu Sando:
Really awesome to get a fresh pork cutlet sandwich.  The pork was very lean with little to no fat.  There was a bit of cabbage in it, overall it was a pretty traditional katsu sandwich.  The breading had a slight sweetness to it that was a little different but in a good way.  The tonkatsu sauce was on point as well.

Matchazuke:
The most passable of the savory items I had here.  It was still great, but for the price, I'm not sure if I would get it again.  It came with a decent sized piece of salmon and the matcha dashi was great, but compared to the other two, it wasn't as impressive.  But don't get me wrong, this was a fantastic chazuke that is maybe worth trying if you're a fan of the dish.

Chicken Okayu:
Super flavorful, I only got to sample this one, but it was addictively good.  The egg was really runny and the porridge was very flavorful.  Everything about this dish was great, probably my favorite of the entree-like dishes.

Pork Chashu Danish:
Looks can be deceiving, for those that eat more with their eyes, they'll probably pass on this one, but boy does this one pack a load of flavors into one pastry.  This was an incredible savory danish.  There was slightly fatty bacon like pieces of chashu along with some greens and onions.  If you're looking for a memorable pastry, this one is the one.

Stonemill Cake:
This cake was great if you like black sesame.  Like most things black sesame, the flavor is very potent.  The frosting layer is also a bit on the sweet side.  Overall, not bad if you have a sweet tooth or enjoy black sesame.

Sparking Yuzu Matcha:
I preferred this over the more traditional matcha drinks.  It always surprises me how well citrus goes with matcha.  I also don't see yuzu used enough as an ingredient around the Bay Area so it was great to see it available here.  This drink is mildly carbonated with a really refreshing quality.

Matcha Latte (iced):
Very smooth.  Much better than your Starbucks matcha (obviously).  It was a solid matcha latte that was also very creamy.  

Really a big fan of this place.  It hit the mark on pretty much everything in terms of food.  Hopefully, they work out a way to deal with all their popularity as it really makes seating a difficult process.  Can't wait to come back and try more of their stuff!
author: Bryson L.

description:
Yuzu matcha tart. Get in my belly now. Please!
Matcha Latte? I'll take one too!

The pastries have consistently been fantastic (Tartine makes them, go figure!) and the drinks have been spot on. I'm more of a matcha drinker than coffee so this place is perfect for me. 

Service is on point and quick, downside is that the tables turn over rarely so it can be hard to find a seat.
author: Vicky L.

description:
Cute hipster spot. You order then seat yourself. Water is also self served. 

We ordered:
1. Matcha cream puff ($4.50) This was the best out of the three times we ordered. It had a crunchy exterior and the matcha cream was perfect!! Not too sweet! (I usually can't finish the dessert if it's overly sweet) 
2. Japanese cheesecake soufflé ($5.50) This was not what I was expecting at all...it was actually more sour than sweet in my opinion. Wouldn't get it again...
3. The "pride" themed mini donuts ($4) It looked better than it tasted lol. It was regular mini donut holes with color sprinkles on it. Also sour and a little dull in my opinion. It made me more thirsty. 

It was good to try. If I were to come back, I'd only get the matcha cream puff and try a matcha drink.
author: Miranda T.

description: Best matcha in town with the best matcha mochi. Place is usually crowded  at pick hour on the weekend. Just grab a drink a go!:) or enjoy your cakes if you are lucky to get a seat inside. Lovely place. I just wish it could keep its vibe without those crazy lines.
author: Anna S.

description:
4 stars for one of the best hojicha latte's I've ever had! It's really creamy and flavorful unlike most other's I've had, which are more watery.

The line is long but moves fast. I was not so impressed with any pastries except the matcha cookie which was delicious!!! 
* Matcha Chocolate Chip Cookie - 5 stars - Soft, rich, with crunchy bits on top.
* Tonkatsu sandwich - 4.5 stars: Really delicious and served on white bread with crust cut off. Small and pricey.
* Matcha Cream Pie - 3 stars: Too sweet. Cream tasted like coconut or almond. Crust was flaky but needed to be more buttery.
* Matcha Cream Puff - 3 stars: Also too sweet, filling similar to the cream pie.
* Souffle Cheesecake - 3.5 stars: A good souffle cheesecake but I'm not a big fan. It reminds me of a chiffon cake more than cheesecake.
author: Jess C.

description:
A new addition that surprisingly excels in it's three main categories: matcha-based drinks, matcha-based pastries and Japanese-inspired light fare.  It's definitely a matcha lover's dream come true.  But the quality is so high, even non-matcha-fanatics will enjoy it.

Katsu Sando: It's like something you'd get at a 7-Eleven in Tokyo, but much fancier.  The cutlet must be made to order, because it took a while and was quite warm (as opposed to the pre-made cold ones at convenience stores).  The bread was extra thick and very fluffy with the crust carefully cut off.  There seemed to be just the right amount of tonkatsu sauce since the sandwich was never dry, but never dripped either.  The meager bit of finely chopped cabbage was just right to add an accent, without dominating.

Matcha Cream Pie: I actually started my meal with the pie since it was handed to me when I ordered.  Every meal should start with pie though!  It had the exact right texture of a good chocolate cream pie.  Except, of course, that the base was a very sweet and heavy umami matcha.  Paired especially well with the dense buttery crust (normally I'm not a big fan of pie crust).

Sparkling Matcha w/ Yuzu & Cane Sugar: Very refreshing.  Not chalky at all (despite the dark green cloudy appearance).  The sugar and yuzu almost made it feel like a Japanese Arnold Palmer.
author: Adam B.

description:
I got the sparkling matcha with yuzu. The place is a bit of a walk from the 16th street Bart station and a bit shady. The line wasn't that long although it was the afternoon during a weekday, it also went by quickly.

The interior of the place was very cute and it had limited seating areas. I would definitely come back again to try the food here. The flavors in the drink worked well together and I never knew you could do this until I came here LOL
author: Jeffrey C.

description:
Overpriced. Matcha latte was ok but not the best I've had (it was missing the "matcha-y" taste for my preference) The interior is very minimal and beautiful. 

Overall, I would recommend any matcha lover to try this place if you're around the mission area.
author: Bianca Z.

description:
Great matcha place in SF away from Japantown! I only wish it was closer to SoMa or downtown. 

Expect a line and don't expect to get a table. There is no WiFi, but people still can work there--i used XFinity WiFi and saw hot spots. I heard some business deals going on at the table next to me, and some people stood and eat (there were some places where people could stand with no chairs.) 

The menu is a bit pricey, but unique and good. I tried the Yuzu Meringue tart. I'm not sure if I would get it again--it was an interesting blend of flavors, and the meringue overwhelmed the matcha flavor. It is, however, very Instagrammable. I'd recommend the Sparkling Matcha with Yuzu--I've never seen something like that on any other matcha place's menu. It was cool and refreshing. 

Other reviews say the service was great, but I found them to be judgmental and not friendly. Maybe it was because it was a Friday late afternoon and the place was packed? 

The bathrooms are clean! 

If I'm back in the Mission, I'll be back to try some baked goods and maybe the hojicha latte.
author: Lizzie S.

description:
Service was extremely quick, especially for a Sunday morning. Japanese wabi-sabi aesthetic was everywhere: from the cafe interior design to the presentation of the food. What Stonehill Matcha absolutely excels in is its mastery of the delicate balance of ingredients. We ordered the hojichata, matcha latte, katsu sando and matchazuke. 

Hojichata - While its murky brown color is initially off-putting, once you take your first sip, there's no going back! Expected it to be some sort of rice pudding with too much cinnamon, but it was an excellent balance between hojicha, rice, cinnamon, vanilla, and agave. Not overpowering at all and actually a very light drink.

Hojicha Latte - Although I regret ordering this warm drink on a hot afternoon, it was excellent. Perfect amount of matcha - not too grassy or bitter, but not too sweet either. Would order again on a cooler day!

Katsu Sando - That pork cutlet was SO tender. It was a touch under seasoned, but the textures of this sandwich was wonderful. You've got layers of soft white bread with crunchy cabbage, wet tonkotsu sauce, crispy breading, then juicy pork. Would definitely order again. 

Matchazuke - Server pours the chicken dashi and matcha in your bowl in front of you, although I'd prefer to do it myself for playful purposes. Salmon was perfectly cooked - extremely moist and tender, sort of a "medium rare" with light raw pink left in the middle. Excellent blend of textures again: silky salmon, crunchy nori and furikake, and soft rice.
author: Shirley C.

description:
We love matcha! 

Parking: Paid street parking 

Ambience: Modern, clean, and multiple tables. No WiFi, so not ideal for studying and working.  

Service: The staff was great! For one of our orders: matcha croissant, one of the the employees let us know that she would refund our money back bc the pastry was not to the quality that they were looking for. I really liked that initiative and service. 

Order:  

- Matcha Latte, $5: You could really taste the matcha, and I liked how strong the tea flavor was in this drink. 
- Matcha Croissant: It was perfectly moist and flakey; however, you could barely taste matcha. 

- Cheesecake: I love Japanese style cheesecakes! This was so good and not too sweet. 

- Matchazuke, $16: This was my favorite dish! :) The salmon was cooked perfectly. The matcha and dashi added another complexity of flavor to this dish. 


Verdict: 5. Every dish was executed well. The service was great. The atmosphere was perfect for catching up and chatting. I would highly recommend it!
author: Michelle B.

description:
Ordered my Matcha Cream pie in a togo box because it's hard to handle a plate with pie and a toddler. I was RUDELY told that I couldn't sit there because I had a togo container. 

Definitely not coming back because of the rude service I received. Even after I told her why, she just looked at my kids and kept cleaning the table as if we weren't there.
author: Jenn V.

description:
Their desserts look really good, but it's not the American sweet desserts.  The flavors are subtle with a hint of sweetness, so you don't get overwhelmed with a sugar kick.  Pork katsu Sandoz was awesome.

The salmon matchazuke was AMAZING.  That would be my first pick if I wanted something savory.
author: Nathan S.

description:
Why is this place so popular? Stonemill Matcha hit the jackpot with its location, being situated in the heart of the Mission District on Valencia Street. But I have to ask, what is it that draws such ridiculous lines out the door to this place? It certainly isn't the matcha. Maybe the service (which is phenomenal and the only reason they're earning 3 stars) or the aesthetics and how Instagrammable everything is...

The matcha cream puffs are cute and extremely sweet (which is to be expected), but the actual matcha itself here is average and certainly nothing to write home about. (I even laughed when I received my matcha art and it looked like a shrunken onion, but oh well.) I preferred the hojicha, which was better than the matcha, but still not phenomenal.

Overall, come check it out if you haven't been. Be sure to take some dope snaps of your totes adorbs matcha to share with all your fans on the Gram. But don't expect it to taste good. If you're here to actually drink something, get the hojicha.
author: Phillip V.

description:
I was afraid that this would be insta food and not delicious but relieved to report it's delicious!

Matcha latte: good/basic

Ginger matcha latte: good if you like the taste of ginger, the taste was smooth/even

Sparkling mtacha with yuzu: my favorite! The taste was so refreshing and I love the tartness of yuzu

Shaved ice: At first, we didn't realize that you were supposed to mix the top (matcha+condensed milk) with the fine ice below but after mixing it was so good! The strawberries added are super sweet so disperse if ya can!

No WiFi but space is clean and calming. A nice day date or meeting up with a friend space.
author: Mimi T.

description:
The Katsu chicken sandwich is simple and tasty, and it's filling. It came in quarters and I barely ate half. The iced hojicha latte was good too. Just a bit of sweetness with enough hojicha.

You line up and order at the register and they take your items to you. There are quite a few pastry case items as well as hot items on the menu. 

It's quite the hot spot at the moment so it's hustling and bustling. Plenty of people sitting and working in the dining area. 

I will definitely be back to try more of their hot items and matcha goodies!
author: Anna R.

description: Got the Matcha Ginger Latte, and I highly recommend if you enjoy spicy things. The ginger gave the latte an extra oomph without it being too spicy. $5.50 is not inexpensive, but really worth it. I took mine to go for a stroll by Clarion Way (just two blocks away), but I also would love to stay in the cafe next time because the vibe is super quiet and chill. The mugs in which the matcha is served is also really beautiful and cozy. Would love to come back next time for their pastries or hot food menu items!
author: Li W.

description:
Came on a Saturday at 1pm and there was a decently long line. I didn't have to wait long and my order came out pretty quickly considering how many people were ahead of me. 

I got the matcha croissant and iced hojicha latte. I think you can pass on the matcha croissant, it doesn't taste much of matcha or much of a butter croissant. Somewhere in the middle. The iced hojicha latte was good in terms of flavor of tea but I thought they went a little heavy with the milk. That could just be me though because I like the earthiness of tea to stand out. 

I'll definitely want to come back to try the black sesame puff and matcha latte among other things!
author: Katherine Z.

description:
I've seen goodies from Stonemill Matcha pop up on Instagram for awhile and I finally had the chance to try them out this morning! Was running errands around Valencia and happened to walk past the storefront a little after 8am. 

I was originally going to order a regular matcha latte when I saw they had  GINGER MATCHA LATTE. Sign me up! Matcha and ginger are two of my favorite flavors. Of course I had to order a MATCHA CROISSANT as well.  Latte was rich, creamy, with great matcha flavor and some heat from the fresh ginger. I was very happy with the drink! Croissant actually didn't have much matcha flavor at all, however the layers were well laminated (thanks Great British Bakeoff for gifting me knowledge of what makes a great croissant), with lots of flaky layers and crispy exterior. It was buttery but not oily at all.

I can see the barista took care in making everyone's drinks. There weren't too many people in here on a Thursday morning but I still waited ~10 minutes or more for my drink. That's fine since it tasted well made! Just be aware if you're in a hurry.

Overall I can see myself coming back here for their lattes as a #yolo treat! But I have to exercise caution since I paid a little over $10 for a drink and pastry. I want to to rotate through their pastries to test out the flavors, and I definitely want to come back for their dessert items. I also want to try their pork katsu sandwich. Guess I'll have to make a visit again soon!
author: Bonnie Z.

description:
If you are a matcha lover this is your kind of cafe! I came here around 2PM or so, it was pretty crowded and seats were limited so prepare to wait and hustle for a seat, first come first serve!

I tried:
Matcha Latte: pretty good, not sweet at all, so you really taste the matcha! Recommend!
Katsu Sando: I really liked this, the katsu was cooked perfectly and the bread was so soft with some creamy mayo :D
Sesame and Matcha Cream Puff: Decent, I prefer the Matcha one more than Sesame, but both had good flavors! Super flaky :D

Great place for coffee with friends and a light snack!
author: Natalie L.

description:
This place is awesome. I got the katsu sando and sesame cream puff which were both super tasty and delicious. I love matcha too but currently being pregnant, I am having to limit my caffeine intake although as soon as I am able, I will be back to try many of their matcha offerings, including their drinks and matcha pastries. The matcha cream puff looked awesome although my black sesame one was one of the best cream puffs I've ever had. Kudos to their pastry team who I read are from the famous Tartine. Decor is great and this includes the presentation of the food. Very IG worthy. The staff are very attentive as well which is nice.

My only con to this place is that there are a lot of people on their laptops here and so seating is very limited. I came on a late weekday afternoon and almost took my food to go because there was no where to sit but luckily someone left as I was about to walk out the door. Some people are eating, but most people are just sitting around and on their computers. I know it is a 'coffee bar' but I think it is also a restaurant/cafe where I hope laptop people are mindful of those that purchased food and wish to eat it there.
author: Cicely T.

description:
After eating at Mixt for lunch I went to Stonemill Matcha for dessert.  It's a small shop with some seating, but not enough.  When I was in line I noticed only 1 table left that I was able to grab and this was on Fri 6/1/18 in the afternoon.

I ordered:

Ginger matcha latte $5.5 - it's a medium sized cup that if you have there, they bring to you.  It takes a bit of time to get so can't be in a rush.

I also got a chocolate chip cookie $3 - it was ok, too salty for me, I did finish it though.  I think I read that Tartine makes their pastries.

They have some regular food on the menu, I didn't pay attn to it.

I walked by on Sunday 6/3/18 and they have a line to get into the shop so if you want to eat there best to go early.

Hrs:
Daily 8am-6pm
author: Ann L.

description:
This place is great. Weekends have long lines, so come on a weekday when it's less crowded!

I love their hojicha latte. They have a bunch of baked goods that are pretty good - I tried their morning roll which was quite good (not standout though), their cream puff (which was really good!), and the stonemill cake which was this sesame flavored light chiffon cake, which was also good but not standout. I also tried their shokupan toast, which was meh. The matcha butter was pretty unique - for some reason I was expecting it to be sweet, but it was literally just matcha and butter so it was more salty/bitter tasting.

I really like their savoury food! I particularly enjoyed their matchazuke, which comes with a huge piece of salmon. It's basically ochazuke but they add matcha to the dashi broth which is genius! They pour in the broth for you when they serve it (it would be nice if they just gave the teapot and let you pour it yourself so you can add however much you want, when you want...) which makes the rice a little bit salty and bitter but it is so good with the furikake and salmon! I have no idea how they came up with such a great dish. I also like the chicken oyaku, which was the other savoury dish I tried.
author: Theresa L.

description:
Another gem on Valencia street! I've been here twice within the past month, and it's such a lovely place to catch up with friends. I absolutely adore the interior and their tableware aesthetics. 

FOOD
I tried the matchazuke on my first visit, which included salmon and rice in a matcha broth. I couldn't really taste the matcha, which was a bit disappointing. The concept is interesting and fun - something cool to try once, but I would not order it again since it is not worth the price. The salmon was cooked perfectly, but the rice was underwhelming and a bit mushy.

PASTRIES
On my first visit, I came at around 5pm, close to closing, so most of their pastries were gone. Come earlier for pastries!

I really liked the yuzu meringue tart. The yuzu was perfectly strong and aromatic, and the dessert itself was light/ not heavy on the stomach. I couldn't really taste the matcha in the crust, but it was cool that it was green. I also liked how they torched the meringue on top, which added to the taste and a nice touch to the aesthetics.

The matcha cream pie was nice and air-y. It had too much cream for me, but the matcha filling was on point. The matcha really hits you in the face with this one.

DRINKS
The hojicha latte was really good - strong tea flavor and creamy. The cups are uniquely crafted, and I love the shape and feel of it. 

The sparkling matcha drink with yuzu and cane sugar was an interesting try, but I don't see the hype in it. I couldn't really taste the matcha, as the yuzu overpowered it.  

Seating can usually be found/ turnover rate is high/ people come and go, but just note that it does get busy here.

I love this place so much that I don't really want to share it with other people... I also wish I have a larger stomach, so I can try all their pastries and drinks. If I lived close by, all my money would be spent here...
author: Tiffany H.

description:
Finally a classy Matcha heaven opened in the mission. Vintage blue exteriors, urban vibes, outdoor seatings & authentic matcha. Absolutely a Must-Go. 

- Sleek, classy, modern interiors + a blend of traditional Japanese decors. Classic Furoshiki (bento cloth wrap), bamboo tea whisks, Shimenawa (straw/ hemp ropes). And of course, the "stonemill" that grinds tea powder in the back, and fine ceramics. 

- Ordered a Matcha Cream Pie & Yuzu Meringue tart. 
Matcha Cream Pie is divine!!! 

Freshly-baked, crunchy, buttery pie crust + a white, middle layer of rich, thick vanilla cream, + a bottom layer of green, Matcha cream custard. Tastes absolutely like real tea in cream texture. 5 stars here!  (How do they make this!)

- Yuzu Meringue tart is a bit too sweet. Topped by meringue, the aesthetics are amazing, absolutely IG worthy. Green Tart is of matcha flavor, but not very strong, can barely taste the matcha. Yuzu paste is very intense, with a hint of sour on palate, but quickly taken over by the sweetness. This dessert will go well w/ espresso or unsweetened tea. 

- Overall ambiance is a mixture of urban, cozy, down-to-earth yet classy vibes, plus a hint of reverence for the Japanese tea manners.

- Love friendly staff & navy blue kimono uniform. 

- A delightful surprise & happy experience! Will come back for more.
author: Jess W.

description:
Creme puffs FTW!!!! 

I made the wifey order "one of everything". She returned with 13 items and a receipt for $80... YIKES!!! Whatevs...well worth it! 

There was not one item that I didn't like... or make an interesting sound after the first bite.
author: Stephen Y.

description: I used to live near here and was horribly addicted to coming every single Sunday. I've since gotten a hold of myself and my credit card is happier. In one go I'd get the yuzu sparkling matcha, matcha ochazuke, a dessert (roll cake, cheese cake or any dessert I thought was new), and then the kinako butter chocolate chip cookie to go. *sheepish look* literally this would be like a $35 lunch just for me! It's gone beyond the price of an expensive SF brunch! But it was glorious. I'd recommend any of their expertly made baked goods, any of their matcha drinks but especially the sparkling ones because you can't get them anywhere else, and the tonkatsu sandwich or ochazuke for a savory meal.
author: Terry K.

description:
Really enjoyed my time here and so did my mom.

PARKING: We were able to find parking across the street on a Thursday afternoon after lunch.  It is located in a busy area of the Mission so I could see how parking might be difficult.

WAIT: Came on a Thursday after lunch and it was pretty crowded! There were no seats when we were ordering so I was afraid we wouldn't find something but after waiting about 2 minutes a table opened up.  After ordering, it took about 5-10 minutes for us to get all of our pastries and drinks.

ATMOSPHERE: Love the minimalist, trendy, smooth wooden interior and atmosphere.  I could see it as a nice place for studying or catching up with friends and family.  There is a pretty large window area where it lets in light and on the side you can see them making the matcha and the stonemill.

FOOD: Obviously they are famous for their stone milled matcha.  They have drinks, pastries and food that you can eat.  The pastries do run out (they ran out of the creme puffs and the matcha creme pie at about 3pm on that Thursday so come early!).  You can see everything in the display case but for some of the pastries they bring it to you after you order.

HOJICHA LATTE - I'm not a fan of lattes because I don't really like milk, but I couldn't deny how pretty this drink looked cold.  You can get it cold or hot so if you want it in the pretty glass ask for it cold.  They have 2 milk alternatives (oat and almond milk) so I got it with oat milk.  Next time I'll ask for less milk as it was a little too milky for me.  It comes layered so you have to stir it to give you the milky tea taste.  The hojicha is very delicious, a good roasted tea taste and with the milk it helps sweeten it slightly but it isn't overly sweet.  The Hojicha is a very dark color so you know it's good!  Overall, I think I may have been converted to Hojicha lattes.

BLACK SESAME CREME PUFF - unlike other places such as beard papa, their creme puff was very flaky and light and didn't taste stale or like the breading was tough or "chewy."  It was very good and not overly sweet, with a great black sesame flavor.

MATCHA CREME PIE - I'm not a huge fan of cream so I can't quite speak to this but the pie crust was similar to the creme puff in that it was very light and flaky.  I think I would prefer a more solid crust but this wasn't bad.  The matcha is tasty as well.

Overall, I would definitely recommend if you like Japanese desserts, drinks and other items.
author: Brittany T.

description:
Great concept, a bit on pricey side even for sf, and it's always flooded with people. Most people adhere to the "order first then find a table" policy that is posted on tables, but not everyone. Not stonemill's fault, but hope they're able to find a better process to prevent this -- as it gets quite frustrating.

Food: katsu sando is the most substantial, though I also love the chicken porridge and fish ochazuke.
author: Victoria C.

description:
About 6 years ago, I gave up coffee because at times, it made me act kinda crazy. One minute, I was talking like Mr. Testaverde, and the next I'm was Jessie Spano sing-crying "I'm So Excited". Then, I would be up all night because of the adrenaline rush. The next morning, I would down more coffee and the cycle would continue. 

I went to my doc and she recommended that I cut out caffeine because I was too sensitive to it. 

What?!

How am I supposed to get through those monologue meetings. You know what I'm talking about - there's always THAT one person at work who can spend the entire hour talking about themselves, what they ate for breakfast, and the color of their bowel movement...and you have to act like you care. 

Enter Matcha.
