If the caffeine from coffee makes you act kinda crazy and you absolutely need caffeine to function, Matcha is the answer. It gives you that calm alertness (caffeine + L-theanine) to get through the work day without looking cray cray. I still try to avoid caffeine during the weekdays but when I do indulge, it's with matcha. 

When I read that Stonemill Matcha, a matcha café was opening, I was excited to visit. Unfortunately, my visit was similar to Luna M. and Mei S., leaving me with mixed feelings about the place. 

I visited for an early lunch during a weekday and ordered the following (some for here and some to-go to bring back to work to share):

*Matcha Latte w/ cane sugar ($5 + $1 sub oat milk): https://bit.ly/2x67bAE
*Pork Katsu Sandwich: Fried pork cutlet, tonkatsu sauce, cabbage ($14): https://bit.ly/2Izdguy
*Japanese Soufflé Cheesecake ($6): https://bit.ly/2ID6pfK
*Everything Furikake Croissant w/ cream cheese ($5): https://bit.ly/2rZRRQW
*Chashu Pork Danish ($6): https://bit.ly/2KLQNHw
*Japanese Butter Chocolate Chip Cookies ($3 each): https://bit.ly/2s3JqTU

(+) Matcha Latte was on point and similar to Boba Guys. The matcha had a nice, vegetal bitterness and I liked the creaminess of the oat milk. It was lightly sweetened with cane sugar. 
(+) Pork Katsu Sandwich is a good example of something simple done right - crisp, tender tonkatsu cutlet between fresh, soft white bread with some shredded cabbage for texture. Could have used a touch more tonkatsu sauce though. 
(+) The soufflé cheesecake was light and fluffy soft with a nice citrus essence. My co-worker loved this.

(-) I love Tartine but the Tartine pastries were a HUGE disappointment. Perhaps, I went on an off day but the croissant was doughy, the danish was incredibly dry (the chashu was congealed fat), and the butter chocolate chip cookie was too salty with no texture to it. We didn't finish any of the pastries and cookies. 

As for the service, it was a mixed bag as well (order at the counter, grab a number, and your order will be delivered to you). Lynn, one of the servers was awesome! She's genuinely warm and friendly to all the customers she interacted with. In a perfect world, every server would be like her.

It's a shame the rest of the staff didn't have the same positive vibes. The ladies behind the counter were unfriendly and I felt like a nuisance for even ordering anything at all (I didn't ask any questions and knew exactly what I wanted to order). 

Make sure to check your order because they forgot to give me the soufflé cheesecake and Lynn was kind enough to pack it up to-go for me. 

Minimalist, zen vibe. Since I went on a weekday, it was quiet with mainly laptop campers. There's about 8 two-tops, counter seating, and two dog-friendly tables outside.

While super hyped up, nothing really stood out at Stonemill Matcha to me (except the unwelcoming vibe from some of the staff) so 3 stars it is.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
SF doesn't have many good matcha cafes so I'm happy that Stonemill entered the scene. 

I enjoy their matcha lattes and katsu sando.  They'll sometimes offer strawberry daifuku and matcha chocolate mochi, which are both tasty and complement the lattes well.  I recently tried their roll cake, which was great.  

Pastries that I didn't like as much were the souffle cheesecake (not as fluffy as I'd like), matcha croissant (too dense and lacked matcha flavor), and black sesame cream puff (also too dense).
author: Christine A.

description:
I LOVED this place! Found out about it via Instagram from a friend and knew I wanted to check it out.

I came on a Saturday afternoon and it was packed! Line out the door. But it's still worth it. There is very limited seating inside (as with most cafes in San Francisco) so you may not get a spot on these busy days.

I tried the iced matcha latte and matcha cream puff, both were delicious! 

I love the little touches of this place like the wooden trays people deliver your pastries and coffee on, they've definitely put great thought into the little details, much appreciated.

I'm already looking forward to coming back and trying a different matcha pastry and drink!
author: Monica G.

description:
Really great and unique offerings in SF with a wide range of baked goods and pastries and foods that are perfect for a morning breakfast or lunch. I tried the Salmon Matchazuke, Katsu Sandwiches, Hojicha Latte, Iced Matcha Mizudashi/Cold-brew and a Black Sesame Cream Puff. All the items tastes great, I particularly enjoyed the Katsu Sandwiches and Iced Matcha Tea. The Matchazuke Salmon dish is interesting but not flavorful and the black sesame cream puff was tasty but nothing special. The costs can really rack up here, while I'd love to come back I wouldn't find myself ordering so much again. I'd stick with trying their other Iced Tea and a couple of pastries. 

My overall impression is this cafe really focuses on the aesthetics; food comes out nicely arranged, the workers are in a sharp uniform, everything is clean and crisp here. With unique and interesting food options, the nice decor and warm environment it's no surprise there's such high reviews and buzz about this place.

My only complaint is the seating situation could be improved, you can order food for eat-in but you are on your own to find a table. Sometimes the food may come out before you even get a table so the workers are either searching fruitlessly for your order number or they find you and you have to awkwardly hold your food and pressure people to leave as you stand closer and closer to someone's table.
author: Daniel C.

description:
Love the decor and self-serve water and napkins.

matcha cream puff: if it's you're first time here you should get this, yummy matcha cream puff.

black sesame cream puff: not bad but I prefer the matcha one

cheesesoufflé cheesecake: this is actually more like a lemon cheese cake, it was fresh and moist but had a lemon flavor to it.

matchazuke: great presentation and good flavor, would highly recommend. Not only that but I don't know many Japanese restaurants in the city that even serve ochazuke (tea poured over a rice bowl).

The owner of this restaurant pays attention to detail. Most restaurants remodel and decorate the inside of the restaurant but don't care about the bathroom, however even the bathroom was decorated with attention to detail and it shows nicely.

Pro-Tip: come early (before noon on a weekend) or else all the good pastries will be sold out.
author: Tom P.

description:
It's esssenpesive but did that stop me from coming here? Nope! 

I enjoyed the lattes and felt like they were reasonably priced since that's pretty much the price you'll pay anywhere in the Bay Area if you want quality matcha. (I make my own all the time and I saw no difference) 

The desserts here were great! Not too sweet and there were great balance of flavors. The matcha cream pie is cream heavy but that's just how these pies are! The flavors were just right. Not too sweet or bitter. The crust was okay... but I guess you wouldn't want a super buttery crust since the filling is kind of heavy. The yuzu tart was great! Sweet and a bit tart with earthy flavors from the matcha. 

Didn't even bother with the food because I didn't think it was worth it. The matcha is the star here anyways! 

I came on a Sunday afternoon around 3pm and there was a line out the door. I probably waited about 20 mins? I felt like this would be a great place to chat with friends or get some work done but this place was filled with people since everyone wanted to try out this new matcha place! However, the space seemed pretty big and it didn't feel too packed. There was just a lot of humans coming in and out which kind of throws off the calm and peaceful vibe.
author: Joyce S.

description: If you are looking to have a great Macha Tea experience, this is the place. Very zen, clean and modern little place perfect for relaxing, reading a book or doing some remote work on your lap top. Macha tea with oats milk was amazing.
author: Moy V.

description:
Wow wow wow. I was super impressed by this place! I absolutely loved everything I tried and will definitely come back again with friends! 

Wait: I came here on a Sunday afternoon and there was a line out the door, but it moved relatively quickly, so the wait wasn't long. 

Drink/ food: I got the iced matcha latte with oat milk and it was delicious! Not to sweet at all the oat milk made the drink super creamy! I also got the salmon matchazuke and it was surprisingly good!! I didn't expect how flavorful it was going to be' the salmon was perfectly cooked and very tender. The broth was so delicious and you could definitely taste the matcha, but it wasn't overpowering the dish at all. I would 100% order it next time, in fact I'm already craving more right now!! My mother got the matcha croissant and daifuku mochi. She said that they were ok, but that she's try something different another time! Next time I really want to try the matcha cream pie! It looked so good! 

Service: service was great! The ladies at the cashier were super efficient and friendly. Tables are self seating! 

Parking: it's a pretty busy street with a lot of nice cafes and boutiques. It's basically all street parking.
author: Laura C.

description: Happened to walk by here after soaking in the sun at Dolores park and the iced matcha latte was so refreshing. You can tell the properly dressed staff in blue lab coats are very attentive to detail when making your drinks. The drink was perfect, not too sweet and not too bitter in some cases for matcha drinks. I noticed that was probably because they only have 1 person in charge pouring the already mixed matcha to help standardize the appropriate amount to balance flavor with precision. I really appreciated the quiet ambiance despite being in the center of Mission district. They sell whisks/ceramic bowls and hold demonstrations in the back in case you ever want to whisk up matcha at home.
author: Ronald M.

description:
Really nice ambiance inside. If you're looking for a place to get work done on the weekends, this is not your place. They have a decent amount of seating, but it gets pretty busy and you'll probably end up waiting around for a table.

Matchazuke: Kind of expensive for what you get. There's salmon on a bed of rice with green onion and toasted rice sprinkled on it. The waitress poured the matcha dashi in at the table. Couldn't really taste the matcha in the dashi - just tasted like broth and rice to me. Comforting, but I'm not sure it's worth the price. Salmon was cooked well, texture was great and not dry at all.

Hojicha latte: Yum. I'm not a huge fan of lattes because it's usually too much milk, but this one was great iced. The hojicha flavor was distinct and it wasn't too much milk.

I've tried a number of the pastries and each of them seem unique/worth a try, but nothing has blown me out of the water and they add up fairly quickly. Still, definitely worth a visit and it's a great place to enjoy a quick light meal/dessert & beverage.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Trendy new matcha tea shop / bakery in the Mission district.  The menu has an extensive tea selection and bakery items.  They even have some hot foods on the menu!

I ordered the matcha latte with almond milk and no sugar.  I recommend ordering it with the cane sugar, unless you are on a low sugar diet like me.  We also ordered the Yuzu meringue tart, which tasted like a lemon filling on a green tea tart. Very tasty!  I also ordered the furikake croissant with the cream cheese filling since it was something unique on the menu. It's a nice savory option on the menu if you have less of a sweet tooth.

I would come back to try some of the other items on the menu, especially of the black sesame variety (they ran out!). The place was packed on a Saturday afternoon with a line out the door!
author: Helen T.

description:
StoneMill Matcha makes every visit a special occasion. The pastry selection ranges from a rhubarb gallete to a sesame cream puff to THE BEST MORNING BUN IVE EVER HAD to cookies to whipped cheese cakes. I always get the Mizudashi with an extra shot of matcha. It's like heaven's elixir with evenly distributed matcha which tastes earthy and vegetal without tasting like grass. Lots of matcha can taste bland or like grass, but StoneMill obviously is obsessive about quality. If you need proof that they are trying their hardest to be the best and most artful, check out their toilet paper. #wabisabi 
They say "I left my heart in San Francisco." Well kids, my heart, mind, and palate feel like StoneMill is a cozy place to call home every Sunday afternoon.
author: Chris L.

description:
Love that a little piece of Kyoto is available in the bay. They have a great variety of matcha options and some pastries. From cold brew teas to lattes and fizzes. We ordered a hojicha latte and it was amazingly complex in flavor yet so simple. Rich roasted tea with hints of carmel that was smooth and no hints of burnt-ness. People who are are not used to the deep matcha flavors, hojicha is a good gateway tea. The cold brew genmatcha we ordered was super smooth with a bit of umami which was weird for me since it tasted a little like a cold seaweed soup. The matcha croissant was good, however nothing to rave about... But it had a good matcha flavor and was not greasy or heavy for a crossiant. It even had a slight chew or bounce to the dough which we liked a lot. Highly recommend to try the teas and enjoy! 

OH yeah... Only down side... it gets crowded and you might not get a table. So we ended up standing and eating next to the stone mill. Which wasn't that bad since we got a nice back drop for our photos... but I felt like I was definitely contaminating it with my pastries bites... I'm a messy eater! Don't judge! Lol.
author: Cynthia W.

description:
Yummy matcha drinks and eats in a lovely, airy space. I came by the weekend after their grand opening around lunchtime. While the place was busy, the staff kept things moving efficiently. That said, snagging a table is a sport--there were lots of folks hovering and waiting.

We got the ginger matcha latte; matcha croissant (I believe custom made for Stonemill Matcha from Tartine Manufactory); sparkling matcha with mint, lime, and cane sugar; and katsu sando. Everything was delicious--especially the katsu sando. The bread was soft and divine, and the katsu itself had the perfect texture and flavor. Bonus points for the lovely dishware and all-around attention to detail.

Love this spot and can't wait to return.

Edit: I've been back many times now and can also recommend the sparkling matcha (in both flavors) and the incredible soufflé cheesecake (fluffiest cheesecake I've ever had).
author: Kelly R.

description:
Wow. I've honestly never been so impressed by an opening day. And the general uniqueness of Stonemill Matcha's offerings, pairing modern SF feels (a la morning buns and citrus tarts), with traditional flavors (yuzu, matcha, sesame, everything!). 

The buds and I got there around 9am, an hour after opening. We waited roughly 25mins to get serviced. Overall, they had a fairly good rhythm going of pushing ppl down their bakery, hot foods, drink orders assembly line as quickly as possible. I'm sure it'll get even better with time. 

I did notice while I was waiting that they were having some issues with hot foods coming out too slow or going missing(?). But the waitstaff was extremely apologetic when that happened. And again, I'm sure they'll get better with time. 

As for the order, I started with a matcha sparkling with yuzu and cane sugar. It was delicious. The hint of citrus from the yuzu, with the ever so light sweetness blended extremely well with the matcha. The pastries were shared among the group, and they were: (1) sesame cream puff - which I almost said no to bc I'm not a cream puff fan, but boy am I glad that I got outvoted. Sesame flavor game strong!; (2) everything croissant - my choice, and prob my least fav of the three pastries ordered. There was a cream cheese filling that I wasn't quite expecting. Not bad, but not great; (3) yuzu matcha tart - divine! If you're as much of a citrus dessert fan as I am, don't walk, RUN. All the lemon meringue tart feels, but really with yuzu and matcha uniqueness. This was by far the fav of the pastries. 

Okk and for the main. Oh man, the main. Got the Matchazuke. At first glance, I couldn't order this dish bc they have chicken dashi sprinkled on it...and I didn't want to be difficult. But after talking to the cashier, she said they could easily make this dish pescetarian friendly by swapping it out with fish dashi. Woot woot! And, OMG, this $16 dish was worth EVERY. PENNY. Okay, I've been a pescetarian for nearly 20yrs now. And I've had my fair share of salmon filets in my lifetime. But hands-down, the piece of salmon I got with this dish had to be one of the top 3, if not the top 1, pieces of salmon I've ever had. In my life. And on top of that, the matcha soup drizzle(?) seemed a bit questionable at first, but paired so beautifully with the salmon and rice, that it just all made perfect sense. Would 1000% come back for this dish alone. 

Yes, they're new. And yes, their service wasn't perfect. But the food and drinks and overall ambiance of what they're trying to build was all there. Highly recommended. 5 stars!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
I've been dying to try this place once it opened and I finally had the chance to yesterday. Walking in, you immediately see a line of people standing by the pastry case, waiting to order. Soo many unique pastries, most with matcha, for you to pick from.

My friend and I ordered hojicha latte with oatmilk, sparkling Matcha with mint and lime, Stonemill Cake, matcha white chocolate chip cookie, and strawberry coconut cake roll. 

Everything was simply amazing. The wait was short so you don't have to wait forever your food. The only problem is that there's so many people there's no place to sit. And it takes awhile for someone to clear the table so you may want to flag someone down to do it.

If you're looking for a refreshing drink, you'll definitely want to try the sparkling matcha with lime and mint. You can taste the citrusy flavor of the lime and freshness of the mint.

The hojicha Latte was so amazing, and it's great if you want something a little different from matcha. 

The matcha White Chocolate cookie is soft and chewy with a strong flavor of matcha. The white chocolate chips add sweetness to the cookies.

The strawberry coconut cake roll was so soft and flavorful. While it was tasty, I wanted more of the strawberry flavor. The coconut was much strong.

My favorite dessert though was the Stonemill Cake. Black sesame cake with black sesame icing dusted with matcha powder. Each bite was light and airy and just so flavorful. Each slice is $5 but soo worth it.

If you're looking for a matcha fix, this is definitely the place to go. I'll be returning. A lot.
author: Andrea G.

description:
I loved my first time to Stonemill Matcha!  Stopped in for lunch on a Thursday and although busy, I was able to snag a bar seat in the window. 

Ordered a matcha latte (because when in Rome) half sweet which was good with yummy matcha flavor and a nice froth, but the food and pastries will definitely be what brings me back. 

I had the chicken okayu ($13), and although others have commented on it being on the small side, I thought it was more than enough. It brought me back to when my mom would make jook except this one was dressed with a perfectly cooked egg and plenty of yummy mushrooms. 

Added a mixed green salad for $2.50, and although nothing to write home about it was perfectly dressed and came with a cute flower on top, so the attention to detail was appreciated. 

Finally, the real star of the meal and what will have me thinking about coming back was the white chocolate chip matcha cookie. They have a tartine collab so this should come as no surprise but it was amazing! Moist and gooey as you would expect from a matcha dessert, and while the white chocolate was a great addition it did not take away from the matcha flavor of the cookie which can sometimes happen. Just perfect, I already want another!
author: Adele T.

description:
A gorgeous, clean, and modern space with a delicious matcha-centric menu.

We arrived Saturday morning around 9:30 am and saw a line extending out the door.  The wait wasn't too bad (roughly 20 min) and tables opened up right before our food came out.

What we ordered:

Matcha Latte (one hot and one cold) - I ordered a dash of yuzu syrup in mine and really enjoyed the fresh, citrus taste.  Both were very lightly sweetened, so I'd recommend adding some sugar if you have a sweet tooth.

Matchazuke - Was not expecting this to have such a large portion of salmon!  Loved the combination of flavors when you add their picked veggies to the rice and broth.  Could maybe use a little salt (but I tend to over-salt things).

Katsu Sando - Pork cutlet sandwich was artfully presented and tasty.

Ichigo Daifuku - Strawberry mochi reminded me of our trip to Japan a couple years ago.
author: Sheila C.

description:
Of course this place gets a lot of things right: matcha, Japan, Mission, foodie scene, clean modern environment, artisan... all the things that SF foodie would want, and of course Instagram perfect photos. We tried the black sesame cream puff - amazing and filled to the brim, matcha butter and red bean paste - extremely Japanese actually but probably too light for the taste buds here, ice matcha latte is a must! We ordered a bunch. The matcha taste is intense, the milk is very creamy, perfect for a hot summer day. 

Lines can get super long, and tables very filled. There are some standing rooms, stand-and-drink counter spaces. You get a wood block for your order number. Fortunately most tables rotate after a while, so seats will become available with a bit of patience. I have seen two baby strollers, surprisingly there is enough space for kids but it is a bit hard to navigate for one parent. Merchandise are a bit pricey and in my personal humble opinion not worth it. The drink experience is perfect though. Must try trendy place. 

There are some touches of details that are very artisan Japanese though this place is still different from a matcha cafe you'd find in modern day kyoto or tokyo: cotton yukata like uniform, clean space, custom staff pins, custom stationery and logo, spot clean modern glassware......
author: Dilys S.

description:
Date & Time: Thursday May 10, 2018 @ 5:30pm 
Matcha Date:  The Husband
Scene:  The Artsy Set in Onisuka Hoodies + Tees, Evisu Denim, RFW Tokyo Sneakers & The Professional Set in Beams Plus Suits & Tadashi Shoji Dresses.  While I Love the RTW Sportiness of American Fashion, the Luxury of French Clothing, the Tailoring of Italian Clothes- It is Japanese Style that I Truly Covet
Decor:  Minimalistic & Zen.  Escape the Hustle & Bustle of Valencia St. & Envelope Yourself in Serenity.  Peruse the Fine Merchandise & Treat Yourself to Some Delicate Japanese Wares, Head Over to The Pastry Counter, Indulge in Tarts + Cakes, Sip on Kyoto Matcha & Savor the Moment on the High-Back Banquettes.  You Deserve This.
Service:  Impeccable Japanese Manner
Imbibe:  Whisked Matcha
Devour:  Matcha Cake, Strawberry Matcha Tart, Matcha Soft-Serve
Total:  $13.50
author: Genevieve Y.

description:
I have been on a matcha kick for goodness knows how long so when I saw Stonemill Matcha pop up on Eater SF I knew I had to visit! I followed the progress for a couple of weeks and did my research instantly following them on facebook and instagram. I'd like to say research while others would like to say stalking, lol! 

My first visit was in and out. I circled Mission and Valencia for a couple of minutes to find parking. I arrived around 1:30pm or so, every table was busy. I got my order to go not wanting to wait for a table. I was super hot and sweaty from the walk. I couldn't imagine sitting down because I needed air. I looked at the menu well beforehand knowing I wanted a katsu sando, matcha latte, and matcha cream puff. 

Who am I kidding? It was all about the matcha cream puff that lured me in the first place! The woman at the register questioned my 2 orders of katsu sando because it comes with 3 sandwiches each. I share ..... when I want to. The bread on the katsu sando was incredibly soft, light, and airy. Anything and I mean anything you put in between those two slices would be heaven! Matcha latte was just okay for me, it did the trick which was to cool me down. The matcha cream puff, ohhhhh that filling was perfection. I easily would have eaten three of those but I kept it to one. 

I took a girlfriend with me the second time. We decided to brunch. This time around since there was open seating, I decided to get the matchazuke. I also ordered the hochija latte and the matcha cream pie. The matchazuke was delicious, salmon perfectly cooked sitting on a small bed of rice surrounded by chicken dashi and matcha topped with green onions and nori. Presentation was beautiful as it was delivered in a wooden tray and the dashi was poured by the server. I did not care for the matcha cream pie. It was overly sweet and I could only taste the whip cream, which I kept removing with my fork. I kept waiting for the earthy match taste to come through with each bite but it never came. I left the rest for my friend. The hochija latte may have been the culprit because it was sweet which may have altered my taste buds. However you'd think with the salmon it would reset. 

This is getting long... It's a beautiful cafe and they do have specials so follow them and see what might entice you. I'd visit every now and then to get a cream puff and perhaps a latte but I wouldn't go out of my way to do so.
author: April L.

description:
It's unusual for me to hit a newly opened business; but I made an exception this time.  My friend & I dropped in yesterday Friday around 11:15a.m.  We took a look around and spotted one open table.  She made a beeline for it.  You need to order at the counter; then get a seat with your assigned #.

Uh oh, now I've got to order without her input.  I knew I wanted the pork cutlet sandwich as I just returned from Japan about a month ago. where I had the best pork cutlet sandwich from Daimaru.  And gotta get something matcha related.

So I did the next best thing.  I asked the person at the counter what the popular items were.  She suggested the matchazuke - salmon with scoop of rice with chicken dashi and matcha in addition to my cutlet sando.

Desserts - got the strawberry coconut cream cake & the black sesame cream puff.

Drinks - the matcha latte & the ginger matcha latter.

The staff was very attentive and accommodating as we wanted to share both the food items and the desserts.

If I had to improve anything - I'd request they bring our lattes later in the meal.  Our lattes came first; then our desserts; and last our food.

By the time we had our lattes with our desserts, the lattes were no longer hot.

We enjoyed everything we ordered and left very content.

No coffee on the premises so we went down to a coffee place 1 1/2 blocks east.
author: Shirley N.

description:
YES. I am a matcha fiend and will love any matcha cafe even if it's bougie and crowded (it's in the Mission after all! at least its location is super convenient).

I went on a Saturday around noon and it was packed. You order at the front after ogling all of the yummy pastries they have to offer, get a number, and hopefully find a table. My friend and I ended up standing at this larger counter table the entire time, which worked out but wasn't the most comfortable. We ordered the katsu sando which was super pricey but delicious and some sweets. I loved the look of the Stonemill Cake which was some kind of black sesame cake - it was pretty good and not very sweet but on the drier side. Also tried the black sesame cream puff which was super yummy. I grabbed a matcha croissant and matcha cookie to bring home - the croissant was well made but I don't think the matcha flavor by itself did much. Would be a lot tastier if it had some kind of filling, imo! I did like the cookie, which had stronger flavors. 

All in all, I wasn't blown away by any means but I was happy with almost everything I tried and can definitely see myself coming back!
author: Allison Y.

description:
Ginger matcha?! Sign me up!

It's located in the old Bar Tartine front and I was a bit sad to see that delicious restaurant leave. But so happy that this awesome, minimal lovers matcha shop opened in its place.

It's cozy, bright and serves up tasty ginger matcha. There's a food menu too. I can't wait to try it.
author: Terri L.

description:
Came to visit Stonemill in the afternoon this past weekend. As with many people, I was very excited to visit this place and hoped it would be reminiscent of my time in Japan. 

The decor is very modern - minimalistic and clean. They sell matcha and cups/bowls that are locally made and some napkins and such. There was a short line for tartine pastries and drinks but no one had ordered traditional tea service (located across the room) while I was there. I thought that the traditional matcha service would be popular but everyone was gravitating towards the lattes and iced drinks. 

Since I already ate lunch, I didn't try any of the meal items but they look and sound delicious. My husband and I ordered a matcha latte, a ginger matcha latte, sesame cream puff and a chocolate butter cooker. The total came to $20. 

The lattes were okay. I would agree with other reviewers that the matcha flavor is very very mild. You really don't taste the matcha much. In the ginger matcha latte, you don't taste the matcha at all because the ginger is just so overpowering. It just tasted like ginger + milk. The latte's were $5 and $5.50. Hard pass for taste and price especially when I make better lattes at home. 

Pastries - the sesame cream puff was delicious but the butter cookie was okay. It just tasted like a regular chocolate chip cookie, and for $3, I would not say it was worth the price. 

Overall, this matcha cafe is a nice place to hang out but I can't see myself visiting again unless I was in the area and wanted a cream puff.
author: Serena L.

description:
Opening day, I was surprised at how smoothly they ran and operated. 

They're open from 8am-6pm daily, but they ran out of baked goods around 2 based off their IG story so might be better to go earlier than later.

With that, alot of their baked goods come from Tartine, but that's not what will keep me coming back. 

As great as the black sesame creme puff and yuzu meringue tart were - that katsu sando was phenomenal.

Their chicken okayu was good but I wished there was more of it. It definitely won't fill you up with that alone.

Their matchazuke, the salmon was cooked perfectly. And while the menu states they use a chicken dashi, they can sub it out for a fish dashi for pescatarians.

Their sparkling matcha with yuzu had great flavor, and their ginder matcha latte was so smooth.

I'm excited to come back and try more of the menu.
author: Mandi W.

description:
Had this bookmarked because it looked amazing and went today to try it out. Ordered a matcha latte, a slice of cheesecake, and a furikake croissant. The matcha latte was good, not too sweet, and a relatively good size priced at $5. The cheesecake for $5.50 was the best thing I tried and it had a bit of citrus taste to it. The furikake croissant was definitely my least favorite item - kind of dry and plain for what I was expecting and priced at $5. 

While I don't have any big complaints about anything at Stonemill, I would say nothing I tried was worth the price point. Everything was overpriced in my opinion and most of the food items were quite small.
author: Jacqueline H.

description:
I'm glad I stumbled on this place on my way to the lines at Tartine. I arrived on a Monday afternoon and people were comfortably chatting or working, but there were definitely 6 or 7 spots open. Combined with the minimalist ambiance and simple (yet extensively matcha) menu, the open space in the cafe was the perfect respite for me.

I ordered the matchacate (matcha mixed with hot water, $4.50) and matcha croissant ($5). Though these were a bit pricey, they came in much bigger sizes than you'd think. The matchacate was easily a mug's worth of rich matcha, and I couldn't finish the croissant, which never happens with me and croissants. Out of personal preference, I'd only say that I wish the croissant had a sweet matcha paste on the inside. It is consistently layered with crispy matcha-flavored dough, but personally I was longing for a little sweetness.

Especially given other reviewers' high praise of the cream puffs, I'd like to come back to try more of the pastries and drinks (matcha latte, hand-whisked matcha) on the menu. They seem to be made with care. Also, this place may seem to be "just trendy," but from someone who is not Japanese, it does also seem to be making an effort to share and communicate Japanese tea culture. I look forward to learning more about the art/history of matcha through future visits!
author: Laura C.

description:
Finally, a location that doesn't just offer soy milk as a milk substitute! I'd buy the drinks and food here anyday. 

If you are especially hungry, the sandwiches are super filling. I personally felt that the salmon dish was a gift for the tastebuds.
author: Hillary K.

description: Cute chic store with a limited menu and waves and waves of customers coming in and out. I'm not a matcha fan so I can't speak for the drinks, but I would definitely come back just to people-watch the typical San Franciscans coming here lol. Great style, fashionable outfits, sleek hairstyle, healthy/fit looking, and all about reusable containers.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Great Place! Love it! 
very refreshing drinks and the staff is great! 
Clean, pleasant and always a place to have a time to remember.
author: Juan T.

description: Ginger matcha latte was creamy and just enough foam in top. Also had the apple pudding cake and it was okay but I'm daughter had the green matcha croissant and I couldn't help notice oodles of layers browned to perfection, most croissants are under baked. Nice space,  ERT modern and relaxing in the mission area.
author: Ruby A.

description:
Pretty good desserts, love the beverages, spacing, but not really into the baked pastries. 

- +100 votes for the Katsu Sando, looks and tastes great! 
- Matcha Latte and yuzu soda is amaaaaazing! 
- The fruit swiss roll is also quite tasty-- especially if you have a thing for coconut! 
- The red bean, matcha butter atop toast-- so good! I really liked the buttery matcha thats salty and sweet spread over the toast. 

The space is beautiful, but super popular and crowded so go early or late to get your photos in (;
author: Maggie Y.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this place. It's really a one-of-a-kind in San Francisco right now. No one else has nailed the simple fare Japanese food and drinks that are extremely high quality. This is my favorite place for authentic Japanese food, though it's a bit pricey.

Drinks wise, the Hojicha Latte is quite good. The Yuzu Matcha drink is good but ends up just tasting like Yuzu tonic. Matcha latte is of course a classic, but the Hojicha Latte is a bit more special since less places have it. 

Pastry wise - I'm a huge fan of their cheesecake. It's light, fluffy, very much like a souffley with a proper glaze finish on top. Most people don't serve cheesecake like this in the city. The yuzu meringue tart is also an excellent balance of tart and more neutral flavors. 

The savory food is really what gets me here and keeps me coming back. Not only are the katsu sandos Instagram perfect, but they're actually delicious as well. Perfectly breaded, yet moist katsu sandwiches on delicious white bread. The Matchazuke is also a delicious take on ochazuke. The chicken oyako left a bit to be desired, but more because I'm not familiar with chicken porridge style. The pickled vegetables are excellent to add onto your meals as well, as they offer some distinction to the otherwise heavier flavors. 

The biggest con of this place is that it's too popular and table space is really hard to get. They do churn through tables quickly, but you sometimes feel like a vulture waiting for a table to free up, and then you feel bad sitting here for too long. It's still a great cafe with wonderful food though, but maybe not a place to dawdle for too long in .
author: Jasmine X.

description:
Stonemill Matcha has a diverse menu centered around Matcha. haven't made it to the brick & mortar location yet. this was a popup at a festival

locale: 6th annual Matsuri Festival, Umami Mart (7/28)
offerings:  kakigori(shaved ice with matcha syrup), matcha white chocolate chip cookie, sparkling matcha, sparkling matcha w/yuzu & cane sugar
drink: sparking matcha(4.5)
-original matcha had bitterish taste, cool this means not watered down.
not unexpected as previous matcha experiences all had sugar mixed in. 
3.5 stars

drips:
-service cordial, quick
-would continue ordering matcha without sugar if possible.
doing same with coffee now.
*like getting benefits of caffeine/matcha without burden of calories..
author: Victor G.

description:
4.5 stars

MMMatcha! Naturally, Yelp and all those beautiful photos brought me here. Being a skeptic and a particular person towards all things matcha and Japanese, I kept moderate expectations. Stonemill Matcha surprisingly exceeded them. 

Vibe: Relaxed, clean, and minimalistic. I went to Japan earlier this year and it brought me back. I love the wooden tables, interior design, and how everything has it's own place. The only thing missing? Japanese toilets haha.

Drink: I ordered the ginger matcha latte and my bf ordered the hojicha latte (both hot). Both were good (about $5 each), but the matcha was better in our opinion. The hojicha can use more sweetener. 

Food:
-Matchazuki: rice served with salmon and a matcha flavored broth poured on top. Stir it all up, and it makes a savory and delicious meal for a cold day.

-Tonkatsu sando: a pork cutlet with cabbage and sauce sandwiched in between pillow-soft pieces of bread. It comes in a cute basket. This was my favorite since it makes a light breakfast. 

Dessert:
-Cheesecake: this was okay-tasted like an average cheesecake 

-Black sesame cream puff: delicious! My bf and I fought to finish this. He let me win :p

-Matcha cookie: filled with white chocolate chips. I did enjoy this since the sweetness balanced with the matcha 

I will be coming back to try more delicious goodies. There are croissants, mochi, and more pastries to try! 

Overall, everything was presented beautifully, and most items were delicious.
author: Corinna T.

description:
Love the vibes of this new cafe. Modern decor with earth-tone walls and furniture. Stonemill Matcha specializes in matcha drinks and creates specialty mixes on that theme, like my ginger matcha latte. (Just a touch of ginger to spice things up!) They also had matcha mochi, but while it is DELICIOUS, I would not buy it again for $4 a piece. :(

I  can imagine this place getting quite popular on the weekends and post-lunch coffee time that there might not be enough seating. They had some tables outside, too, if the weather's nice.

Would love to swing by again to check-out their pastries. Ask the baristas/cashiers if you are undecided about what to get. They'll recommend something yummy!
author: Kailin H.

description:
almost didn't come here and am soo thankful I did! they were almost sold out of their pastries on a monday afternoon but thankfully, they have a good amount of cream puffs available. next time i want to eat there and try their matchazuke, katsu sando and other dishes & pastries as well because everything looked delicious. 

MATCHA CREAM PUFF - amazing. the cream was so light (could've been a tad bit stronger) and custard like & the outer shell was a little crispy. it was basically perfect. 

BLACK SESAME CREAM PUFF - not always a fan of black sesame but this was pretty good. it was sweeter than the matcha cream and had a good balance of black sesame flavor.
author: Yan L.

description:
Came here to catch up with some friends on a Saturday morning. Got there around 9am on a saturday, it wasn't busy but once it got to 10 it was super busy. 

I tried the matcha latte cold with less ice, so good. But even tho I asked for less ice their ice is huge and it was still too much for my liking. It was creamery and full of matcha flavor. I also got the katsu with matcha. One word "delicious". It comes with 3 pieces, very flavorful the spread and katsu was paired perfectly. 

The katsu sandwich and matcha latte came out to about $15. It's pricey for the size of latte I got since it was full of ice, but at the same time it's matcha. It's the new thing now. While watching the drink being made, I was wondering why they use pre-mixed matcha and charge $5.50 for it.

My friend got the salmon and rice bowl. The salmon was amazing and so juicy. The matcha soup was unique, it was salty, fishy and a bit sweet; but it worked. 

Will go back to try a hot latte and a friend recommended the barley bowl. The employees are nice, but as it started to get packed it seems like they kind of rush you to leave.
author: Bonnie C.

description:
This is probably my favorite Matcha place in the city! Amazing Matcha latte. Love the food and the vibes. Very friendly and helpful staff.
Unfortunately no WiFi, if there was WiFi then I would probably spend my time there every day.
author: Anna Z.

description:
We came last Sunday (opening weekend) afternoon for a late lunch and surprisingly, the wait was nowhere near as bad as the line looked. Tables seemed to turn over pretty quickly considering how busy the place was. My fiancee waited outside with our dog for one of the two outdoor tables to open up while I got in line inside. 

We ordered a hot hojicha latte (the employee told me it's best served hot), a sparkling matcha with yuzu (creatively delicious but mine was 50% ice), the katsu sando, and the chicken okayu -- I originally wanted the matchazuke instead but it was sold out. Everything was delicious albeit a bit pricey. Yeah I know, this is Valencia Street. For what it's worth, my fiancee was born and raised in Japan and gave the katsu sandwich and the okayu her seal of approval; you simply can't get these dishes elsewhere here!
author: Olivia V.

description:
I went here Saturday around 1pm and it was bustling. I got the salmon dish, katsu sando, sparkling matcha, and matcha latte with almond milk since there was no non-fat milk. The salmon dish was perfect and latte were great. I thought the sparkling matcha - while good- was overpriced at $5. Service is impeccable. 

It was hard to find a table because it was insanely packed. Still, a great experience.
author: Thu P.

description:
Wow wow wow! If you are looking for a delicious, authentic and representative taste of great Matcha dessert, this is the spot! All the dessert are not overly sweet allowing all the notes in the matcha to come through the dessert. The creampuff is also so crunchy on the surface yet chewy once you take a bite!

All in all, I splurged and had the matcha cream puff, black sesame roll cake and the Salmon Matchazuke. I love the Salmon Matchazuke, and I thought the portion was perfect for a satisfying lunch (I am always for adequate proportion in food).

Came here on a weekday lunch so it was not busy. There are also plenty of table seating (some with outlets) if you would like to sneak a little bit of work with pastry to power you through.
author: Priscilla M.

description:
If you're really into matcha, you might love this place. I came here with friends and I thought the store was really cute. The layout is great and it's nice to see them preparing the matcha tea right in front of you at the bar.

They have a few types of matcha but they're all very strong so you have to truly know what you like. The selection of pastries and baked goods were pretty nice if you're looking for something to nibble on. It was pretty crowded so it's not very easy to get a spot here to sit down, especially among all the people with laptops. 

Overall, I probably won't be back unless I need to impress a matcha fiend :)
author: Megan K.

description:
3.75/5
Came by with a friend to study and get some delicious matcha treats. As a study spot this place isn't ideal but it's not bad. There's good lighting and plenty of seats (this place was consistently busy the entire Friday afternoon we were here but there's enough turn over where it wasn't too hard to get a spot). However there doesn't seem to be any outlets and there's no free wifi. There's also servers that come around fairly often to see if you need anything to a point where it was slightly uncomfortable sticking around (they don't rush you out or anything but it's a bit awkward).

For our visit my friend and I got the following
1) Yuzu Meringue Tart: More or less a lemon meringue pie with a twist. I can't even say the twist is the yuzu cause it's so close to lemon (usually I can taste a distinct difference but not so much here). The matcha base was alright but if it was stronger this item would've been more worth getting. The meringue on top was light but it's sat out for a while so the browned bits aren't that distinguishable from the rest. Not bad but not a must get (3.25/5)

2) Matcha Cream Pie: Now THIS is the matcha goodness I've been looking for (despite the fact the matcha portion could actually be a bit stronger). I'm a cream pie person so the ratio of cream to matcha was fine (though like I said, stronger would be nice) especially since the cream was delicious. The fresh milk flavor comes out a lot and it almost has a citrusy undertone. The crust is very buttery and delicious too. (4.5/5)

3) Sparkling Matcha w/ Yuzu and Cane Sugar: My drink. I got it at 1/2 sweetness which was nice and tart like I prefer. Very refreshing at first but like a lot of people said it's a lot of ice. The matcha flavor was noticeable at first but after a while the yuzu dominates the drink. (3.25/5) 

4) Iced Matcha Latte: Friend's drink. Enjoyable and the quality of the matcha is noticeable though once again wish it was stronger. 

Overall I like this spot, I'd say my most consistent complaint is that the matcha flavor just needs to be stronger in almost every item. It's there and the quality is good but the other ingredients mask it.

---The Re-Return: Matcha Cream Pie---
author: Vivian C.

description:
This place is great and located at such a good location. I'm so happy this place is here because San Francisco needs more matcha tea shops. There's so few compared to socal.

The service is always friendly and just after three visits they already recognize me and my dog lol. So far I had the matcha latte and genmatcha. Both very good. The matcha is not too sweet with the right amount of bitterness to it. They also make it pretty fast so that's awesome.

The matcha cookie is also very good. There's several things in it, and I can't tell what's inside it. But it has a nice toasty flavor as well of course matcha flavored cookie. So good.

Overall I definitely will be back!
author: Garrett P.

description:
I honestly could eat here every day, but sadly I don't live in SF anymore. That being said, I've already been here twice since they've opened so that's some commitment. 

With so many things to try, it's surprising that everything I've eaten is amazing. 

MY ALL TIME FAVORITES:
- Katsu Sando
- Ginger Matcha Latte
- Chicken Okayu
- Matchazuke

If you haven't already gone here, it's a new must for SF!!!
author: Kristen C.

description: Brilliant place for all of the ​matcha lover! must try it out! They have the best green tea, that​ tea comes from Kyoto as they said, and the taste is good  I love their katsu sandwich, the best ever!
author: Faye L.

description:
I wish I would have been more diligent and read the reviews prior. As many others have voiced in their reviews, the experience was dampened by the hot mess of a seating situation they have going on. The owner and management needs to adapt and sort this out immediately, or they'll inevitably loss repeat clientele. The food and desserts were a solid 4.5 out of 5, however the stress of having to eat a full meal standing up in the corner while being one of dozens hawkishly vigilant for an available table made the experience undesirable. 

If you plan on sitting down instead of taking out, I'd recommend waiting a few months until they sort things out or the hype dies down, or alternately drop in during the week at a non-peak hour.
author: Alex B.

description:
Lattes, pastries, and toasts!  Oh Matcha!!!

It's pretty rare to see at least one piece of Japanese lifestyle in the Mission District.  Walk into Valencia from 16th St, and you find Stonemill Matcha.  Inside the wide, crisp, and airy space, they have more than just anything that's simply matcha.  It's a great opportunity to have Katsu Sando, a ramen, or even the Matchazuke.  What I have to prefer on my first visit is the Matchacano (the matcha version of Americano) for $4.5.  By finishing the whole cup, its highly potent vegetal flavor has given me more energy and focus needed compared to coffee.  Looking at the matcha I drink is just like ceremonial matcha bowl, except I can't spin the cup when its handle is in the way.

I pretty much enjoy the high end atmosphere, just as pleasant as the customer service and the peace loving patrons.  I be more than glad to come back and buy fancy matcha desserts.  And one more thing; for those of you who missed the SF Matcha Fest at Spark Social, Stonemill Matcha has everything you crave for matcha. ;-)
author: Jimmy C.

description: This is the new hip spot in the mission! Everything is very pricey, but tasted very authentic. I really liked their salmon ochazuke which came out to around $17. The salmon was cooked very well and I am a big fan of their dashi ocha.
author: Annie Z.

description:
This place does a few things well. The line is usually very long on weekends and it's hard to find a seat so be prepared to wait. 

Matchazuke - pretty good small meal. They deep fry the salmon skin separately which is delicious

Matcha Yu Zu tart - way too sweet and does not taste like matcha

Ginger matcha latte - I love ginger and I love matcha but I did not like this latte. The ginger doesn't complement the matcha -- it cuts it so you can't taste the matcha and just taste a sour ginger flavor.

Matcha latte - not anything special.
author: Siri W.

description:
The baked goods are certifiably exquisite, although I found the drinks (i.e. the matcha latte) to be merely OK.

It gets ridiculously mobbed here, especially on weekends, so trying some of the more substantial items on the menu, like the chicken okayu or the katsu sando, just won't feel right unless you eat the items fresh on the premises. Which is impossible given the crowds - made all the more infuriating by laptop loiterers taking up a table long after they've finished their drinks. Because of course.

While the food certainly looks promising, I certainly wouldn't wait in line for a matcha latte that isn't that much more distinguishable from green tea lattes anywhere else. And that's after having taken the time to savor and taste every last drop of my latte slowly and leisurely while sitting at the bike stand directly outside and people-watching along this busy Mission corridor.
author: Vincent L.

description:
I've only been here on a weekday so have never dealt with the long lines. We've tried the matcha and hojicha lattes, the matcha white chocolate cookies, the black sesame cream puff, the kakigori with roasted strawberries, katsu sando, and the matcha cream pie.

I'd give this place 5 stars for the matcha cream pie alone.. it's that good. This is now my favorite pie in the world, it has beaten out the banana cream pie with flakey crust from Mission Pie (still good though). I've inquired about it and here's a PSA: You can order a whole matcha cream pie with 48hrs notice :)

Everything else was good. I'd say my least favorite was the kakigori, but I'd give that a 7/10. 

Besides the food, service is prompt. Don't expect to grab a table though.. We've always had to sit at the little bar table at the center of the cafe, nice and snug with strangers.
author: C. Z.

description: Really nice venue (I appreciated the ceremonial decorations), matcha latte and matcha cream puff were pretty good.
author: Josh L.

description:
This is a super trendy place right now in San Francisco. Over-instagrammed, and long lines are to be expected. Sometimes you fear the hype...

But I was very impressed and not let down. This place seems to have lived up to my anticipation. We tried several real food menu items in addition to pastries and drinks and came away impressed with everything we ordered. The prices may seem high, but in this part of the country, this is reasonably priced believe it or not. 

I know a place is worth a high rating if I start thinking about it several days post-visit. I don't think you'll be let down.
author: Sokokyu K.

description: I can see when this place is empty that it could be a real tranquil place.  That is what 8:00 am is like.  You have time to choose your drug of choice,  pastry of choice.   I can see someone buying everything.  So tempting.  I had to try the sesame cream puff.  Plenty of filling and very sesame and the puff is very crunchy.  The ginger matcha latte wasn't so over powering with the ginger, just ever so light.  It is a treat to go inside.  I would recommend all you matcha lovers out there to try this place.  Unique!   This place is a little heaven.
author: Helen L.

description:
I'm a sucker for matcha and while I find it's growing prominence somewhat disturbing, Stonemill's ginger matcha latte is fantastic. It'd probably be the ideal drink if your stomach was a little messed up too.

I'll try the food at some point, but it all looks rather pricy. Still chazuke is a thing I like and I've never tried it with matcha so that's pretty enticing.
author: Misha T.

description:
My favorite type of coffee shop. It's got bright lights and nice modern feel to it. 

Hojicha Latte. If you want something different other than matcha latte, this is what you should get. It's made of black sesame & the sesame flavor is pretty mild. It's very refreshing! I highly recommend! 

Matcha Latte. If you want a safe option, matcha latte is the one! You can never go wrong with it. It's definitely good!

Matcha Cream Puff. Love that the cream puff is not soggy. That matcha cream is delicious! You might want to share this with someone unless you're super hungry!

Love it here! Need to come back!
author: Mandy W.

description: Love the savory dishes, especially the Matchazuke and Chicken Okayu. The pastries were good, and the decor is beautiful. The presentation of the dishes are well thought out. A great place to mingle, especially outside on a sunny day!
author: Theresa Thao N.

description:
A relatively new cafe that popped up in the Mission district, Stonemill Matcha offers a good selection of, well as its name suggests, matcha drinks and desserts, with some additional Japanese-inspired items on the menu. Stopped by here with a group of friends for a bite, and boy was it packed. Luckily we were able to get a table after a bit of waiting.

I ordered their matcha latte ($5), matcha cream puff ($4.5), and katsu sando ($14). Their matcha latte was rock solid -- strong green tea flavor mixed with a creamy milk, topped with a wonderful latte art. Their matcha cream puff was so good -- the matcha cream had the same strong green tea flavor and the pastry was so light and flaky it mixed with the cream very well.

Their katsu sando came with three relatively small pork cutlets sandwiched in between two fluffy pieces of bread. The taste was okay -- the pork was moist but a bit bland. This was definitely not worth the price, compared to other katsupan places that you can get in Japan for convenient stores (for 3x+ less the price).

Overall, still recommend, though stick with the matcha items.
author: Alvin W.

description:
Our Japanese friend recommended us coming here for a late lunch on a Saturday. It was a BAD idea not because of the food but because of the line! This is a place where they serve both savory and sweet dishes. There are people queuing up for afternoon tea (if you are accustomed to grabbing a snack between lunch and dinner) and for late lunch. 

We got there around 3pm on a Saturday. People were there for coffee, dessert, and for us is savory dishes. We had the pork katsu sandwich (that's what my Japanese friend recommended) and the chicken okayu. We were joking before we got there that we can get the same sandwich at Japanese grocery market. We are wrong of course! The pork cutlet was thick and the okonoyami-like sauce was rich. All of those made the sandwich taste really good. As for the chicken okayu. It is out of this world! It is like porridge but it comes with lot of condiments like pickle and diced deep fried chicken skin (we think). The rice was soaked and cooked with the rich chicken stock. It is just very comforting.

With the savory dish that we ordered and given we were very hungry. We were quite frustrated in finding a seat for our late lunch. We ended up standing at he high table which is next to tea-bar. 

The food is phenomenal(can only comment the savory dish). The wait and the craziness is getting a seat is not fun. It is not a cafe where you can chill and relax because there are people eyeing on you when they can take your seat at least on a Saturday. 

Will come back for matcha-flavored dessert and cakes. But I will try to avoid if you just want to be here to chill and relax.
author: Fontane Y.

description:
I had just came from Japan, so I think I now know what authentic matcha and hojicha taste like.  Also keep in mind that the portions are not American sizes, so if you need to eat a lot to be satisfied, you might have to order more than one food item. 
I had ordered the Chicken Rice Porridge, Matcha Cream Pie, and the Hojichata, while the rest of my party ordered the Katsu sandwich, black sesame creme puff, and fruit roll cake. 
The hojichata was very good and the matcha was also good, but more on the bitter side (which is normal).
The chicken porridge reminded me of more Chinese style, but it was very flavorful and delicious.  The matcha pie tasted more lemony and the black sesame's creme puff was a bit on the hard side. The fruit roll cake was the best out of all of the desserts.
I will definitely be coming back here, but it is definitely heavy on the wallet so probably not for a long time.
author: Ashley Y.

description: Your food such a amazing and purify with everything's i will be came bake again.
author: Joasen J.

description:
The anticipation of checking out this place after jumping on Bart and turning the corner of Valencia was well worth it! Once you walk in, you can feel the simple yet chic zen ambiance that makes you smile and forget about everything else...

5 stars for the savory food
-Matchazuke: tender cooked just right salmon soaked in the soon to be dashi matcha broth...sooooo delicious
-definitely wanna try the katsu sando

4 stars for the sesame cream puff
-sesame cream has just the right sweetness

4 stars for the hojicha latte

Overall love this place
author: Christina M.

description:
Had this on my list to try the yuzu tart and matcha cream pie... unfortunately I came in the late afternoon and they were out of both. Settled for the matcha cream puff, hojicha pot de creme, and kinski morning bun. The cream puff was good and what I imagine the cream pie to taste like, the pot de creme was smooth and delicious but I didnt taste the hojicha flavor as much, and lastly the kinako morning bun was dry...

Nice place to grab some tea and desserts (they also have that hipster oatley milk), however it is very packed and busy. 

Tip: Go early and get first dibs on the goodies!
author: Rachelle T.

description:
Visited this cafe for the first time based on the review. Ordered an iced matcha latte, matcha cream pie, black sesame cream puff, matcha cream puff, and matcha ice cream. 

Pros:
Quality - excellent matcha-flavored drink and food items tasted just like the ones from Kyoto, Japan 
Clean tables 
Welcome vibe friendly and attentive service 
Eco friendly straws etc. 

Cons:
location - difficulty finding street parking 
Crowdedness - getting a table can be challenging during busy hours and a wait line can be long
author: Amy B.

description:
A hip, crowded, newly opened matcha spot that serves mediocre fare.

I arrived here during peak hours on a late Friday afternoon. The space was crowded but the decor was nice. Atmosphere gives off the vibe of a hip new coffee shop. The interior design can be described as bright and contemporary.

Finding seating proved to be difficult. I don't think they have enough seating to accommodate everyone, so many people were taking things to go. The benefit here is that if you are seated, you will be happy by the spacious layout and people being comfortably more than an arm's length away from you.

Their matcha can be described as average. I ordered the matcha latte and one of their matcha pastries. I found the former to be watered down, and the latter to be too sweet. This spot is newly opened so they are popular at the moment, but if you come here for the food you may leave wanting.
author: Chris W.

description:
The basic matcha latte was really really good. Super flavorful. I would definitely come back here for it! The ginger macha latte wasn't really my thing. It felt too gingery, and I normally real like my ginger. But here it just hides the matcha too much in my opinion.

We also got a black sesame cream puff. The cream itself was great, but the shell was meh. Made me appreciate beard papas. 

On the plus side, they have a sign here that asks people not to camp out with their laptops for hours, which is very much appreciated!
author: Igor V.

description:
Japanese matcha realness! 
 
My first time there but already planning a next visit. 
‼
Every bite was complete nirvana.
author: Rich S.

description:
*** In Short ***

Sleek and modern cafe with limited open seating and hit or miss eats.

*** In Depth ***

Okay, so I have to admit, I went to Stonemill twice, on back to back days. Why, you ask? Well, they were sold out of all the pastries I really wanted to try the first day I went, and after hearing a number of friends rave about the katsu sandwich later that day, had to have it in my belly ASAP.

The hits? Their chashu danish (preferably reheated in a toaster at home), the black sesame cream puff, and that katsu sando FOSHO, which, surprisingly, was even better than ones I had back in Tokyo.

As for misses, there seems to be pretty universal disappointment among friends with their drinks for being too bland, and I myself found the roll cake to be pretty unnoteworthy.

The place is pretty popping, so despite the high number of tables, finding an open seat can sometimes be a little difficult. And their pastries definitely do run out, so you'll be safer showing up around noon than anytime after 2pm.

***Accessibility Info***

Venue - Spacious with a wide array of seating, many of which are accessible.

Bathroom - Didn't try them.
author: Johnny W.

description: If you're a matcha lover, you have to come here. Stonemill Matcha has an extensive and unique menu featuring matcha desserts and drinks. I had to restrain myself from ordering the entire menu, which included matcha cream pie, mochi donuts, and matcha affogato. I ended up ordering the iced matcha latte with oat milk (they have almond and regular milk as well) and a matcha mochi (mochi is only available on weekends!)The latte was delicious and not overly sweet, a perfect complement to the matcha mochi, which had a creamy white chocolate matcha filling. Definitely would come back to visit next time I'm in the area.
author: Josephine M.

description:
Stonemill is my new favorite place in the Mission. To me their standouts are their drinks- everything i've tried so far has been fantastic! Strong tea/matcha flavors but still smooth, and the best part is that in all of their lattes they don't go overboard on sweetener! There's just enough to balance out the bitterness of the matcha but not so much that you're left with a weird aftertaste from drinking it. The ginger matcha is my fav but I love the hojicha latte as well. I'm a huge fan of the chicken okayu bowl and the katsu sandwich, which has no right  being as tasty as it is. Both are perfect for lunch! The pastry case I feel like is a little more hit or miss. While I am obsessed with the matcha cream pie and some seasonal items like the homemade poptart, I think most of the pastries from Tartine are a bit of a let down. I've tried both the matcha croissant and kinako morning bun and while the pastry itself is great, the flavors for both don't come through at all - they just taste like plain croissants or morning buns, which i found pretty disappointing. 

The line and availability for seating space can get a little hectic on the weekends towards lunch time, but if you go a little earlier it isn't too bad! I'm so glad we have something like this so close to me hough - there's certainly nothing else like it in the area!
author: Stephany L.

description:
Come early! We went to Stonemill on their opening weekend and it was packed. There was a line to order and almost all the pastries had sold out already - but we were able to grab seats to wait for our food. The katsu sandwich was solid, probably one of the better katsu sandwich interpretations in SF. I decided I should try to come back again another time.

So, I came back again on a weekday morning after yoga, and it was busy a few minutes after opening, but not packed yet. I was able to pick up some pastries this time (pretty good, they collaborate with Tartine on pastries) and an iced matcha latte with oat milk. Definitely great quality, just docking a star because it felt a little pricey between the food, drink and pastry menus.
author: Ada C.

description: Matcha Matcha and all things Matcha, high quality matcha drinks. I tried matcha latte, sparkling matcha, and cold brew matcha. Also, their pastry are well presented, tried matcha cream puff and morning bun. Nice and spacious inside, it is a perfect place for match lover and I am one of them! Bill totals to be $26 for 5 items!
author: Jenny N.

description:
Queue in Sunday afternoon is insane. My party stood for around 20 minutes. The price for lattes is $4.5 for Hojicha, $5 for Matcha, $5.5 for Ginger Matcha. We ordered each kind to try them all. The ginger is fresh and overpowers the matcha taste. Sweetness is perfect on my tongue. My friends got theirs with almond milk which gave a strong almond flavor.

The shop was busy and seemed understaffed - tables couldn't be busted in time.
author: Sherry Z.

description:
I love this place as I love everything matcha. First off, as a drink, I recommend the yuzu matcha. Refreshing and delicious. You can ask them to reduce the sweetness if you don't like things sweet. I got it half sweet and I could barely taste any sweetness. 

I also ordered the chicken okayu which was visually appealing in its presentation and even more delicious to taste. The crispy garlic and green onions added a nice crunch to the savory chicken and soy sauce flavors of the porridge. I really enjoyed the mushrooms as well as a nice additional texture and flavor. I added the togarashi (red pepper) to add some heat and I probably would've enjoyed a little more than just what they gave me.

I also enjoyed ended up getting their matcha cookies which was a little pricey for $3/ea but I really liked to sweet/saltiness of the cookie which had some rice cake specs in it to add crunch and saltiness. The cookie also had enough of a matcha flavor without being overwhelming. 

The only downside is that this place is a little far from where I work but if I get a chance, I'm definitely going back. LOVE. IT.
author: Mark F.

description:
I don't think I've done enough reviews to start doing updates, but this needed to be done!

Since my first visit, I've had the katsu sando, the special kakigori, cheesecake, and matcha cream pie.  The food is so, so excellent!  It's definitely my new favorite cafe/lunch/dessert/snack/study spot.

Tips and Tricks:
-That line is long on weekends!  Head over early on a weekday to get a chance to eat the kakigori and so you can grab a seat.
author: Jessica L.

description: A very hip and trendy place for all things matcha. I love how creative all their pastries look, but overall, I will say that their menu is very focused and a little bit on the pricier side. Even though I'm a sweets person, it's very hard to control my sweet tooth once I'm around desserts and sweet food. So I decided to keep it simple and ordered a matchacano (plain Jane matcha with frothed water). For $5, the quality of the matcha was incredible. The baristas here definitely know how to whisk a cup of matcha, resulting in a smooth-tasting drink. Unfortunately, given the price, I know I can't come here as often as I'd like, but I highly recommend Stonemill Matcha for a high-quality matcha drink!
author: Connie X.

description:
When I heard about Stonemill Matcha's arrival earlier this year, I was excited but also skeptical when it opened--I had just returned from a vacation in Japan and the concept of a matcha-focused cafe seemed a bit gimmicky.

The verdict: it's not gimmicky at all. The matcha lattes are the closest quality to what I've had in Japan, and there's always a line (at least on the weekends). The ambience reminds me of an upscale living room, with Japanese accents. I've always found myself wanting to linger, but that's difficult when there's always people waiting for a table.

When it comes to their matcha lattes, they're my favorite, hands-down. As opposed to Equator's, Asha's, or Boba Guys, Stonemill's lattes have an unmatched depth in their tea, and you can tell they truly care about their craft here when it comes to preparation and presentation. One caveat: their ice cubes are a little large for my taste.

Over three visits I've also had a chance to sample some of their food offerings and sweets. The photos speak for themselves, but I'd highly recommend the Chicken Okayu. The rice porridge is hearty with a great mix of flavors and textures, and gives you a warm feeling in both your stomach and heart.

Quick tip: if you're lactose intolerant choose oat milk for your matcha latte. Unlike other places that use honey or simple syrup, Stonemill uses cane sugar as their sweetener, and oat milk provides a creamier texture. A latte with almond milk might taste slightly watered down.
author: Aaron B.

description:
Matcha is all the rage right now! We walked into Stonemill and we were completely in awe of what a chic space this was. Everything about it was super modern and chic. The wooden counter tops, the seating, the glassware, and the staff's uniform! I'm not the biggest matcha fan, so I need to really love the item to appreciate the matcha flavor. I ordered the matcha ginger latte with almond milk. It was pretty good and they even had a cute latte design on it upon delivery to our table. My husband and I shared the matcha cookie with white chocolate chips - it was very matcha tasting which was OK, but a bit strong for us. The food items look pretty delicious, so maybe next time we'll order those. 

The staff were all really nice and pleasant. Another cute, hipster cafe addition to the Mission! Great place to meet up with friends for small bites and drinks!
author: Diana P.

description:
My boyfriend and I are huge fans of this place! We've been here twice in the past two weeks. The first time we went was around noon on a Saturday, and suprisingly the line wasn't out the door. While we waited, we had time to look at the menu and see what we wanted to eat and drink. While the group ahead of us were ordering, we found a table for two that had just vacated, and so we figured my boyfriend could snatch that spot while I order. Side note: my bf had ankle surgery and wanted to sit asap to avoid some pressure on his ankle (he's in a walking boot and just got off crutches). An employee told him he couldn't sit there until he ordered, and he pointed out I was about to order, but they made him get up regardless. Right after we ordered, we looked over at the same table, hoping no one snatched it up, and a kid was sitting at it, holding the spot for his parent somewhere behind us in line. We thought it was a little unfair that the table was still being held, and that the parent was not told the same thing we were....
BUT! After seeing what was happening, the manager(?) said that they would find us a table ASAP and once one opened up, made sure we could sit. They were super accommodating and sincerely apologetic, which we really appreciated. 

Onto the food and drinks!
1) Katsu sando - get this. We're a little obsessed, so much so that we went back the next week and got it again! The bread was soft and perfect, going really well with the katsu that was nicely breaded too. The sandwich comes with 3 pieces, which was nice instead of the regular 2! 
2) Chicken okayu- I heard people thought the portions were small on this, but for the quality of ingredients, I honestly thought the portion was fit for the price, and I definitely wasn't still hungry afterward. It's served in a deeper bowl, which makes the portion seem smaller, I guess? We loved the poached egg and mushrooms, and the porridge was so flavorful!
3) Iced Hojicha latte with oat milk - honestly, if you like black sesame, I think you'll like this drink. We were also obsessed with this drink...super addicting and had a nuttiness to it with the oat milk.
4) Matcha latte with almond milk- your standard matcha latte; I wouldn't say it was anything special, but it was really good nonetheless
5) black sesame angel cake- this was good! Angel cake is usually a lighter cake anyway, but the black sesame stood out; there was also a glaze over the cake, which added a nice sweetness to it!
author: Shannon N.

description: I love that there are black sesame option. Matcha is good but I've had better. Service is fast. The space is good size but there are so many people. The good thing is that they do not allow people to sit with their laptops. Love the desserts. They also have savory food - that's is awesome.
author: Gloria T.

description: This place seems kind of trendy. It's a nice, modern looking cafe with a good selection of delicious desserts and drinks, most somehow infused with matcha. It was crowded on a Friday at about 2pm, but we managed to get a table for two. We tried an iced matcha latte and a black sesame cream puff, which were both delicious! I would love to go back and try something else!
author: Florence A.

description:
Hrmmm as a matcha lover and Japanese cuisine lover (with standards who has been to Japan multiple times), I was impressed by Stonemill Matcha... at least with the items I've tried so far. I didn't try any pastries from here, maybe next time!

FOOD/DRINK
+ Katsu sando: wow, sooo good. Just like something you would get in Japan. The delicious white bread is soft and fluffy. The katsu was lightly fried with not a lot of grease. The mayo and veggie used had just the right amount of sweetness. All presented neatly in a fine wooden box. Dare me say it's perfect.
+ Chicken okayu: rice porridge with pickled wakame, egg, mushroom and green onion. Texture of the porridge was very good and the accompaniments being a big salty made it tasty. The egg was soft cooked to perfection. I was so impressed by this dish as I was by the katsu sando, but this was beautifully executed nonetheless
+ Miso soup: loaded with mushrooms!
+ Side salad: greens served with sesame dressing. Not particularly special, but was a good cold side item to balance out the other food items
+ Matcha almond latte: got this with zero sugar as you can customize!!! Very smooooth and simply delightful.

AMBIANCE/DECOR
Clean and modern. There is an actual stonemill at the back of the cafe. Tea station in the back. Cashier counter where you order displays various baked goods. They were selling matcha croissants from Tartine, they also have kinako flavored cookies and buns. Seatings at tables and counters available. Due to a lot of customers, you may need to wait a little to get a seat. Nothing too crazy tho.

SERVICE/STAFF
Very good. Got seated, placed number on table. Drink arrived first, followed shortly by utensils and food items. Staff were polite and friendly, asked us if we needed anything else. Staff wore Stonemill Matcha uniform which was cool, too.

It hasn't been a week since my first visit and I already want to return. I want to try the other drinks and food, also will definitely get the katsu sando again. I joked with husband that I wish the katsu sando is available on Caviar or Ubereats, husband said too many pigs will die if that happens. I don't really want that!
author: Iris H.

description: New spot for all my chill hangouts with friends. No wifi here, but delicious matcha lattes with robust flavor. I really like the subdued tones and vibe and their use of quality ceramics to serve food in. Am a fan of the katsu sando and Stonemill cake. Thought the milk bread was meh.
author: Shaw L.

description:
We heard all the buzz and saw the photos and deemed it was worth a drive over the bridge to come check it out. We were there around 10am, hoping to snag a table and enjoy some hoji-cha lattes and katsu sandwiches. Unfortunately all of the tables were taken and we had to take everything to go.

The staff greeted us from behind the counter and they were all very expressionless and looked like they didn't want to be there. Felt like they had been hired solely for their looks rather than whether they can serve. We ordered quite a few items, several pastries to take home, a sandwich to take home, and two hoji-cha lattes, one iced, one hot. They immediately gave us 3 of 5 of the pastries we ordered and they took down our name for our drinks and the sandwich. We had to remind them about the other 2 pastries - if we didn't check, we probably would not have received them.

Both lattes were given to us hot, and I had to mention that I ordered an iced one, and the man had to remake it. Seems like a hassle for such an expensive drink, and I felt bad, but maybe they should have put the order in correctly.

DRINKS: My mom's drink was lukewarm and unimpressive. My latte was good, I liked it, but as I kept drinking it, it started to taste just more and more like an oolong milk tea boba I get from down the street. I could tell the quality of the tea but it just wasn't anything special. Looked nice, so that's a point.

PASTRIES: The pastries are what you should come for. These are ALL good. We got the yuzu tart, matcha cream pie, Japanese baked cheese cake (just like what my mom used to make when I was a kid!), matcha choux cream, and black sesame choux cream. They are all spectacular and well balanced. Not a great aftertaste, but it's expected when you're eating sweets with tea in it.
