Katsu Sand! So yummy. But probably not worth $14. I'd pay $12 at most for the portion. But I suppose in a bougie shop in a neighborhood-turning-bougie, $14 is appropriate. I'd buy this every time if I was willing to pay for it.

Overall, uncomfortable, uninviting, unimpressive. But it was a nice drive over to try it out.
author: Luna M.

description:
Great addition to the neighborhood! Pricey but worth having once in a while. Cool/modern atmosphere that makes it a great spot to catch up with friends!

I enjoyed:
- The Matcha Cream Pie : Globs of matcha and cream dollop a thin flakey crust. The crust itself is the crisp filo texture and not as chewy as I was expecting. Very large portion and quite sweet.

- Sesame Creme Puff : Also a crispy pastry shell and not as chewy as I was expecting. Generous portions of sesame cream that was permeating with natural flavors! 

- Sparkling Matcha with Yuzu : You have to add 50 cents more to get the yuzu but it was worth it! This was really refreshing and not too sweet! It was my favorite.

I liked but not loved it:
- Coconut cake roll : It was a soft cake filled with coconut cream and fruits. It was good but tasted very similar to chinese fruit cake. For the price, it is not worth it!

There is outdoor seating for the dog as well but very limited in space!
author: Tina O.

description:
I love everything with  Matcha, so I'm a big fan of this place!! 

Husband and I got there before 10am on a Saturday morning. I think it was still early, we were able to find  parking immediately on a street spot.  

There was a line at Stonmill but the line wasn't too crazy. The line was just at the door not outside the  door like some posts I saw. 

We ordered matcha latte with Oat Milk, Genmaicha Cold Brew, Matcha Croissant , Katsu sando, 

* Matcha Latte iwth Oat Milk was good.  It had a very matcha tasted and a nice foam top. 

* Matcha Crossiant was big and fluffy.  It was really fresh  because the top layer with crispy. 

* Katsu Sando was something different.  The  katsu was really crispy with the tonkatsu sauce and the cabbage.  Perfect to share with 2 people . 

We also ordered a Sparkling Matcha togo.
author: Stacy L.

description:
I discovered Stonemill Matcha through instagram of several food bloggers that I follow. I knew it was going to be a hub for foodies, instagrammers, and bloggers alike which = super long ridiculous lines. Not to my surprised, the bf and I came on a sunny saturday and the line, as expected was super long.

The location is great, though, with the hustle and bustle of valencia, street parking is hard the find. The ambiance in the store is bright, great for natural lighting. Seating is limited and hard to find due to the influx fo new patrons checking out the goodies. You order up front, decide if you want to go or in store and pray that you'll snatch a seat at one of their tables or small bar stool seating. 

Their menu is vast and encompasses all you can hope for in a world dedicated to Matcha. There is everything from matcha lattes, to fizzy matcha drinks, to straight up matcha. In terms of food, my eye diverted straight to the sweets and baked goods..unfortunately, I didn't get a chance to check out their menu for more substantial food items. 

The BF and I both shared the following:

Matcha croissaint- This was very buttery and flaky as a croissant should be...but to be honest, I didn't particular taste the matcha integrated into the bread. I was cool to look at..and a good tasting croissant, but matcha wise, this was substle.

Matcha Crea Pie- This was probably the golden dish. Dear lord, I can eat an entire pie to myself (and i'm lactose intolerant). This, my friend, was amazing. The creaminess of the filling constrast perfectly with the crust. I must say that it was not overwhelming sweet and you definitely tasted the matcha incorporated in the cream filling. I wish I order 5 slices or more. I would definitely go back for this iteam alone.

Ice Matcha Latte regular and the one with Ginger: Great drinks, well made. Make sure you stir the drink otherwise the concentration of sugar will make it taste to sweet. Perfect drink to have with their dessert.

All in all, this place was worth the hype. The above cost approx $25 dollars and it was worth every penny.
author: Diane T.

description:
Super excited that another matcha shop has open in SF! I'm a huge matcha addict! 

SERVICE: 
I came opening day and waited about 25 minutes before we ordered. The staff is really friendly there and of course they are all familiar with the menu and had recommendations. This cafe works a little like any bakery, you order and they give you a number and you have to find yourself a table. The food comes out pretty quick and they try to clear the tables as fast as possible. 

FOOD: 
Although, they have "matcha" in their name, they service other flavors. They have a selection of bake goods, pastries, drinks and savory plates. I only ordered matcha pastries this time and got: 
+ Matcha cream pie slice $6: I believe this one is a collaboration from Tartine. This is half cream and half matcha. Honestly, I could do without the cream, there was way too much I ended up just removing more than half my pie, and just ate the matcha cream with the thin crust. Flavor wise, the matcha could have been a tad stronger, but other wise a well balance in sugar taste and very smooth in texture! 
+ Matcha Cream Puff $5: the matcha cream in this choux was matcha perfection! A good balance between the bitterness and sweetness, without being too sweet. However, this is very pricey for a small choux.
+ Goma Chocolate Tart $5.5:  This is a chocolate tart with a sesame crisp sheet at the bottom of the tart. I love tarts, and this one did not disappoint me! The texture of the tart held it's shape, was not greasy, the filling was decadent and very smooth. The sesame with a create addition for texture. The presentation was so pretty I felt bad eating it. 
+ Chasu Danish $5: This reminded me of something Baker Doe would make! Very flake and smelled so good! There isn't too much chasu in the middle, but the combo of all the meat, veggies and sauce made a pretty tasty danish! 

They also have matcha bowls, whisk and other utensil for sale (pricey!)

AMBIANCE:
The shop is medium size, with lots of tables for parties of 2 and some for parties of 4. The inside decor is very appropriate for their name and the matcha/Japanese theme. They also have  bathroom located in the back! 

Verdict: Very aesthetically pleasing and tasty Asian flavor inspired bake good. Although just on the pricier side. I am coming back to try their drinks and the matcha salmon!
author: Samantha F.

description:
Matcha cream puff was delicious! Pastry was not dry, not too soft, perfect flakiness and bite to it, cream was tasty not too sweet

Matcha latte was standard, not too sweet. Options for almond or oat milk for a extra $1.

Japanese cheesecake was good too.

Great environment and good for dates.
author: Andy L.

description: This place gets high marks for me. Excellent, innovative menu, everything we tried was delicious. There were plenty of items that made you want to come back and try them again. Service was efficient and friendly. And the space had a hip, energetic feel to it. I also appreciated the tiny gift-type-store in front where you could buy some items. I'm looking forward to trying this place again and again. Fantastic!
author: Jason P.

description: What can I say, the best matcha cream pie ever...I mean I'm not even sure you can get that anywhere else but here. Everything is great, I had to get some cream puffs and cookies to go and that was amazing too. Perfect balance of sweetness and bitterness. I will definitely be back for more!
author: Stephanie W.

description: Felt extremely sick for the next day and a half after drinking a matcha late on Sunday. My friend experienced the same thing. Maybe your liquid match mixture wasn't fresh and had bacteria growing in it? I haven't felt this sick in years.
author: G M.

description:
MATCHA LOVAS, WE GOT ANOTHA ONE.

Seriously though, I was so excited when not one, but TWO matcha cafes opened within a month of each other. I was also a little sad, because I love Cafe Maiko, and I didn't want this place to steal their thunder. After going, I will say that the two places couldn't be more different. If you're looking for a good matcha / hojicha drink fix or you want an amazing matcha ice cream fixin, Cafe Maiko is your spot. Stonehill is a more elegant sit down cafe, where you can also get amazing drinks at, but their food selection is more vast. 

To start with, the ambiance of this place is on point. Everything inside is so serene, and relaxing, even the employees. I was joking that all the employees look like they work for Everlane, just see for yourself ;) (that's a compliment). 

I got a little out of control and ordered about 80% of the things on the menu, because you never know when something is going to go away, right?!

* Ginger matcha latte- Only had a sip of my friends, but this was lovely. Perfect amount of ginger, not to spicy.
* The matcha croissant- underwhelming. No matcha flavor, but the coloring inside was beautiful. It's not like the croissant was bad, I was just disappointed it had no matcha flavor. 
* Furikake croissant- this has cream cheese inside and was really good, although I do wish the croissant was heated up to compliment the cream cheese.
Matchazuke- SO GOOD. If you want more of a meal, definitely go for this. I don't know how they made the matcha-y broth, but wow it was amazing. The little fried salmon chip on the top was also a cute and tasty touch. 
*Matcha cream pie- FAVORITE THING OF ALL. If you're a coconut cream pie fan, and you also love matcha, this is for you. The matcha filling was the perfect puddling like consistency, and the matcha flavor was strong. Crust was also on point. I'm writing this dreaming of a whole pie. 
* Black sesame cream puff- I got this for the black sesame, but I just need to accept the fact that cream puffs aren't my thing. The filling was good, but I just don't love cream puffs. You might. 

They also have this cake that I took a picture of, but couldn't fit into my stomach at the time. I heard it was really good, and I'm excited to try it along with 17 other things on my next visit :)
author: Morgyn T.

description:
This place is riding on that matcha wave in SF! I haven't tried the other recently opened matcha cafe in Japantown yet, and will update my review after I try that one.

My boyfriend and I shared a ginger matcha latte, cold-brew matcha, and katsu sandwich. The cold-brew was so refreshing and smooth, and I love the strong flavor. It was surprisingly not too bitter. I like my drinks without sugar, but there are also options to add cane sugar.

All the items we ordered were delicious! They have pretty fast service despite the long lines too.

Since this place is newly opened, it's still really crowded. I'd definitely come back again for their cold brew matcha :)
author: Alicia L.

description:
Came here on a Saturday afternoon and it was busy. The interior is minimal and elegant - wish we got to eat there but we got our pastries to go since there wasn't much room. Overall, most of the desserts were pretty good and looked delightful. Would probably come back to try the other snacks and mochi.

We got the black sesame cream puff, cheesecake, matcha croissant, yuzu meringue tart and the iced matcha yuzu mint drink.

Black sesame cream puff = amazing!!! Must try if you're a fan of black sesame. Great flavor and cream puff is crispy!

Cheesecake = pretty good, super soft and fluffy. There was a bit of orange zest that made it interesting/different from other Japanese cheesecakes.

Yuzu meringue tart = really good, but tbh it just tasted like key lime pie (a really pretty dessert and instagrammable though)

Matcha croissant = pass on this, it's a mediocre croissant that doesn't have any matcha flavor

Iced drinks are refreshing here but unfortunately 75% ice which is disappointing.
author: Madeline C.

description:
Cute place. Got items to go. 

Got an iced matcha, very good. This is not your Starbucks matcha. Not sweet which I like because you can really taste the matcha. 

Also bought a slice of the stonemill cake and matcha cream pie. Both very good.
author: Angelica G.

description:
Beautiful minimalist wood interior that hosts an array of delicious pastries, savory foods, lattes and what looked like a tea area in back. 

We arrived at 10:30 am on a Saturday morning and waited in a short line. We ordered a matcha latte (w oat milk), the katsu sando, chicken oyaku the small salad, pickles and the two cookies. Everything was phenomenal. I would come back and eat everything again and try even more food. 

The place filled up quickly but wasn't super noisy, good acoustics and a great place for catching up with friends. Can't get over how esthetically pleasing everything was!!
author: Alexa N.

description:
Stopped by on a weekday afternoon to avoid the crowds during the weekend. There was no wait to order, service was fast, and we were able to get a table. The interior is so thoughtfully decorated and looks amazing!

The drinks we tried were the hojicha latte and the sparkling matcha. I loved the hojicha latte, as it was very flavorful and not too milky. I wanted to see how the sparkling matcha tasted plain, but I think it really needs some added sugar (ie: yuzu + sugar option). 

We also ordered the katsu sando, matcha cream puff, and matcha croissant. The katsu sando was tasty, but pretty expensive for the portion size. My favorite was the matcha cream puff, because it had the perfect ratio of cream to pastry (I'm not a fan of cream puffs that are like 75% cream) and the choux dough was super tasty! Would highly recommend! The item I was actually most excited to try was the matcha croissant, but I found it to be disappointing. I personally don't feel like matcha goes well with croissant, because instead of tasting buttery, it just tasted kind of bitter... 

Overall though I had a great experience, and I would definitely come back to try more menu items!
author: Audrey G.

description: This place rocks and will be back as often as i can!
author: Jessica T.

description: Get their pork cutlet sandwich and mint yuzu matcha. This place has incredible food / drinks and an interior that will take your breath away!
author: Jessica M.

description: Came in around 5pm, an hour before closing and unfortunately many of the matcha items were out. It's still soft opening and I will have to return. Big space with many tables and chairs. The yuzu tart is a must try! Tastes almost like lemon curd. I like that it wasn't too sweet. Also tried the Chasu Danish. Tastes good. It has seaweed, a touch of wasabi, onions, Chinese brocolli and diced chasu. The furikake croissant had cream cheese inside, a different take on the bagel and cream cheese. I hope to try more matcha items when I return.
author: Vinkin Ken T.

description:
Pricey stuff. Got the matcha latte with almond milk. A little disappointed that they still add sugar but I mean I guess that's all places. 

It's very hip, the pastries are very aesthetically pleasing but probably no better than your average sweet. A small cookie for $3? No thanks.

The latte was pretty filling and the matcha flavor had a beautiful bitterness. $6 though, I'm good.
author: Lilian K.

description: Really enjoyed the ginger matcha latte made with oat milk! Just the right amount of ginger  Also really loved their sesame cake... the toast with red bean jam is also delish and a unique thing to try!
author: Chelsea G.

description: So sad that the ran out of the Matcha cookie. Tired Matcha latte last time was really good. Ordered sparkling matcha this time was good too for a hot day.
author: Kay H.

description:
Stonemill Matcha is the perfect matcha destination in SF. I went on a Saturday morning around 11:30 am and it was already packed. There are tables, but not as many as this place should have given the popularity. That being said, the tables do turn relatively quickly so as long as you keep an eye out, you can grab one before your food is ready.

In terms of drink offerings, they have a variety of matcha drinks. My girlfriend and I ordered the sparkling matcha and a matcha latte. Both were tasty and well made.

To eat, they have both pastries and savory dishes. We ordered the Matchazuke and the Katsu Sando. They were both very delicious and relatively filling. For dessert, we indulged in the black sesame cake. The cake was moist and not too sweet.

Overall, this is a great place to grab a bite, but if you order a lot, the bill adds up pretty fast. The staff are super friendly and helpful. I look forward to my next visit and trying more things on the menu!.
author: Erik D.

description:
It took me a while to write this review, first of all because I wanted to to multiple items on the menu and second because, selfishly, I don't want this place to get too much hype. I live traditional Japanese food and flavors so this is really one of my favorite spots. I've been here 7-8 times since they opened 3 weeks ago..

Let's start with service: cordial and affable. Everyone at the store is great and the manager always gives me the best suggestions on what to order.

Food: my very favorites for savory are furikake croissant and the salmon matchatsuke. On the sweet side, the chocolate tart and the lemon tart. The chocolate tart has just the right amount of sweetness and had a nice wafery crunch when you eat it. My drink? Hojicha latte with oat milk.

Store: simple and clean. I love that takes are not too crammed one on top of the other.

I am fan.
author: Flora F.

description:
Mixed feelings about this place. The squirt bottle matcha is a big nope. For a $6.50 matcha latte to be made using pre-mixed matcha from a bottle is a bit disappointing. 

On the plus side, squirt bottle does make the delivery time much faster.
author: Ming S.

description:
It has only been 2 weeks since grand opening and we are fans. Line almost goes out the door on a Saturday early afternoon but it moves by quickly. We ordered the Black sesame puff
Affagato with matcha shot
Matcha mizudashi
Katsu sandwiches 
The atmosphere and style of presentation and food is very Japanese. Staff is friendly but you'll need to wait for seating. We very matcha enjoyed it all!
author: Daniel W.

description: The Japanese sweet pastries are legit! The matcha drinks are legit. The space is legit. Too legit to quit.
author: Helen Y.

description:
Very nice interior. 

I am a salmon lover and i liked their salmon dish and katsu sandwich. 
Maybe salmon dish could be better without the matcha sauce but it was fine. (Matcha wasn't as strong as i imagined)

Katsu sandwich was delicious.
Although this place has some decent meals, i think it is more of a cafe than a meal place. It would be a good choice if your friend wants to drink and you also want a light meal :)

If there were more choices for the meal, i would def give a 4 star! It is a unique place in sf area and a pretty familiar place if you have been to Asia alot. Enjoy!
author: Eli K.

description:
Came here on a Saturday around 10am and there was already a line. By the time we ordered (maybe around 10:15/10:20), all the seating was taken. Fortunately for us, we only stood around for a few minutes before a table opened up but boy I definitely felt an adrenaline rush as multiple parties were scanning the room for free tables.

Anyways, here's what we ordered:
1) Matcha latte - 5 stars
2) Matcha croissant- this thing was HUGE! So I recommend asking for a knife if you remember. Also 5 stars.
3) Stonemill Cake- 2 stars- just too sweet
4) Pork Katsu Sando- actually a pretty big portion but around 14 bucks- 5 stars
5) Salmon Matchazuke- star of the show. Salmon was perfectly cooked and the matcha dashi broth was amazing- 5 stars 
Average score: 4.4
Total bill: ~$55 

Will I come back? Probably if I can visit during a weekday or wake up early on the weekend. The lines are already crazy and it's only been opened for 5 weeks! Also note that they only let you sit if you've ordered so there's no claiming seats (not sure how they enforce it). Overall, I'd definitely come back for their savory dishes and drinks. Pastry-wise, everything looks beautiful but I'd have to try more to see if it's worth it.
author: Joanna H.

description: YUM. I am not in this neighborhood a lot so I had to come here. I didn't get a chance to try the food, but had the hojicha latte which was delicious. Good flavor. The space is inviting with an open bar kind of design, and good variety of drinks. Came at 5 pm and there were still plenty of customers chilling on the tables doing work and talking.
author: Wendy L.

description: Yeeessss!! is all I could think when I first read about this place. Then I was so worried I would be disappointed because it was not what I was hoping for....all the things I love about Japan culture and Japanese food all tucked into this unassuming cafe. But, I was right. This place is everything I could ask for and more. Amazingly delicate flavors and desserts with just the right texture and sweetness. I have been a few times and each time I appreciate the food, the service and the vibe more and more. Even when it is busy and a seat is hard to come by the other patrons seem more polite as the relaxed atmosphere instantly calms you. Simply wonderful!!!
author: Speak F.

description: Hojicha Latte with oat milk is a must try! Hojicha is a Japanese green tea that is roasted in a porcelain pot over charcoal. The toasty tea and the oat milk marries perfectly together.
author: Ivy H.

description:
Came for the "opening" on Saturday, came in the AM around 8:30 and there was already a long line. Waited about 25 minutes or so.

The decor was clean and modern. Love the blue store front. There was a mix of groups of friends, couples and young families enjoying the treats. 

The eats are extremely aesthetically pleasing. I brought home the matcha cream pie, the souffle cheesecake, the furikake everything croissant and chashu pastry. Each thing was very very good. 

The only star deduction is for their extremely slow one register service. There was a ton of staff running around but only one person at one square machine very slowly managing the line. There was actually no reason for a line unless they were trying to generate a buzz by showing a line outside. 

Would recommend to a friend, bring friends from out of town, and will continue to enjoy. Hopefully they will be better prepared for their waits or the crowd will die down after the initial intrigue.
author: Natasha B.

description:
Love this place. Authentic Japanese matcha! 
I came here for Sunday lunch and it's very hard to get a seat. We're lucky and found our seats after waiting 10 min but I saw other people waiting for 30 min. 
I had matcha zuke (ochazuke in Japanese) and Hojicha latte. I will try sweets next time!
author: Saki ..

description: Initially, I was not planning to rate stonemill matcha that high. The first thing I tried from here was the Katsu sandwich. While the pork was juicy and the bread was soft, the sandwich was not very flavorful and was very very expensive... I might as well have gone to nijiya for a cheaper a taster katsu sandwich. I was ready to dismiss this place as another hipster hype but then I tried the Matcha mochi and can I say OMG WHERE DID THAT COME FROM AND WHERE CAN I GET MORE?! The matcha mochi was ridiculously mind blowing good. I also bought my boyfriend the furikake pastry and the matcha croissant. He ate then too quickly so I didn't get to try them but he said they were good. He liked the furikake more than the matcha one but he also likes salty more than sweet. I am looking forward to trying more of their desserts and pastries!
author: Jocelyn K.

description:
I had the matcha latte with oat milk here and it was the best one I have had yet. Very smooth and lightly sweetened. I've also tried the ginger matcha latte and agree with other reviews that it has a very strong ginger taste, which is not a bad thing but stick to the regular matcha latte if you don't want the pronounced gingery taste. I have not tried any of the food but the latte alone is worth five stars to me.

The interior is very elegantly decorated. There are small tables to sit at and your drinks and food are brought to your table. You can watch the matcha being whisked and the drinks assembled. If you come early in the day, around 10 AM, there are not that many people and you can sit for a while and get some work done. This is a great place to come with a friend or alone.
author: Mimi S.

description: Super popular place in the Mission, luckily we were able to beat the rush and find a table for three people. The drinks and food are slightly expensive but taste very good, from their pastries to their sandwiches to their matcha latte. The people working there are super friendly and answer any question that you may have.
author: David K.

description:
I love matcha! :) I came here with a group of friends this past Sunday and we were met with a line that went out the door. Despite the crowd, we managed to place our order within 10-15 minutes of waiting in line, and even secured a table for a group of 6.

Drinks: I really liked the iced matcha latte and iced matcha cold brew. There was a good balance of creaminess and sweetness in the latte, with a slight bitterness from the matcha. The cold brew had a smooth and intense matcha flavor.

Food: My 2 favorite food items were the Japanese soufflé cheesecake and the matcha cream puff. The cheesecake was soft, fluffy, and creamy. The cream puff had an amazing matcha filling held by a crispy cream puff. I thought both these items went very well with the matcha beverages. My friends also liked the katsu sandwich.

Service: There was initially some confusion regarding our order, and the wrong items were brought to our table a few times. We also waited a while for one of the items we ordered to arrive at our table. It was a busy day, and we had a relatively bigger party, so it was totally understandable. The server was very helpful and did her best to make sure we got everything we needed at the end.

Overall, I liked my experience here and would definitely return to enjoy a drink and pastries :)
author: Jennifer X.

description: A bougie, trendy matcha cafe in the Mission, you'll find all sorts of creative matcha-based pastries and small dishes at Stonemill Matcha. The iced matcha latte (made with oat milk) was impossible for me to pass up--it was so creamy with just a hint of sweetness, though not cheap by any means. To eat, we also had the pork katsu sando, a simple sandwich of uncrusted white bread with a perfectly breaded pork cutlet, tonkatsu sauce, and cabbage. Despite the good reviews about this dish, I found it extremely bland and not worth the price tag one bit. We also had the matchazuke, a bowl of rice with a matcha-based broth topped with a perfectly cooked chunk of salmon with crispy salmon skin on top. The flavor of this was also quite subtle, though the fish was tender and delicious. But again, the portion size didn't justify the prices at all! Come here to enjoy the drinks and the atmosphere, but don't expect your dollar to take you very far!
author: David K.

description:
This place is incredible.

The vibe, the people, the matcha: amazing.
The pastries easily rank with all the best spots.

Surprisingly, the warm plates are incredibly presented and are comparable to high-end restaurants if not better!!

Really excited to have this place in the neiborhood!!!
author: Mitch L.

description:
Stonemill Matcha is , from the seating arrangements, presentation, and food; this place will keep me coming back.

Walking in, I was already attracted to the seating arrangements. With the afternoon light filtering in through the windows and onto the high ceilings amidst the multiple potted plants, makes for a cheerful, calming environment.

I ordered the matchazuke, matcha cream puff, and matcha latte. And no, it was not a matcha overload because each food item had just the right amount of matcha in it without being overbearing. 

The matcha latte is just perfect. I liked how consistent and strong the taste was throughout the latte. The cream puff had cream that was slightly heavier than whip cream. My cream puff that day was slightly toasted and crispy, but it went nicely with the matcha flavoring. It was also a bigger cream puff too. The matchazuke was surprisingly filling, a good sized appetizer plate, with a good ole scoop of rice and cut of salmon. 

Stonemill Matcha has no WiFi ,and maybe one or two outlets. You can still do work here or bring peeps to socialize and share the food .
author: Brenda B.

description:
I'm a huge fan of matcha and tartine bakery so naturally I had to check this place out. Their pastries on display are all made by tartine but the flavors are specifically meant for Stonemill. They also have a variety of matcha drinks and hot cafe foods as well.

For their pastries, I tried their matcha croissant, kinako morning bun, and the matcha cream puff. I was slightly disappointed with the croissant and morning bun since there are high expectations when tartine is making these pastries. The matcha croissant didn't have much matcha flavor so it essentially ended up tasting like a typical tartine croissant that was green colored. The kinako morning bun had something lacking since it still had the strong orange flavor of a typical morning but but without that sugary exterior we've all grown to love. The matcha cream puff however was a real winner since they pipe the cream after you order it, keeping the cream puff crispy and flaky. Highly recommend eating it immediately after ordering it so it doesn't get soggy.

For their drinks, the ginger matcha latte sounded interesting since they use fresh ginger. I couldn't really taste the matcha since the ginger overpowered the flavor of a subtle matcha taste. The hojicha latte was a winner though since it had a nice deep roasted flavor.

For their cafe food, I tried the matchazuke. It was an interesting concept to use matcha in the dashi broth but ultimately I couldn't really find the matcha flavor much. The dashi broth was really tasty but I feel like adding the matcha didn't do much to add to the flavor of the broth. The salmon was cooked very well and they give a hearty portion of rice with it.

There's so many other items I want to go back and try like their katsu sandwich and black sesame cream puff, I'll definitely be back!
author: Spencer E.

description: I was slightly disappointed by the customer service. One young guy was a bit rude with the table policy and messed up with the food order slightly. The food was average for Tokyo standard and probably above for America. The matcha flavor was not as deep as I'd hope, but that's probably to cater to America's market. I got the chicken ohayu, hojicha pot de creme, matcha cream pie, pork sando, sparkling matcha and cookies. There was no hojicha flavor in the pot de creme, but there was an alcohol flavor which is something I actually like. I was in Japan twice this year already and I visit a few times yearly, so I've been very spoiled when it comes to Japanese food. (I don't dine in B kyu restaurants in Japan either) The order was close to 70 bucks which is an okay for SF Japanese food, but with the crowd and seating policy... I don't think I'll return. The cookies were the least impressive.
author: Kosmo Z.

description: The katsu sando was yummy but I wish the bread was toasted, the matcha cream puff was kinda disappointing bc the matcha cream itself was so yummy but the choux pastry was a little dry and tough, the cheesecake was ok but tasted a little eggy :(
author: Jenny N.

description:
Array of Matcha pastries, coffee and drinks
Quick and Friendly Service
Very Clean and Roomy Seating
author: Wesley O.

description: Meh. So many hipster kids eating silly green stuff and nowhere to sit. Had high expectations but did not fall in love.
author: Fred A.

description: We ordered Katsu Sando, black sesame cream puff, matcha latte, matcha crossiant, chasiu Danish, and matcha cream pie. None of us really impressed with the sandwich or pastries except the cream pie. My friends even dislike the matcha latte.  For us, this place just doesn't worth the drive and the high price.
author: Sharon C.

description: I ordered the Chicken Okayu and was blown away by the amount of flavors from the dish. It's more of a snack/appetizer rather than an entire. However, it's a cafe at the end of the day. Delicious and beautifully presented. I would definitely recommend this dish to any newcomers who are interested in exploring their menu!
author: Jeff C.

description: Got the ginger matcha iced latte and one of their cookies. The ginger was fresh and noticeable but not overpowering. Cookies were small (and expensive) but gooey and dense ~ will definitely come back and get the ginger matcha if I'm in the area
author: Rena L.

description: Honestly feel it's overrated. The decor looks like a Muji store which I guess is quite modern and sophisticated. My main complaint is re: the food I received - I got there on a Friday afternoon to get the shaved ice, and it was made without the strawberries without any explanation. Really took away the balance that the tartness would've provided to what is otherwise a really sweet dessert. PLUS not sure what bothered me more but the texture of the matcha sauce + condensed milk reminded me of slime/saliva. Definitely not in a rush to come back anytime soon. Pretty let down.
author: Katie M.

description:
Hard pass! If you like matcha and Japanese desserts, skip this place.

I've had matcha lattes here as well as a few desserts on several occasions. Without fail the lattes always taste like skim milk with just a faint hint of matcha, which is pre-mixed in a squirt bottle :(

Desserts are waaay too sweet and not at all like the subtle flavor and sweetness that I love in Japanese treats. The prices are too high for the low quality of ingredients that you get.

Always had good interactions with the staff though, so the star is for them.
author: Mina G.

description: This is a really cool Japanese matcha place in town. Everything is very delicious and unique. Definitely recommend it. The only down side is there is always a line, especially on the weekends. You have to order first  and stand in the store waiting for a seat for like 10- 15 minutes. The first time we were here, we had to hold your drinks and plates waiting for people to leave. Try to come during weekdays if possible, weekends are always super easy.
author: Choco W.

description:
For drinks, we had the hojicha latte (so good), and a genmaicha mizudashi.  Both had excellent and distinctly different tea flavors. For food, we had the Katsu sando (lightly crisped) on white bread - so simple but so good, and the veggie and barley salad.

They had plenty of servers and made sure the place was impeccable. My new favorite place! Can't wait to come back and try the pastries!!!
author: Genie S.

description:
Bougie, crowded, long lines, and pricey. What else can you expect from the new instagram hot spot in the Mission? The interior is nice, but they don't make very good use of their space. The line bottlenecks at the door, and they have an excessively long counter space.

We came by to check it out, and the line was already out the door. I got the matcha latte, which was nice and smooth, but not worth $6. I'd rather get a matcha boba at Boba Guys.

The morning bun was good - much better than Tartine's IMO. But the matcha croissant was dry and not very matcha-y OR butter-y.
author: Vivian H.

description: Friendly and respectable service despite being packed on certain days such as weekends. If you order food, the wait time is pretty quick, but the downside is when it's crowded because it can be difficult to find seating. The  matcha quantity to milk ratio is great because other places can't compare. Top choices for pastries are the cheesecake and matcha cream pie. Tip: the Chasu Danish contains wasabi in it. Be careful because it packs a punch. If I had known there was wasabi, I probably wouldn't have gotten it. Stonemill Matcha should add it onto their ingredients description just in case people have allergies. Overall, it's my go to place.
author: Hi B.

description:
Nice place with freshly made bakery. I ordered matcha pie and got satisfied 100%. Lightly sweet nice flavor mouth watering , thank you guys!
Will be back to try matcha teas
author: Yana C.

description:
Come here for the matcha and you won't be disappointed.  The newest, hippest cafe in town that is completely matcha (yes, even the savory dishes).  If you haven't been paying attention, matcha is the latest obsession and Stonemill does not disappoint - everything is exceptional from the food to the drinks, to The interior decor and lighting.  You'll likely have a hard time finding a table unless you go right when they open but to-go is always nice!  

That said, prices are a bit high, even by SF standards.  $6+ for a drink, $4 for a mochi.  Some other desserts are more reasonable priced ($3.5 for a delicious cream puff was totally worth it).
author: Melody L.

description:
Pretty much tried almost everything on their bakery side- came here once for takeout and ended up dining in the next weekend to try their sandwich 

Drinks- tried their hojicha latte and matcha latte, both w/ regular milk and oat milk. Either version tastes great. 

Food from menu- pork katsu sandwich (bigger than I thought it would be, but it was delicious and it was very filling)

Some of the Pastries they had which we got included: 
-yuzu meringue tart (delicious! Must get!), 
-kinako morning bun (sweet like a soft donut), 
-matcha cream puff & black sesame cream puff (packed with cream ), 
-matcha crossiant (not enough matcha taste to it), 
-furikake everything crossiant (smells delicious but next time I need to eat it fresh ), 
-butter chocolate chip cookie (very small & not worth the $3- looked way bigger in other people's photos), 
-chashu danish (maybe b/c I didn't eat it fresh, but it fell apart between layers as I lifted it with a fork)
author: serene h.

description: Love the vibe and ambience. Fast service. A little pricey, but on par with other cafe style places in SF. The sparkling matcha with Yuzu was light, refreshing, and so unique! Not sweet at all, it just hit the spot without being too rich. The Japanese cheesecake was light, though the cheesecake flavor was stronger than other places I have had Japanese cheesecake. All in all, if I was craving matcha or sesame things, I'd stop by again. Lots of seating and decorated similar to a muji store - simple, clean, warm.
author: Cindy L.

description:
I've been to Japan and this place totally brought me back to that great little country that I fell in love with. It's also a beautiful place right in the heart of the Mission.

Here's what I ordered:
1. Hand-Whisked Matcha: 3 Stars 
2. Cheesecake: 5 Stars! It was exactly like the traditional cheesecake I had in Japan. Japanese cheesecake is also my favorite of all cheesecakes.
3. Barley & Veggie Bowl: 5 Stars! Served a pretty big portion. It was delish!

My 3 stars for the Hand-Whisked Matcha is because of the serving. I was served one scoop of water; it wasn't even half full. It literally took 3 good sips to finish. In Japan, they always filled your matcha bowl to the top. And for $10, that's what I was expecting. I was disappointed.

Other than that, this will be my weekly go-to place. And next time, I'll say something about the serving on my Hand-Whisked Matcha.

Note: This place gets pretty crowded after during lunch rush. So, if you want a good seat, get there before 12noon. Otherwise, between 12--2:30pm, good luck finding a seat!
author: Rosa D.

description:
G#D F###ING D@MIT!
Another poorly executed "Matcha" joint.
In short, skip this place.
---
I came in with Japan quality standards, and with one sip of watery matcha latte, dropped to Bay Area standards (extremely low).  

Matcha is pre-made (fail).
Barely any Matcha taste (fail).
One size only (fail).
Can't get an "extra shot" (stronger) of Matcha (fail).
Had the Matcha cookie as well. Tasted like butter and dough, not Matcha. (Epic fail).

No wonder this joke joint wasn't busy on a Sunday Morning.
author: Dan M.

description:
I didn't know that I needed a place like this in my life. I like matcha, but for me it's usually pretty hard to find it done well. This place does it so well. If you're not feeling the traditional matcha- they have fun matcha drinks that are really pleasant.

Their pastries are also really great! It's worth grabbing none if you find yourself in the shop
author: Pierce S.

description:
I've been here two times and have tried a good amount of the sweets / food! Here is what I think is worth ordering:

(1) Katsu sando - yummy katsu sandwich that reminds me of Japan
(2) Black sesame cake - if you like black sesame, def try this cake! It's not too sweet but still has the super asian sesame taste
(3) Strawberry daifuku - this is SO GOOD. you can't go wrong with a strawberry daifuku and I don't know many other places in the city to get one...
(4) Matcha mochi - must try if you love matcha and chewy things!

I've had the cheesecake and it's pretty average - wouldn't order again. The matcha drink is good but nothing special IMO. I've heard the porridge is really tasty from a friend so I'd be down to try that next time!
author: Sophia L.

description:
The line was so inefficient (moving so slow) and the lady at the counter was so rude! We were trying to get takeout pastries and she was so snobby and snappy. I guess just because there was a long line and the place was new (just opened this week) she took customer service for granted. 

I am a fan of matcha but this place definitely left a bad taste. Won't be back again.
author: Amanda L.

description: Highly recommended!!! The desserts were great and less sweet. The place was nice, clean and quite. If you like matcha and lemon, you should try Yuzu.
author: Pinarat S.

description: When we got here, we waited some time to get into the building but that's not why I gave them 1 star. I came here with my fiancée and three other friends. My fiancée and I made one order, and our 3 friends made a second order right after us. We all ordered pastries, drinks, and a sandwich. My fiancée and I got our sandwich and drinks about five minutes after we placed our order. Almost 20 minutes later, other people who ordered after my friends were getting their sandwiches and drinks before them. The workers there did not even bother asking what we were waiting for. So my friend went up to them, and they COMPLETELY FORGOT about their drinks and sandwiches. They didn't even apologized, they just said "oh we'll make your drinks now." Their food was just "alright" and their service was just poor. If I  could give them a negative star, I WOULD.
author: Aaron L.

description: Matcha quality is definitely 5 stars-worthy. Their dessert options, though, leave a lot to be desired. I felt a bit ripped off after paying $8(?) for an anmitsu that was just a single scoop of ice cream, and just two pieces each of the kanten or guhi or whatever the gelatin is and a matcha shiratama (which may not exactly be shiratama if it isn't white).
author: Kazu O.

description:
Matcha matcha Matcha.

The matcha God came and showered matcha powder on this place.

Bougie nice place

The uniforms are also super cool

Food is also pretty delicious

Didn't like the matcha drinks as much as the food with matcha in them
author: Arthur K.

description:
-sparkling matcha with yuzu and cane sugar. Interesting concept, except that the yuzu overpowered the matcha. Could barely taste any matcha at all

-black sesame creampuff. I liked it but seems too expensive for what it is. You're basically paying for the fancy decor and rent. 

-Whats with restaurants slipping in an extra "sf mandate" charge that's a random % between 3-5. I don't care about 30 cents but can't you just be upfront about it and include it on the menu price?
author: Brendan D.

description:
The food here is tasty and presented beautifully. Price is high but I knew that going in. 

You get to play a fun game with the wait staff called how many gigantic tray sized plates can we fit on a tiny two top. Fun game but not super efficient when it comes to actually putting the food in your mouth.
author: Sabrina M.

description:
good spot for breakfast or to hangout. super polite
ppl and clean space. highly recommended!
author: Nee V.

description:
I almost wish Stonemill could split into two separate locations-- one to provide its full-meal options and one for its cafe options.

While the food itself is great (albeit slightly overpriced but it's San Francisco so what isn't?), the fact that it attempts to serve as a cafe and a restaurant makes its  first-come first-serve seating model not make sense. You end up with people standing and holding hot bowls of porridge, waiting for the guy reading his GRE textbook over a half-empty latte to get up.

If seating here wasn't as stressful as rush hour traffic on 101, Stonemill would be a 5/5 experience.
author: Jess L.

description: Finally came here this weekend! I was expecting a line out the door, but luckily the line was pretty short and it moved quickly. If you are a matcha lover like me, you definitely have to go! I got the matcha latte with oat milk (+$1). I have been loving getting my matcha with oat milk lately-I think it complements well together. They had various matcha desserts that all looked delicious. I got the white chocolate matcha mochi (they only have this on the weekend). They have seating, first come first serve. The space is pretty open, so doesn't seem overly crowded, but every table was taken when we got there. We stood at the back table (near where they were selling products). I definitely see myself coming back, I want to try more matcha treats!
author: Kim C.

description: A bit stuffy and the croissant and ginger matcha latte was okay.  It  was hard to find parking in this area.
author: Jboogie L.

description: This is absolutely a great japanese dessert and lunch place. Amazing foof and cakes. And the teas and drinks, you will feel today is the best weekend ever. I dont need to mention any menu. Please go and try.
author: Won Y.

description: The matcha is excellent, as well as the service. Clean, line moves fast so don't fret! Wish there were more outside seatings, though!
author: Morethankimchi J.

description: I came here on a Sunday ~1pm, and there was a decent line that took ~10 mins. We got lucky and found seating right away, but I saw others have to wait much longer for a table. I realized only after I left that I didn't get anything with matcha here!! I got the Katsu Sando ($14) and souffle cheesecake ($5.50). The cheesecake was okay, but I really like the Katsu Sando, and I'll definitely be back for that. I gotta try something with matcha!
author: Annie S.

description: So glad Stonemill Matcha moved into the neighborhood. I love matcha so I'm biased. I get the iced matcha with oat milk because I'm vegan. There could be more options for vegans, especially in the dessert and baked goods department. The desserts look amazing but they have dairy in them. Please source some vegan deserts matcha and black sesame flavors. If you get more vegan options then the vegans will come! I would have given 5 stars if there was a vegan version of any of the desserts.
author: R R.

description:
$5 matcha latte 
$5.5 soufflé cheesecake 
$5.5 matcha cream pie

The latte is ok. People who says "it's the greatest matcha ever".. where exactly have you gone to get Matcha before? Because this taste like regular matcha to me. They use straus milk if you choose dairy. And that's basically boba guys down 2 blocks. 

Soufflé cheesecake is good. Texture is your usual Japanese cheesecake. BUT there's hint of orange zest to it. The portion is small in terms of the price I'm paying. It fills me up, but I would hav even more happy at $4.. I would be more estactic at $3. 

Matcha cream pie is good. Portion is small. The whip cream (which has a bit of lemon or orange in it) is like more than half of the matcha side. The matcha custard is good. But wtf... it's like when the main chacrater of a movie only shows up for 10 min of the movie. 

Was about to get the Katsu Sando.. but that would have been $27! No thank you.
author: Irene C.

description: They have creative food menu. I ordered the Matchazuke because the dish just looked so pretty and too interesting not to try. So far so good. I liked the salmon although the portion was kinda small. It's definitely not enough to fill me up. The matcha cream puff are on the point. Overall, great experience for something I like to try once in a while. I could come back more often for the matcha milk tea though.
author: uyen p.

description:
great atmosphere.  will still get crowded despite having pretty ample seating.

the matcha itself has a very clean, pristine taste. fun to see them milling with the actual stonemill. the folks creating the tea drinks look pretty well trained in matcha with their focused, deliberate movements.

creampuff was nice - cream itself isn't too greasy, has delicate matcha flavor

liked checking out the ceramics they have on sale
author: Marshall Y.

description: My friend that lives local to the area wanted to check out Stonemill.  Of course others were in the same boat so there was a brief wait.  We ended up satisfying our matcha cravings with a matcha latte with almond milk, sparkling matcha, and a furikake croissant.  The drinks were great with high quality matcha.  The furikake croissant was savory and I enjoyed the unique spin on the traditional croissant.  I would definitely recommend making a stop if you enjoy anything matcha flavored!
author: Lani L.

description: Stopped by here after a urban hike down van ness into the mission. Their Matcha latte and may ha cream puffs' were legit- until we saw their pork cutler Sandies and salmon matchazuke. Stop by this spot for a snack between meals. Numba
author: James L.

description: Really enjoy Stonemill. It is super cute and yummy. I surprisingly loved the sparkling matcha. They pastries are good too, I only had one but loved it.
author: Tina L.

description: Lovely space, super unique and high quality desserts and drinks. Get the matcha cream puff.
author: Esther Y.

description:
I may love this place. Happy they're here in my hood. I've been going a few times a week since it opened. The first week it was way more chill. You could find a seat pretty easily and just take it all in. Now it's super busy and loud. Trying to find a seat is a sport. Folks are pretty aggressive about securing a seat. The cafe is gorgeous (ceramics, bar, seating, super cool plants) though I think the lighting may have changed from the first week. It felt softer then.

I'm really happy they offer oat milk as an option. The matcha lattes are delicious. The cold brew was a little too watery for me. I hope they'll start serving a vegan dessert option. It's such a miss. Especially since they said they're going for a mixed vibe of Californian/Japanese. They've figured it out on the milk alternative side why not one dessert option? 

The miso soup is really good but the salmon was a bit bland for us. The presentation is beautiful. All in all, I hope this place sticks around and I hope the menu evolves. It would be cool if they start giving out punch cards for us loyal return customers, you know: come 10 times and get an item for free.
author: Bells F.

description:
The katsu sando tasted exactly like every other katsu I've had except in sandwich form. At $14, it was underwhelming. It wasn't terrible but it wasn't good enough to justify the price. If you've had katsu before, this isn't anything new. 

Matcha latte was good but still nothing special. 

Inside of cafe was really clean and cute.
author: Kathleen C.

description: I really enjoying going to place for sandwiches. This place is solid. The service is great and the staff is really sweet. They go out of their way to make sure you're happy with your order.
author: James L.

description:
Overrated and not customer friendly for various reasons I'm not going to go into here. Other bubble tea places are cheaper and of equal quality. Here, you'll pay $6 plus tax for 12oz matcha latte with half of the cup being ice. I asked for less ice so that I could get more drink, and they left at least 2 inches of empty space in my cup. 

When I asked them for more milk to actually fill my cup, they refused. So, I got less than half of what I would have got for the same price at other bubble tea places. The quality is fine, but it doesn't blow me away. The drink could have used more matcha. I've come a couple times, but won't be going back. Boba guys is so much better, cheaper, and more accommodating to the customer.
author: g b.

description: This place is great! I love all the matcha options. The menu is very unique, I definitely recommend it! I got the soufflé cheesecake and the matcha cream puff. Out of the two, my favorite was the matcha cream puff. The matcha was very light and the pastry was nice and flaky. I thought the soufflé cheesecake was alright, it could have been a little more lighter and fluffier.
author: I K.

description: Beautiful atmosphere with exciting new menu items. I love my matcha and when I saw a Sparkling Matcha on the menu I had to give it a go. Matcha + sparkling water + mint, lime, and sugar cane, an amazing combination! I also recommend the genmaicha it has a great nutty flavor.
author: Robbie P.

description: Got the matcha latte with oat, spot on with a touch of sweetness. Katsu sando was flavorful but not overbearing and not too saucy. The salmon over rice was top notch, salmon, rice - all spot on in being cooked to perfection
author: Eric F.

description: Beautiful atmosphere. A lot of wonderful thought and art behind the food, which is all DELICIOUS. I've had the rice porridge and the katsu sandwich, both had incredible flavor and texture. Highly recommend!!
author: Cassie X.

description:
I've to say this is exactly what SF needs for an authentic  Japanese cafe. It worths every penny I spent here, although I'm not very impressed by the drinks menu here in general. Beside that, the matcha creme pie is enough to make me come back! Match creme pie hands the best - not too rich, not too sweet, right amount of creme with thin & crunchy crust on the base. So FIVE stars solely for that! I also tried the mizudashi both matcha & sencha on two separate occasions. I'd recommend matcha, not the sencha as it tastes fairly bland to me.  

Must try : matcha creme pie (come early tho, last time I was here on Sunday afternoon it was already sold out, pretty much all pastries) 

Drinks & pastries here are def on the pricier side but it's SF Bay Area, what is not expensive here??
author: Kandice Z.

description: Loved the signage on the building. Cool chic place. It was fun to watch the staff prepare food and desserts. Compact place, but they managed to squeeze us in and offered a standing table. We tried a variety of food and desserts.
author: LM D.

description: They have good matcha. I really do love all the matcha options. I'd come back, again and again. Hehe
author: Debra N.

description: Excited to check this out, but I think I ordered the wrong items? Got the matcha croissant ($5), and the matcha flavor is too subtle, it was basically a well made croissant. The matcha latte ($5) was also okay. In short, I was expecting more flavor, but I am open to coming back to try the black sesame and yuzu infused options. They also sold out on cream puffs by 10:15am, and another batch wouldn't be ready for almost an hour. I did feel the order process was fine; select pastries, pay and wait for your items at the end. I really liked the clean, modern, woodsy interior and the geometric bowls used to serve the hot drinks (for sit down orders). Their takeout cups were unique colors too. Anyway, give it a try!
author: Thomas L.

description:
I loved their pork katsu sandwich - so moist and yummy! I also highly recommend their croissants - they are perfect!

The matcha ginger latte could have used more matcha flavor, but I still enjoyed it. Definitely plan on coming here again. I love the ambience as well!
author: Christina C.

description: I am Japanese from Japan and I endorse Stonemill Matcha. There are many establishments here in SF provides Japanese culture and food. The cafe is very unique and one of a kind that you never knew about tea culture in Japan with a twist of cafe style and rituals that you are familiar. I had Hoji cha latte just because it was later in the afternoon and wanted less caffeine in my tea. I also had matcha flavored small sweets to go with it. Ambiance of the cafe made me relaxed and I was able to really taste tea and sweets I ordered. Sweets are made by Kimiko who is a pastry chef from State Bird Provision. Tea leaves are coming from a farm from Kyoto Japan. You can also buy a matcha kit as well as ceramics made by artists from Japan and Bay Area.
author: Miyako U.

description: You are truly paying for an experience at Stonemill. This place is a dream- the aesthetic transported me back to Japan. Luckily, I came early enough to escape the crowd that inevitably showed up at 11a. Prior to that, I was able to experience a quiet morning to enjoy my matcha croissant. The sparkling matcha was refreshingly delightful and in a class of its own. Bring some friends and share some pastries so you don't limit yourself to just one! ;-)
author: Janet P.

description: I went at 3:30pm and it's still crowded, but not to hard to get a seat. The pork sando is pretty good for its price, matcha cream puff is good too. Matcha yuzu pie is way too sweet for asian stomach.
author: Iris W.

description: It was recommended by my foodie client as she said "my new favorite cafe". There was a long line, it took around 7-10minutes to order. It was very busy inside the cafe, but luckily we had gotten a outside table since we had a puppy. The space inside the cafe is beautiful, very clean sleek look  made me feel very zen. Both the dessert server and cashier were very polite. After ordering they handed a number in just a few minutes we had our Iced matcha latte & matcha latte.
author: Natalia F.

description: Really good awesome matcha great to go to super nice staff but you could do better that's why you get 4 stars
author: Lis R.

description: Feel like this spot is the most expensive one on 16th mission district! Whole environment is trendy and nice. I feel like the pastries they offer are coming from some other vendors. Ordered hojicha latte and green tea cream pie, feel like the pie is pretty sweeter than I thought. Will come back during their lunch time to try the katsu sando
author: Nina H.

description: It's very fancy nice place to have a afternoon tea with your friends we ordered salmon with white rice and strawberry shaved ice. The food is amazing.
author: Clancy Y.

description: My boyfriend and I got the Matcha and Sencha Mizudashi which is their cold brew. I'm a lover of cold brew coffee and matcha, but the cold brew here just wasn't worth $5. I felt like I was drinking iced flavored water. I'm sure everything is made with quality ingredients but I left unsatisfied.
author: Cynthia T.

description: The definition of all flash and no substance.  The matcha mizudashi is basically green water with ice
author: Jonathan H.

description: Honestly just the best matcha you can find. The katsu sandwich is unreal.
author: Jackson D.

description: Such a cute little place! They decor was adorable and the bathrooms were really nice. Most importantly, I ordered an iced ginger matcha latte and it was delicious! The price was a little high, but since I was on vacation and it was a unique spot, it seemed worth it.
author: Amanda D.

description: Line is out the door but it's worth the wait. Flavorful matcha that is not too bitter. They have a good selection of pastries as well.
author: Michael W.

description: Second person on day one. Their matcha is the best in the bay, bar none. You won't be able to go back to the second-rate stuff served at most cafes in the city. The sesame angel food cake and soufflé cake were amazing as well. We will be back.
author: Kartik S.

description:
This may be my favorite spot in all of SF 

I went the morning of their grand opening with three friends and I think between all of us, we ordered one of everything! Th pastries here are exquisite and he food is just perfectly balanced and comforting. The drinks, needless to say, are fabulous examples of matcha done right. My favorite stand out items are the wagashi, matcha stonemill cake (light, airy angel foodcake with sesame and matcha), and matcha cream pie. The Japanese cheesecake is amazing too but I guess I just have a soft spot for the basic one you can find in Japantown :)

The food items are great - if you eat pork, the Katsu sando is a can't miss. I am a big fan of the chicken porridge too with all the spices added in and stirred well. The perfect nourishing meal when it's super cold out as it often is in the city.

When I went yesterday, they were testing Japanese shave ice. I'll be eagerly awaiting the release once they perfect the recipe! Looks like it's slated to be matcha or hojicha flavored with kinako and red bean.

Only con is it is pricey, however quality of venue, service, and all in house made food is there. In my opinion, it's a worthy splurge. You won't regret it - and as a note, matcha is so incredibly healthy for you so why not! I'm just glad it's caught on in the West and I can enjoy a very beautiful interpretation here to fulfill my matcha drink and food needs. Hats off to you, stonemill matcha!
author: Ashley G.

description: I had a sparkling matcha drink which was tasty. Good but not amazing. Part of why I also can't give more than 4 stars is it says on Yelp there are gluten free options, however when I went in there was only one gluten free option. And I believe Yelp also says dairy free? But when I asked the staff they practically laughed said there were hardly any dairy free options. The place is super pretty but also sadly rather noisy even on a weekday. I wanted to love it here...so much potential! I'm hoping there can be more gluten free and vegan options so that folks don't get confused when they come here via Yelp.
author: Emily H.

description: Very nice and cozy place. I visit this place almost every day and have some coffee along with deserts and sandwiches. They have friendly stuff, what gives very easy-going atmosphere. I am only suggesting this place, I also visiting this coffee shop on regular bases. Hope to meet you there one day))))
author: Rebecca K.

description: Recommended by a friend. Came here for a brunch on Saturday. The place is pretty busy and seating space is limited, but the food is really good. We got the Matchazuke: the salmon was perfectly cooked, and the crisp on top added extra flavor to it. The rice simmered with matcha tastes pretty good too. The combination works out pretty well. For desserts, we got matcha cream puff and yuzu tart: I highly recommend both! The cream puff is big: super crispy crust filled with a ton of matcha cream. The yuzu tart has a light and fluffy layer of cream on top, yuzu jam in the middle and cookie crust at the bottom. Not overwhelmingly sweet and rich in flavors.
author: Zhihui H.

description: Super unique menu and cute space! Service is impeccable. Albeit a little pricey, the drinks are delicious and matcha-filled. I recommend the sencha cold brew or sparkling matcha with yuzu and sugar; both were very refreshing! I'd come back to try some other food items.
author: Jenny N.

description: Big fan of matcha and big fan of this place. The matcharelli cookies and the black sesame cake are insanely amazing.  I usually get the iced matcha but with no sweetener -- I'm sure that if I kept the sugar it would be even better but it's still lovely. Love the design aesthetic as well.
author: DeAnna C.

description: A very minimalist, Japanese-themed cafe. Insta-worthy for all of those matcha desserts and lattes. They have sandwiches and other savory food too, but the menu is very small.
author: Oxana S.

description:
My wife is from Japan. She says this place is legit and is run by former employees of a well-known Japanese brewery. All I know is that it's the only place within a 400-mile radius to get a matcha latte and pastries in such a nice setting. Basically, you'd have to head down to Los Angeles, and even there most places are set up as fast casual for the youths. Here, it's a spacious, well-lit, modern Japanese experience in the former Bar Tartine. The headliner is the bright green matcha, which is made much differently than coffee or tea and can be observed at the counter in the back. My pick is the hojicha (roasted tea) latte, which has the flavor and consistency almost like very light hot cocoa. 

The food menu is quite large for a cafe and my favorite so far is the tonkatsu (breaded pork cutlet) sandwich, which is made when you order and arrives hot in three sections. Great for sharing. In Japan, tonkatsu sandwiches are a very popular snack item and can be had a convenience stores and train stations, usually sold packaged in the refrigerated section. Stonemill's is the highest execution of this snack I've had so far, and it is likely the best example in the Bay Area: a fried, golden brown juicy pork cutlet is accompanied by a lightly-dressed cole slaw, all pressed between two slices of sturdy bread (crusts cut off) to which Bulldog sauce (a thicker, sweeter version of Worcestershire) has been generously applied. If you enjoy meat and have never had one of these, it will blow your freaking mind.

I have also heard that the salmon over rice is very good, and look forward to trying it next time.

All in all, it's great to see another authentically modern Japanese place open up in San Francisco and provide a new experience to expand beyond the steadily improving ramen, yakitori, and sushi scenes.
author: E L.

description: Stonemill Matcha is nice place to spent your time with your friends. I visit usually Matcha at the weekends and we have a great time and a lot of pleasure.
author: Grace S.

description: I'm obsessed w this place. Everything was delicious. For all my fellow matcha lovers, CHECK THIS PLACE OUT
author: Ella S.

description: The katsu sandwich is very noms! The salmon rice with the soupy matcha is to die for. Everything is pricey, but hey it's SF and don't eat out if you can't afford to. Lunch for two can be around $50 but maybe that's just my FA and my bf. We also ordered the iced matcha, matcha latte, matcha cream puff. It was very matchac heavenly. The ambience is bright, modern and you have to get a bit cozy with your neighbors. I don't really suggest studying.. it's more of a 1st date ordeal or a friends catch up talking about the latest men/trend kind of thing.
author: Jenna L.

description: I've visited two times now and love the matcha latte. Great customer service and super cute decor. Will definitely be back!
author: Elvia D.

description: The desserts are good if a little overpriced. However, don't expect to get any seating here. If you go in, then either claim a seat first (or have a friend do it) or just order to go. They'll bring the dessert out to you, but it does no good if you don't have a seat and you ordered-in. Other than the seating (can you tell it annoyed me?) The cream puffs were great, the way the cafe is designed is pretty nice as well. Definitely a "new thing" people want to try out.
author: Norman-lee D.

description: The place per-se is nice, all the dishes are well made and very interesting and tasty. The overall experience is just ok  too many people in such a small place, too much pressure that makes the whole time you are there quite stressful
author: Luca R.

description: Great matcha latte with oatmilk drink. wished the matcha flavor was a little more obvious. I also enjoyed the matcha meringue tart and the matcha flavor was absent. Counter girl was not that helpful and super short with her answers. but all the other employees seemed cool and friendly.
author: Joss Rane E.

description: I love their Matcha latte with milk.  I also tried it with Oat milk but I prefer the regular milk.  The sesame cake was to die for.  I've here twice in the span of 10 days.  I'm already dreaming of going back.  The service is also very good.
author: Parastoo E.

description:
As a longtime lover of matcha I was excited when reading about the upcoming Stonewall Matcha cafe. The facility is beautiful; the product and service sorely lacking. I was surprised and disappointed to be told they offerred only one type of matcha (why have "matcha" in the name of the establishment?). The sales clerk was rushed, discombobulated and clearly not familiar with the product line.

The hand whisked matcha was not hot when delivered and the serving size was very very small, not at all like what I experienced in Japan or other places that offer matcha.

In addition, there is not nearly enough seating. The place already has a Starbucks vibe - most of the tables were being used by people that were "camping" for who knows how long.

I appreciate what the owners are trying to create and wish them good luck.
author: Chuck C.

description: Overall the food is pretty good and unique, the matcha quality isnt the best I've ever had but it's good quality, the staff however are kinda snobbish and not very warm for the most part which kinda sours it.
author: Emelia W.

description: Looking forward to coming back to try the food, but I was intrigued with the matcha selections. The ginger matcha latte and sparkling matcha were my favorites. The latter was unusual in an unusually favorable way...the mix of dry sparkling with the earthiness of matcha. Beautiful setting, minimalist meets artisanal Japan.
author: A K.

description: Great matcha jasmine lattes; available with almond or coconut milk too. Lovely bibble quiche. A lovely calm place just near times sq. Loved the atmosphere here. Didn't try the cakes but will be back!
author: Macleod R.

description: I love the food and atmosphere​ there, wooden color and very clean place. The hot matcha latte​ is really amazing. but things are expensive.
author: Wi T.

description: Yet another soulless SF hipster coffee shop. I could get past that if the matcha was actually decent. It wasn't. I'm a huge matcha fan and drink it often so I was so disappointed to see everything was pre-made and kept in plastic containers. The matcha had no depth of flavor or richness. It lacked exactly what the space lacked itself, soul. The taste was so offensive I had to toss it out. We paid over $16 for 2 matchas and a cream puff and pretty much threw all of it out. The black sesame cream puff was old and seemed leftover from days ago. I was highly disappointed. Again so much hype, not enough substance. I will NOT be going back!
author: Sara B.

description: It's hard to ignore the pockets of gentrification occurring in the Mission, and it seems to be for the better in terms of restaurants, cafes, and bakeries. The selection of teas and baked goods here are aesthetically pleasing and made from high quality ingredients - especially the matcha green tea. We ordered an original matcha latte, ginger matcha latte (cold), and shared a black sesame cream puff. The lattes were amazing and not overly sweetened while the texture and flavor of the black sesame cream filling complemented the matcha flavors well. It was a little difficult to split the cream puff pastry itself between the two of us -  it was a little too dry and crunchy for me (possibly from being on display too long?). I would really like to try the Stonemill Matcha cake next time - it's a well-camouflaged "stonemill" angel food cake that I contemplated ordering but ultimately decided against. The earthy but modern Japanese cafe interior influenced our decision to linger a little longer and savor each bite and taste of our mid-afternoon snacks that much more. Five stars much?
author: Christine T.

description: It looks like they need a serious training for the servers. Ordered few things, not being served for a ling time. Asked a server, then they ran away, not showing up nearby.  No receipt given so I was treated as I was trying to get a free food. Not pleasant. Decent macha, but nothing special.  Not considering coming back here.
author: C C.

description: Nice coffee shop, but I can feel the tension between the waitress, they are friendly but I can feel they are nerves , don't have smiles on the face. A small bowl of chicken matcha 粥 $13，I think it $$$$$ is just too much !
author: Christina O.

description: Hojicha is amazing, especially the hot one. This place gets really crowded. Haven't tried the food yet but it looks absolutely delicious!
author: Liv T.

description: Really elegant Japanese cafe that reminds me of Kyoto. I thought the food was very good (I've had desserts and their rice/salmon dish), and loved the ice tea. The quality is very high and consistent with prices you'd expect to pay for that type of quality.
author: M H.

description:
Came in on opening day before 8am.  Waited about 30 min.  The lady by the front door was nice and helpful to get the line going.  The lady behind the counter not so much.  Looked rather impatient.  The register was extremely slow otherwise I don't think the wait should be that long.  Maybe they'll improve after working out the opening day kinks.

Got the ginger matcha latte with oat milk.  This drink was rather bland.  i did like the fact that it's not overly sweet.  The katsu sando was delish.  Chicken Okayu was ok and the portion was rather small so not that satisfying.

Also got some items to go.  The matcha mochi was overly sweet which is rather surprising.  I didn't enjoy that at all.  The furikake croissant was probably the best.  The rest of the pastries were just ok.  Would I wait 30 min to get my matcha (though I think it's one of the best) probably not.  If I were in the area maybe but then I could get similar drinks from Samovar which I think is equally good if not better for my taste.

I do like the clean, minimalist ambiance and space.
author: Mei S.

description: Love this place! The savory chicken porridge is such a perfect breakfast/brunch and goes great with the classic iced Matcha. The interior is decorated beautiful and there's a few outdoor tables out front for the good weather.
author: Erin R.

description: I wanted to love Stonemill, but the pastries and dessert were subpar. I wasn't wowed by the matcha croissant, the taste was subtle. The matcha latte was not the best I've had. The mochi dessert was off putting as it didn't taste very authentic. The katsu sando however, was delicious. The ambience was pretty and authentic and I will try to give them another chance.
author: Rachel T.

description:
Katsu Sando, Chicken Okayu and Affogato are excellent, must try.
Also tried matcha and sesame cream puff, the creamy fillings are ok, but the puff is kind of hard almost like sourdough bread.
I'm disappointed on the hot Matcha and Hojicha Latte that we ordered.  They tasted just like milk with sugar. I would expect stronger flavor in the drinks, especially when you name the store with "Matcha".
author: Bob K.

description: I love Stonemill Matcha!! We had the salmon with match broth- so good !!!! Also the Stonemill cake is unexpectedly delicious. Will definitely go back !
author: Somie L.

description: This place is literally what dreams are made of-that is if you're a fun, Instagram-loving, millennial. I don't always mean that as a bad thing. Their food is, of course, all matcha, so feel free to venture out and choose something you would never usually get (go with the matchazuke) because it is a bit on the pricey end. The only issue I had with this place is their seating because even though they're going for that minimalism-vibe, it didn't have to mean go minimal on seats. Either take note from Everlane next door and facilitate people trying to get in, or simply add more tables. :)
author: Geraldine G.

description: I love this cafe, if you are also a fan of matcha you won't be disappointed. Definitely try the weekday matcha shaved ice with strawberries!
author: Janice S.

description: Love the savory and sweets!! Matcha tea is legit!
author: J. L.

description: I was not convinced. The coffee and cake I ordered was okay, but overpriced. The service and the decors were great. Location was weird.
author: Jacky C.

description: I came for the tea, and returned three times for lunch. The best pork cutlet / katsu I've had outside of Japan. The amount of bread vs katsu is perfect. Favorite drink is the matchacano (just the matcha with hot water), which leaves a subtle and smooth aftertaste of the matcha. Haven't tried the lates, but will be back. Premium stuff!
author: Razmig H.

description: I felt like the matcha latte wasn't anything special. It was an okay matcha latte, no complaints. The pastries however I thought were unique, not too sweet, and yummy.
author: Catherine Y.

description: Found Stonemill via Yelp and decided to try it out based on reviews and pictures, and it did NOT disappoint. I tried their classic Iced Matcha Latte w/Almond Milk and their Katsu Sando and both were absolutely delicious. Only problem is how busy the cafe was, it was pretty difficult finding a seat. I hope to try more things in their menu again when I'm in SF again.
author: Denisa P.

description: Great place with unique and delicious items. A bit over crowded but we visited on opening day. The matcha affogato was amazing.
author: Harry P.

description: Besides sushi omakase spots, this is easily one of the most authentic Japanese dining experiences I've had outside of Japan. The pork of the katsu sandwich had right amount of moisture, fat, and resilience.. sauce wasn't too sweet, everything held together by some nice fluffy white bread. Salmon was perfectly cooked, the judicious amount of matcha added to the base stock really elevated the dish and added complexity to the subtle flavors. The space is well lit and comfortable, Japanese minimalist decor but warm and tastefully done. Attention to details everywhere! Hope it doesn't get too busy!
author: Enzhu X.

description: I had a salmon matchazuke, and a strawberry rhubarb galette. Wow! The music was chill, decor pristine, servers were friendly (but not obnoxiously cheerful), and the flavors enhanced each other.
author: iko o.

description: Mmmm this place is amazing for everyone that loves sweets n my mom is one of them this place is so good mmmm ginger licking good
author: Leidy M.

description: Stonemill Matcha has two restrooms! This is awesome since so many cafes in the city only have one restroom (*cough* *cough* Four Barrel). I came here on a busy weekend afternoon and the restroom was reasonably clean.
author: Rest R.

description: Glad I was able to eat at this place today. I doubt I will be back because the line will be horrendous. Matcha was good but I wish there was a stronger matcha flavor. The katsu sando was delicious. Go before the line turns into the Japanese cheesecake line in union square.
author: Fatty A.
