description: My recent fav!!!  What a great place to have authentic matcha and other delicious bites!  I love their perfect mix of Kyoto and SF.  Two of my favorite places. Katsusando is to die for.. and desserts..... Missing one star for there is a room for improvement!  See you again soon.
author: Nami O.

description:
I'm so excited that a "little" matcha cafe like Stonemill Matcha opened up in SF. It's such a beautifully and tastefully designed space. It takes advantage of the layout while giving everyone room to take in the whole experience. 

All the servers who helped us were very kind and patient. We also enjoyed the warm foods and sweets (Mikiko is a genius!). The katsu sando was a reminder of the time I spent in Japan. There was a good balance of bread to protein. However, we wished it came out a little hotter. The congee was warm and hearty. The balance of the egg, wakame, and mushrooms was very tasteful. I like adding the pickles because it brings a kick to the congee. The congee itself has a mild flavor. It reminds me of what I would eat for breakfast as a kid or for every meal when I am sick. The salmon with rice and matcha was a fun combination. The fish was so fresh and well-balanced. It wasn't raw or overcooked. As mentioned earlier, it would have been better for it to come out warmer.

The pastries were a class of their own. A must is the cheesecake. It just melts in your mouth. I never understood the hype of Pablo cheesecake in Japan. This cheesecake is miles better than any Pablo cheesecake you'll ever have. The creme puff with matcha and black sesame are also great options. The flavors are intense and hit the whole range from crunchy to melting in your mouth. Most people don't order the chocolate cake, but it's intense and not overly rich. It has sesame on the bottom. Totally worth ordering, especially for all the chocolate lovers! The mochis are also a must order. Mikiko works so hard daily to prepare the mochi by hand. It's truly a labor of love and you can taste it in every bite. The lemon meringue pie was a little too sweet for us.

For drinks, we got the matcha latte with ginger and oat milk as well as the regular matcha latte and the matcha spritzer with lime and mint. My favorite was the matcha latte with ginger and oat milk COLD. It's so refreshing and the ginger adds a subtle kick. They freshly squeeze ginger juice every day to make sure it's intense without being too bitter or spicy. The matcha spritzer with lime and mint was like a matcha mojito; really light and refreshing and a fun twist on a wonderful drink.

I'm very excited to see all the avenues and roads Stonemill Matcha has ahead. And I look forward to going back many times to try more of the same treats and new treats. Best of luck!
author: Emma L.

description: Beautiful, great service, loved my salad and my iced ginger matcha. Great for a pick up or casual sit down in a stylish spot. Will go again.
author: Margaret C.

description: Amazing modern minimalist decor and interior, wonderful pastries and super delicious savory foods and drinks. A spectacular addition to the neighborhood. We ordered the hojicha latte, ginger matcha latte, yuzu soda, the katsu sando, chicken oyaku, and a bunch of pastries. All of it was DELICIOUS. Great place to catch up with friends. It's super popular and crowded but well worth it much like a lot of places in the city.
author: Jennifer J.

description: Some of the best pastries in San Francisco. Try their mochi and the matcha cookie and pretty much everything. The sparkling matcha water is surprisingly good too.
author: Ari W.

description: DELICIOUS! I am picky about my desserts but Stonemill Matcha did not disappoint. I got the matcha puff pastry and it was perfectly flaky and filled with matcha cream that was just the right consistency. I got it planning to share it with friends but ended up eating all of it myself and not offering any to anyone else because it was too good. After being so impressed with the pastry, I decided to try something else as well. I got the ginger matcha latte and subbed in oat milk instead of regular milk and it was just as good as the pastry. I hate when my lattes are too sweet and taste artificial, but this one was perfectly sweetened to just round out the taste without being overwhelming. The ginger added a little kick, but again, was not overpowering. Would highly, highly recommend this place.
author: Rebecca L.

description: After a year of waiting for this place to open, my roommate and I came here on opening day and enjoyed a couple of matcha lattes.
author: Jacob S.

description: We were really excited to visit stonemill as we've been walking past it for a while. Unfortunately our experience was pretty lackluster, and we decided that we aren't coming back. Firstly, the prices are on the steep side, even for San Francisco - that would be understandable if the quality warranted it. 10$ for a handwhisked matcha (why would you pay a premium for ordering something the way it's made? I don't pay 10$ for a handmade latte or handshaken cocktail...) and 6$ for a latte. My partner and I found the latte decent but nothing to brag about, but the handwhisked matcha was so small it was a joke. We had to politely ask if they made a mistake but they said that's the traditional way. And the matcha tasted average. Certainly better than teavana or Starbucks but you can get a better matcha at the teahouses in japantown for 7$. Plus, you pay tax and mandate on top of it so our three sip matcha and latte came to 20$ with tip. Also there was no information or literature about the matcha, where it comes from, or even if it's organic. I run a tea company so that is something important for tea gnomes like me. The space and ceramics were beautiful, I'll give them that, but I believe that is what the customers are paying for. There also isn't enough seating. If you are trying to be the premier matcha cafe in a city such as SF, step up your game. Hopefully when they recoup the costs of renovating and opening they can make the prices more reasonable. Otherwise better fly to Japan for better matcha at a lower price
author: Vince F.

description: Have been here twice! Always had a great time!!! The line was always so long but it's not that hard to find a seat! Highly recommend chashu danish, okayu, katsusando and soufflé cheesecake!
author: Dessert L.

description: everything is SO good! i love the hojicha latte (although i do wish it was just a tiny bit less sweet) and the cheesecake, its so fluffy!
author: Vicky L.

description: I got the chicken porridge and matcha latte for brunch. Both were really good. I got a puff for dessert too. I wish that they had more variety of food options though.
author: Martha S.

description: the space is beautiful and so is the food.  i had the salmon ochazuke, and it was delicious.  i was so hungry that i scarfed it down in about 5 minutes flat.  i washed this all down w/ a sparkling matcha w/ yuzu and cane sugar.  also delicious and refreshing.  my friend had the toast w/ matcha butter and a red bean jam, and she enjoyed it as well.  i want to come back for the shaved ice (kagigori?), which looked fabulous!
author: Helen T.

description: Had a matcha latte. found it to be all milk and very little matcha. Was expecting that lovely bitter matcha tang but no luck.
author: Brian M.

description: Cool new spot for matcha lovers! First time visiting today but i can probably tell this will become a favorite hang-out place! I had the iced ginger matcha which was amazing and highly recommended! It can get quite busy though so expect a long wait for ordering and finding a table!
author: Sophia V.

description: matcha cream puff was delicious and the regular matcha latte was on point. The place was very nice but it was quite crowded even late afternoon.
author: Virginia W.

description: Braved the line during Pride week and it was so worth it. Friendly staff, beautiful space. Hojicha iced latte and the black sesame angel food cake were incredible.
author: Ivy B.

description: dairy dayrea, prices for westwood n posting implants, for interior hos
author: Mai H.

description: yeah its expensive but what did u expect walking into a place like this. look up the menu before u go if u on a budget. Iced matcha latte, solid, nothing special.  Matcha white chocolate, incredibly sexy, faintly chewy and salty, would get again evem though it's 3$ a pop. Kakiguri (shaved ice) is Really sexy, squeeze in some lime halfway thru to spice it up a lil. U will never hve better shaved ice in ur life time. Treat urself right.
author: Tiffany X.

description: Delicious sesame cream puff. Enjoyed the Katsu sando and the matchazuke. The food came out in a timely fashion, the food was hot. Wish they left the dashi so I can pour it myself instead of pouring the whole thing onto my rice. The staff is friendly.
author: Ka Wan C.

description: We also love this place. Everything is a bit pricey but very good and the presentation and setting are lovely. We especially like the hearty rice porridge and the sando to split between us for breakfast or lunch with a macha or hoji latte. We've tried several of the pastries and all were at least "good". We've been 4-5 times and the only real quibble has been that a few of the staff have seemed a bit lost at times, although all have been warm and welcoming. As mentioned the crowd/line can be daunting- especially on Saturday or at lunch time, at least for now.  Aesthetically it's a bit like going to one of Cory Lee's places for $15 a head rather than $150 +...
author: Jim F.

description:
We dropped in for lunch on Wednesday and got in line to order our food.  The space is very nice - clean design with tables on one side of the restaurant where you try to grab a table after going to the counter to order your food.  We had the Matcha Latte (very toasty and excellent), Katsu sandwich (everything great about Japanese sandwiches if you like them - especially the tarty sweet kewpie mayo which might be house made), Salmon Matchazuke (poached salmon over white rice and a mocha dash broth - excellent) and a simple bowl of white rice (which I would return for - you have to be asian and a rice fan to understand that!)

After lunch we grabbed a matcha cream puff - too dry, and the japanese cheesecake - ok but not exceptional.  They both looked beautiful but the taste and texture where it rates a 7 out of 10 if you have had excellent examples of it elsewhere.

The food overall has all the beautiful umami characteristics that I crave from Japanese food.  I would go back in a heart beat for the hot food, but would pass on the pastries next time.  This is the reverse of what I expected when I got there. Could be the food feels more authentic and the pastry feels more like fusion

The only reason I didn't give 5 stars is the seating system.  When I think of the Japanese doing experience I think of it as being calm and stress free.  Calming colors and soothing textures and service.  The challenge I found with Stonemill Matcha is you order your food at the counter and get your number.  After that you have to stand around trying to hawk a table not quite clear about the etiquette of what is your priority with the other people also waiting for a table with their number.  Did they get there before me?  What happens if my food comes before I get my table?  Am I going to eat salmon in dashi while standing up?  It creates a stress that really brings the experience down a notch.  The cafe and restaurant format where a bro is occupying a table drinking water and doing conference calls will have me thinking twice the next time I go and really prevent me from bringing a guest there in the future as I dont know if I can sit down and enjoy the absolutely exceptional food.   Could be a settling out period for a new restaurant - I hope thats what it is as Stonemill has created a new restaurant that is truly unique in a city where that is pretty hard.
author: Michael L.

description: So good! Very cool place. The char siu croissant is delicious as well as the katsu sandwich.
author: Liz V.
